(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s)

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity wants to publish forecast financial information derived from a Production Target again later, what is it allowed to link that forecast to (its holdings or a project), and what must it include so it can leave out the extra supporting details?
expected_answer: Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to a Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of that kind of forecast financial information that complied with the required content, then a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the otherwise required supporting information, but only if it meets the stated conditions [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The later disclosure must point back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must confirm that all the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement about the disclosed forecast financial information; and if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must include a similarly prominent and proximate statement tailored to that situation [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].

question: When an Authorised Person is subject to restrictions on distributions and is required to prepare and submit a capital conservation plan, what event triggers that plan requirement, what is the submission deadline to the Regulator, and what minimum content must the plan include?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is subject to the restrictions on distributions must also prepare and submit a capital conservation plan as part of its required actions [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e]. The specific trigger for that plan obligation is the Authorised Person failing to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, and the plan must be submitted to the Regulator no later than five business days after the Authorised Person identified that failure [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e]. The plan is not merely a notice; it must contain defined minimum elements, including estimates of income and expenditure and a forecast balance sheet, measures to increase the CET1 Capital of the Authorised Person, and a plan and timeframe for increasing CET1 Capital with the objective of restoring the Combined Buffer [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e]. In addition, the Authorised Person must include any other information the Regulator might need to carry out its considerations effectively, ensuring the submission is complete and usable for regulatory review [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e].

Finally, it must include any other information the Regulator might need to carry out its considerations effectively, so the Authorised Person should ensure the submission is complete and responsive to regulatory needs [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e].

question: For purposes of defining AT1 Capital, how must an Authorised Person determine what constitutes the sum of AT1 Capital elements, including which capital elements are included and how any later deductions affect the resulting amount?
expected_answer: AT1 Capital (referred to as Additional Tier 1 Capital) is defined as an aggregate measure built from specified AT1 Capital elements, but it is not merely a gross total. Under the definition that frames the overall construct, AT1 Capital constitutes the sum of the AT1 Capital elements identified for this purpose, and that sum is expressly subject to deductions that are stipulated later in the same Section, meaning the final AT1 Capital amount must reflect those subsequent deductions rather than only the initial aggregation [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9]. The capital elements that make up the initial sum are defined to include (i) capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria laid down elsewhere and (ii) the share premium accounts related to those eligible instruments, so both the qualifying instruments and their associated share premium accounts are included in the starting total [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. Read together, the definition requires first identifying these included elements and then applying the later-stipulated deductions to arrive at AT1 Capital.

answer_spans.text:
AT1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements:
(a)	capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.

question: What exactly is included when you add up AT1 Capital, and do you have to adjust that total for anything later in the same Section?
expected_answer: AT1 Capital (Additional Tier 1 Capital) is defined as a sum, but it is a sum with a required adjustment. First, you identify the AT1 Capital elements that are included in the calculation. Those elements consist of two components: (a) capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria laid down elsewhere, and (b) the share premium accounts related to those eligible instruments, so both the instruments and their related share premium accounts form part of the initial total [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. Second, you do not stop at that gross sum. The definition that sets the overall approach states that AT1 Capital constitutes the sum of the relevant AT1 Capital elements, but it is expressly “subject to the deductions stipulated later in this Section,” meaning the final AT1 Capital figure must be reduced by whatever deductions are set out later in the same Section [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9]. So, you add the included elements and then apply the later deductions to reach the final amount.

answer_spans.text:
AT1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements:
(a)	capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.

The required action is payment of the stated amount to the Regulator as part of the application process, with the applicability anchored by the Spot Commodities/Recognised Body context.

question: If an application is about Spot Commodities activities that a Recognised Body (a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House) will carry out, what fee does the Applicant have to pay to the Regulator when applying to deal in investments as principal (not as a matched principal)?
expected_answer: When an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be undertaken by a Recognised Body—meaning either a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House—the relevant application-fee regime is the one that applies to that Spot Commodities/Recognised Body scenario [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]. Under the obligation for the specific permission and activity described, an Applicant who applies for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, but not as a Matched Principal, must pay an application fee of $40,000 to the Regulator [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c]. So, if both conditions are met—(1) the application is tied to Spot Commodities activities undertaken by the specified type of Recognised Body, and (2) the Applicant is applying to deal as principal (excluding matched principal)—the required payment is $40,000, and it must be paid to the Regulator as part of the application.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, under what conditions may a subsequent disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates omit the detailed content otherwise required in the original disclosure, and what minimum statement must still be presented prominently and close to the estimates?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that is disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation must ordinarily include the full set of specified content in its disclosure, including a prominent and proximate statement addressing the nature and limitations of the Non-Equivalent Estimates, along with other prescribed supporting information (such as sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and verification plans) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. However, where the Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in a manner that complied with those requirements, a later disclosure made in respect of the same Non-Equivalent Estimates is permitted to omit the information otherwise required, provided three conditions are met: it must reference the earlier compliant disclosure; it must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier compliant information continues to apply and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard; and it must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the same matters as the original prominent statement requirement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already disclosed material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation with all required details, when can it make a later disclosure about those estimates without repeating all the details, and what does it still have to say clearly next to the estimates?
expected_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it must include specific information in the disclosure, including a clear statement placed prominently and close to the estimates explaining that they are Non-Equivalent Estimates, not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, not yet classified by a Competent Person as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and may never become reportable as such, plus other required supporting items (for example, sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and verification work, timing and funding) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. But if the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of those Non-Equivalent Estimates that complied with those requirements, a later disclosure about the same estimates does not need to repeat the required information as long as it (1) points back to the earlier compliant disclosure, (2) confirms the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates under a Mining Reporting Standard, and (3) still includes an equally prominent and proximate statement about the estimates covering the same key matters as the original prominent statement requirement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].

question: When Restricted Securities are subject to a holding lock, how must a Listed Entity ensure the lock is not released without the Regulator’s prior written consent, and in what circumstances may the Regulator permit the party managing the holding lock to release it to facilitate actions under a Takeover or Merger?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must implement controls that align the holding-lock undertaking with the Regulator’s consent framework: it must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, and submit that undertaking to the Regulator within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. The undertaking must require the relevant entity to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds and not to release that holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent, so the Listed Entity’s obligation is both to secure the undertaking and to ensure the lock-release condition is embedded and observed [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. In parallel, the Regulator has discretion to consent to a party that is managing a holding lock releasing the holding lock in the context of a Takeover or Merger, where doing so enables holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer or to transfer or cancel Securities under a Takeover [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67].

debug_context.semantic_hook: may consent to a party that is managing

answer_spans.text: within two Business Days

question: If Restricted Securities are issued and then a Takeover happens, what must a Listed Entity do within two Business Days to set up the holding lock, and when can the Regulator allow the party managing the holding lock to release it?
expected_answer: The Listed Entity has a timing and submission obligation tied to the holding lock: within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or another entity the Regulator considers suitable, and it must submit that undertaking to the Regulator [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. That undertaking must cover two key points: the entity will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds, and it will not release the holding lock unless it first has the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. Separately, in a Takeover or Merger scenario, the Regulator may consent to the party that is managing the holding lock releasing it, but only to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer or to transfer or cancel Securities under a Takeover [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. This means the lock can be lifted only through the Regulator’s consent pathway, even when a corporate transaction creates a need to act.

debug_context.semantic_hook: may consent to a party that is managing

answer_spans.text: within two Business Days

question: For an Authorised Person that falls within the Appendix’s scope because it meets the relevant criteria, when must it have a Trading Book based on the nature of its positions, trading intent, and the applicable value thresholds over time?
expected_answer: Where this Appendix applies—i.e., to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria referenced in the Appendix and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]—the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book when the conditions in the obligation are satisfied [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. Specifically, it must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5. In addition, the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book pursuant to those criteria must meet one of the quantitative triggers: it normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. These scope and threshold elements operate together to determine when the Trading Book requirement applies.

debug_context.semantic_hook: applies to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria

answer_spans.text: must have a Trading Book

question: If an Authorised Person is within the Appendix’s scope because it meets the stated criteria, how do the Section A2.1 inclusion requirement, the trading-intent condition, and the $15 million/$20 million and 5%/6% thresholds (including the preceding 12 month period test) determine whether it must have a Trading Book?
expected_answer: The Appendix establishes applicability by stating it applies to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria referenced and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]. Within that applicable population, the obligation specifies the concrete circumstances in which an Authorised Person must have a Trading Book [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. The requirement is triggered only if three linked elements are present: (a) the Authorised Person has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2; (b) those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5; and (c) the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion pursuant to (a) and (b) meets a size test. The size test is satisfied if the value normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of combined on and off balance sheet positions, or if it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. Together, scope plus these conditions determine when the Trading Book must be maintained.

debug_context.semantic_hook: applies to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria

answer_spans.text: must have a Trading Book

question: If an Authorised Person is covered by this Appendix because it meets the stated criteria, when does it have to have a Trading Book based on what positions it holds, whether they are held for trading, and the dollar/percentage thresholds (including the last 12 months test)?
expected_answer: This Appendix applies to an Authorised Person that meets the referenced criteria and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]. For an Authorised Person in that scope, it must have a Trading Book when the specific conditions in the obligation are met [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. The Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent under Rule A2.1.5. It also has to meet a size threshold based on the total value of positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book under those two conditions. That threshold is met if the value normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or if it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. If these elements line up, the Trading Book is required.

question: This Appendix says it applies to an Authorised Person that meets certain criteria. For that Authorised Person, what exact tests must be true before it must have a Trading Book, including the $15 million/$20 million and 5%/6% triggers and the preceding 12 month period?
expected_answer: The scope statement says the Appendix applies to an Authorised Person that meets the referenced criteria and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]. The obligation then explains when an Authorised Person must have a Trading Book by setting out the tests that trigger the requirement [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. First, the Authorised Person must have positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2. Second, those positions must be held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5. Third, the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book (based on the first two tests) must be large enough: it normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. Meeting these tests means the Trading Book is required.

question: When handling Applications for recognition, how should the Authority align the procedural steps with the procedures that apply to the exercise of its Own-Initiative Powers, and what internal sequencing should be followed to ensure the decision is processed under the relevant FSMR or applicable Rulebook procedure rather than ad hoc handling?
expected_answer: For Applications for recognition, the Authority should treat the matter as a decision that must be processed under the relevant procedures specified in FSMR or the applicable Rulebook, rather than using an informal or bespoke workflow. In practice, this means the Authority should first classify the application as falling within the category of decisions that are “subject to the relevant procedures” and then route it through the applicable procedural track identified for the type of power being exercised. Where the application handling involves (or triggers) the exercise of the Authority’s Own-Initiative Powers, the Authority should follow the applicable procedures for exercising those powers, ensuring the application is managed consistently with that procedural framework and not separated from it. The procedural alignment is therefore twofold: (i) the recognition application is handled as an “application for recognition” matter, and (ii) any Own-Initiative Powers component is handled under the corresponding Own-Initiative Powers procedure, with both elements anchored to the relevant FSMR/Rulebook procedures as referenced in the decision-category guidance. [#TGT:f7674119-c840-498b-af18-02db0720ccb5] [#SRC:99839c16-01e8-4626-8f0f-118176d7c9a3]

answer_spans.text: Applications for recognition .

question: If the Authority is dealing with Applications for recognition, and it also needs to use its Own-Initiative Powers, what procedure should it follow and how should it decide which set of steps applies?
expected_answer: When the Authority deals with Applications for recognition, it should not invent a new process; it should handle the matter using the relevant procedures that are specified in FSMR or in the applicable Rulebook for decisions in that category. The practical way to choose the right steps is to identify what the Authority is doing in the case: if it is simply processing an application for recognition, it should follow the recognition-application procedure; if, in addition, the Authority is exercising its Own-Initiative Powers as part of the same matter, it should also apply the applicable procedures for exercising those Own-Initiative Powers. The key is that both aspects are treated as procedurally governed decisions: the recognition application is handled under the recognition application procedure, and any Own-Initiative Powers action is handled under the Own-Initiative Powers procedure, with both being “subject to the relevant procedures” referenced for this category of decisions. This ensures the Authority’s handling is consistent with the procedural framework indicated for such decisions, rather than being managed informally. [#TGT:f7674119-c840-498b-af18-02db0720ccb5] [#SRC:99839c16-01e8-4626-8f0f-118176d7c9a3]

answer_spans.text: Applications for recognition .

question: When the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than otherwise prescribed, what must the Authorised Person do to comply with its ongoing duties to prepare and submit returns through the Regulator’s electronic reporting system, and how long must it follow the direction?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with two linked requirements: the baseline obligation to prepare and submit returns under the Chapter’s rules and the Regulator’s EPRS requirements, and any overriding written direction from the Regulator that changes the form, manner, or frequency of those returns. Specifically, the Authorised Person must prepare its returns in line with the applicable Rules, relevant instructional guidelines, and the requirements of the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the submission frequency specified within EPRS, and it must submit those returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. In addition, where the Regulator has exercised its permission to issue a written notice directing the Authorised Person to submit returns in a form, manner, or frequency other than otherwise prescribed, the Authorised Person must continue submitting its returns in accordance with that direction [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. This continues until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise, at which point the Authorised Person must follow the updated instruction while still meeting the EPRS-based submission requirement.

debug_context.semantic_hook: direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2

question: If the Regulator sends a written notice telling an Authorised Person to file its returns in a different way or on a different schedule, what must the Authorised Person do when preparing and submitting returns using the Regulator’s electronic system, and when can it stop following that notice?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must meet its standard reporting duties and also follow any special written direction from the Regulator that changes how returns are submitted. Under its core obligation, the Authorised Person must prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) requirements, including the submission frequency set out in EPRS, and it must submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. Separately, the Regulator is permitted to issue a written notice directing the Authorised Person to submit returns in a form, manner, or frequency different from what would otherwise apply, and the Authorised Person must continue submitting its returns in line with that direction [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. The Authorised Person can stop following the earlier direction only when the Regulator issues another written notice directing otherwise; until then, the direction remains in effect alongside the requirement to submit via EPRS.

debug_context.semantic_hook: direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2

question: Under the definitions provided, how is the second instance of Market Abuse triggered when an Insider shares Inside Information with another person, and what is the limiting condition relating to the proper course of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties?
expected_answer: Across both definitions, the “second” instance is triggered where an Insider communicates Inside Information to another person in circumstances that fall outside the proper course of the exercise of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties. The SOURCE frames this conduct as one of the instances in which Market Abuse will constitute, making the disclosure itself the operative act and the “proper course” limitation the key boundary that distinguishes permitted communications from the defined abusive instance [#SRC:2099b5f8-78a0-43e7-8fc5-0295f590463e]. The TARGET mirrors this same definitional trigger by identifying the second instance specifically as the situation where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. Read together, the definition requires (i) an Insider, (ii) a disclosure of Inside Information, (iii) to another person, and (iv) that the disclosure is not made in the proper course of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties; the “otherwise than” condition is the decisive qualifier in both passages.

debug_context.semantic_hook: an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person

answer_spans.text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: When does the “second” case apply if an Insider tells someone else Inside Information, and what does it mean for that disclosure to be outside the proper course of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties?
expected_answer: Both passages define the “second” case as applying when an Insider passes Inside Information to another person in a way that is not part of the proper course of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties. In the SOURCE, this type of disclosure is expressly listed as an instance in which Market Abuse will constitute, so the definition treats the act of disclosure as the trigger and uses the “proper course” concept as the key limitation on when such sharing is captured [#SRC:2099b5f8-78a0-43e7-8fc5-0295f590463e]. The TARGET repeats the same definitional formulation by stating that the second case is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of the Insider’s employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. Taken together, the definition is not about any disclosure in general; it is specifically about disclosure by an Insider, of Inside Information, to another person, where the disclosure is “otherwise than” (i.e., outside) the proper course of the Insider’s work-related role, profession, or duties as described in both texts.

debug_context.semantic_hook: an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person

answer_spans.text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: When the Regulator holds Confidential Information that qualifies as CRD Information because it was received from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive, in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from disclosing it, and what consent and purpose limitations must be satisfied before any disclosure can occur?
expected_answer: CRD Information is a defined subset of Confidential Information: it is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and an EEA Competent Authority is a public authority or body officially recognised by national law in an EEA jurisdiction and empowered to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Because of that origin, the Regulator is prohibited from disclosing such Confidential Information under the relevant disclosure gateways unless specific conditions are met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. In particular, where the Confidential Information is CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority that disclosed it to the Regulator must first give prior written consent to the disclosure. Further, if that consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator may disclose the CRD Information only for that purpose and not for any other use or audience. These constraints operate as mandatory preconditions to any disclosure of CRD Information by the Regulator, notwithstanding other potential disclosure permissions.

question: How should the Regulator distinguish between Confidential Information that merely originates in another governmental or regulatory authority and Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and what is the resulting prohibition on disclosure absent the required prior written consent?
expected_answer: The Regulator must first classify the Confidential Information by reference to its origin and the specific definition of CRD Information. CRD Information is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and an EEA Competent Authority is an officially recognised EEA public authority or body empowered under national law to supervise institutions [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Separately, Confidential Information may originate in another governmental or regulatory authority (whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise) without necessarily being CRD Information. The prohibition is that the relevant disclosure permissions do not allow the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the applicable consent conditions are satisfied [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. For information originating in another authority, the disclosing authority must provide prior written consent. For CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority must provide prior written consent, and any purpose limitation attached to that consent binds the Regulator so that disclosure is solely for that purpose.

expected_answer: CRD Information is a specific kind of Confidential Information: it is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and the EEA Competent Authority is an officially recognised EEA public authority or body empowered by national law to supervise institutions [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Because the information is CRD Information, the Regulator is not allowed to disclose it through the relevant disclosure routes unless the required conditions are met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. The key condition is prior written consent from the EEA Competent Authority that provided the Confidential Information to the Regulator. Also, if that consent is given only for a particular purpose, the Regulator must limit any disclosure to that purpose only. In practice, this means the Regulator must check both (1) whether the Confidential Information meets the CRD Information definition and (2) whether the EEA Competent Authority has provided written consent, including any stated purpose limits, before disclosing anything.

expected_answer: Confidential Information can be restricted because of where it came from, and the rules treat two origin categories. One category is Confidential Information that originates in another governmental or regulatory authority (in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or elsewhere). Another category is CRD Information, which is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and an EEA Competent Authority is an officially recognised EEA public authority or body empowered to supervise institutions under national law [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. The Regulator is not allowed to disclose Confidential Information under the relevant disclosure permissions unless the matching consent condition is met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. For information from another authority, that authority must give prior written consent. For CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority must give prior written consent, and if it limits consent to a particular purpose, the Regulator can disclose only for that purpose.

question: When applying the recording and retention requirement for voice and electronic communications, how must an Authorised Person treat conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions, given that those communications are carved out from the relevant scope?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s duty to take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings of voice and electronic communications is expressly conditional, because it applies only to the extent not limited by the carve-out that excludes certain categories of conversations or communications from the underlying scope [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. In practice, the Authorised Person must implement recording and retention controls for communications with a Client or another Person in relation to a Transaction (including order receipt, execution, arranging execution, and related instructions) and for communications made with, sent from, or received on equipment provided to, or sanctioned/permitted for use by, an Employee or contractor [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. However, the effect of the relevant carve-out is that conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions are excluded from that scope [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]. Accordingly, the Authorised Person should distinguish in its procedures between in-scope transactional communications that must be recorded and retained and the excluded categories, so that the obligation is applied consistently with the stated exclusion [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] and the conditional nature of the recording requirement [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8].

debug_context.semantic_hook: exclude from onversations or communications

answer_spans.text: Subject to Rule 6.

question: For communications made on equipment provided by, or sanctioned by, an Authorised Person for an Employee or contractor, must the Authorised Person record and retain all such communications, or does the exclusion for communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions limit what is required?
expected_answer: The obligation on an Authorised Person to take reasonable steps to ensure it makes and retains recordings is not absolute for every communication on firm-provided or firm-sanctioned equipment; it is expressly framed as being subject to a limitation that can narrow the scope of what must be recorded and retained [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. Within the obligation, the communications that must be recorded and retained are those that are (i) with a Client or another Person in relation to a Transaction, including communications about receiving, executing, or arranging execution of Client orders and passing related instructions, and (ii) made with, sent from, or received on equipment provided by the Authorised Person to an Employee or contractor, or whose use by an Employee or contractor has been sanctioned or permitted by the Authorised Person [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. At the same time, the relevant scope provision states that the effect of the carve-out is to exclude from the underlying scope conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]. Therefore, even where the equipment condition is met, the Authorised Person must apply the recording/retention requirement in a way that respects that exclusion, rather than treating all such communications as automatically in-scope [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5].

debug_context.semantic_hook: exclude from onversations or communications

answer_spans.text: Subject to Rule 6.

question: If an Authorised Person must record and keep certain calls and electronic messages about Transactions, does it still have to do that for conversations made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, or people doing back office functions?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure it makes and retains recordings of voice and electronic communications, but that duty is expressly conditional and must be applied within the relevant scope limits [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. The communications covered by the duty are those with a Client or another Person in relation to a Transaction, including communications about receiving Client orders, executing them, arranging their execution, and passing related instructions, and they must also meet the equipment condition (made with, sent from, or received on equipment provided by the Authorised Person to an Employee or contractor, or equipment whose use has been sanctioned or permitted by the Authorised Person) [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. However, the scope text explains that the effect of the carve-out is to exclude from the underlying scope conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]. So, when deciding what to record and keep, the Authorised Person should not treat those excluded categories as automatically covered, even if they involve communications that might otherwise look like they relate to Transactions or occur on firm equipment [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5].

debug_context.semantic_hook: exclude from onversations or communications

answer_spans.text: Subject to Rule 6.

question: The rule says an Authorised Person must record communications on its approved devices when they relate to Transactions. How does that change if the communication is made by an Investment Analyst, a retail financial adviser, or someone doing back office work?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person’s recording and retention duty applies to specific kinds of communications and is explicitly subject to a limitation that can remove certain communications from the scope of what must be recorded [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. Under the duty, the Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure it records and keeps voice and electronic communications that are with a Client or another Person in relation to a Transaction (including order receipt, execution, arranging execution, and related instructions) and that are made with, sent from, or received on equipment the Authorised Person provided to an Employee or contractor, or whose use it has sanctioned or permitted [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8]. But the scope text states that the effect of the carve-out is to exclude from the underlying scope conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]. As a result, the Authorised Person should apply its recording controls to in-scope transactional communications while recognizing that these excluded categories are not intended to be captured by the same requirement [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5].

debug_context.semantic_hook: exclude from onversations or communications

answer_spans.text: Subject to Rule 6.

question: How must the Board operationalise its duty to safeguard Shareholders’ rights and prevent abuse of minority Shareholders by using annual report disclosures about the audit committee’s work and the safeguards for auditor objectivity and independence when non-audit services are provided?
expected_answer: The Board must put in place appropriate measures that both protect Shareholders’ rights and make those rights practically exercisable, while also promoting effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders and preventing any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. In doing so, the annual report should support this outcome by including a separate section describing the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, so that Shareholders can understand how key oversight functions are being carried out and can engage effectively on that basis [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. The annual report should also explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded if the auditor provides non-audit services, which helps ensure that Shareholders receive clear information relevant to accountability and informed dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. Taken together, these disclosures are part of the Board’s broader obligation to implement measures that safeguard rights, enable effective exercise of those rights, and reduce the risk of unfair treatment, including of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].

debug_context.semantic_hook: rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures

answer_spans.text: Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue.

question: When preparing the annual report, what must the Board ensure regarding (i) a separate section on the audit committee’s work and (ii) explanations of safeguards for auditor independence in non-audit services, to evidence that Shareholders’ rights are effectively enabled and dialogue is promoted?
expected_answer: The Board must ensure that Shareholders’ rights are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. In the annual report, this should be supported by transparency measures directed to Shareholders. Specifically, a separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, giving Shareholders visibility into how the audit committee has performed its role and providing a concrete basis for engagement and scrutiny [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. In addition, the annual report should explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded where the auditor provides non-audit services, addressing a key area where Shareholders may have concerns and enabling more informed dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. These disclosures are not standalone; they should be treated as part of the Board’s overall measures to enable effective exercise of Shareholder rights and to reduce the risk of abuse or oppression, including of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].

debug_context.semantic_hook: rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures

answer_spans.text: Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue.

question: What must the Board do to protect Shareholders’ rights and support good dialogue, and how should the annual report help by describing the audit committee’s work and explaining how auditor independence is protected when non-audit services are provided?
expected_answer: The Board must ensure that the rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. The annual report should help deliver these outcomes by giving Shareholders clear, relevant information that supports accountability and engagement. In particular, a separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, so Shareholders can understand what the audit committee has done and can engage with the Board on that basis [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. The annual report should also explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded if the auditor provides non-audit services, addressing a key risk area that can affect Shareholder confidence and informed dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. Together, these disclosures support the Board’s broader obligation to implement measures that make Shareholder rights effective in practice and reduce the risk of unfair treatment, including for minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].

debug_context.semantic_hook: rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures

answer_spans.text: Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue.

question: If Shareholders ask how their rights are being protected, what must the Board be able to show, and what should the annual report include about the audit committee and auditor independence to support that?
expected_answer: The Board must be able to show that it has appropriate measures in place to safeguard the rights of Shareholders, enable Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. The annual report should support this by providing information that helps Shareholders understand governance and oversight in practice. It should include a separate section describing the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, which gives Shareholders a clear view of what the audit committee has done and supports meaningful engagement [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. It should also explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded if the auditor provides non-audit services, so Shareholders can assess how independence concerns are addressed and raise questions through effective dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. By combining these disclosures with the Board’s wider measures, the Board strengthens the practical protection of Shareholder rights and helps reduce the risk of unfair treatment, including of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].

debug_context.semantic_hook: rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures

answer_spans.text: Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue.

question: For purposes of the insider dealing restriction, how should a compliance function determine whether an investment is a “Related Instrument” to a Financial Instrument, and what is the resulting scope of the prohibition on an Insider dealing or attempting to deal when the Inside Information relates to the underlying Financial Instrument?
expected_answer: An investment is treated as a “Related Instrument” where, in relation to a Financial Instrument, its price or value depends on the price or value of that Financial Instrument; this dependency test is the defining criterion for bringing the investment within the Related Instrument category [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f]. Once an investment meets that definition, the insider dealing restriction applies not only to the Financial Instrument to which the Inside Information relates, but also to the Related Instrument, meaning an Insider is prohibited from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the relevant Financial Instrument (and, where applicable, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity to which the Inside Information relates) or the Related Instrument [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]. Practically, if an Insider has Inside Information about an Issuer of Financial Instruments, the prohibition can extend to a Derivative linked to those Financial Instruments, or to another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, provided the price or value of that other instrument depends (in whole or in part) on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f].

debug_context.semantic_hook: prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal

answer_spans.text: Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments.

question: When does an investment count as a “Related Instrument” to a Financial Instrument, and if it does, what exactly is an Insider not allowed to do with that Related Instrument when they have Inside Information about the Financial Instrument?
expected_answer: A “Related Instrument” is an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of a Financial Instrument; that dependency is what makes it “related” for insider dealing purposes [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f]. If an investment meets that definition, the insider dealing rule applies to it as well as to the underlying Financial Instrument. As a result, an Insider is prohibited from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument to which the Inside Information relates (and, where relevant, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity to which the Inside Information relates) or the Related Instrument [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]. For example, where an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer of Financial Instruments, a Related Instrument could include a Derivative linked to those Financial Instruments, or another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, so long as the price or value of that other instrument depends in whole or in part on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f].

debug_context.semantic_hook: prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal

answer_spans.text: Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, what must be included in the initial disclosure, and under what conditions may a later disclosure omit repeating that same supporting information while still remaining compliant?
expected_answer: For an initial disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity must include the required content for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, including all material economic assumptions employed, any commercially sensitive treatment (a statement that the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them), all other material assumptions utilised, and the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3) [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. After the Mining Reporting Entity has made that compliant disclosure, a subsequent disclosure in relation to the same type of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is permitted to omit the information otherwise required by Rule 11.9.2, but only if it references the earlier compliant disclosure and confirms that all material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements are also required in the subsequent disclosure where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].

debug_context.semantic_hook: subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information

answer_spans.text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, what does it still have to include in that first disclosure, and what does it need to do in a later update so it can avoid repeating the same detailed information?
expected_answer: In the first disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, the Mining Reporting Entity must include the required elements for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1: all material economic assumptions employed, plus (if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive) a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, as well as all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3 [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Once that compliant disclosure has been made, a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the information in Rule 11.9.2, but only if it references the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Depending on whether the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must also include an equally prominent and proximate statement of the specified type [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].

debug_context.semantic_hook: subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information

answer_spans.text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.

question: When an Authorised Person has failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it treat proposed CET1 Capital-related actions that fall within the meaning of a distribution (including cash dividends, bonus Shares, or a redemption or purchase of its own Shares), and what calculation and notification steps must occur before any such action may be undertaken?
expected_answer: A distribution in connection with CET1 Capital is defined broadly to capture multiple forms of value transfer or capital reduction, including payment of cash dividends, distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments, a redemption or purchase by an institution of its own Shares or other capital instruments, repayment of amounts paid up in connection with capital, and other items eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule and, until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator, it must ensure it does not make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital (as defined) [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. This restriction also applies to creating an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and to paying variable remuneration where the obligation was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement, as well as to making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital includes

answer_spans.text:
Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3

question: If an Authorised Person that has not met the Combined Buffer Requirement intends to execute a redemption or purchase of its own Shares or other capital instruments, what must it do before proceeding, and why is that action treated as a restricted CET1 Capital distribution?
expected_answer: A redemption or purchase by an institution of its own Shares or other capital instruments is expressly included within the meaning of a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, alongside other forms such as cash dividends, bonus Shares, repayment of paid-up capital, and other eligible CET1 items [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. Accordingly, if an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must treat that proposed redemption or buyback as a restricted distribution and follow the required sequencing of actions. Specifically, it must calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the relevant rule and must ensure it does not undertake the redemption or purchase (as a CET1 Capital distribution) until it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under the applicable notification rule [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. The same “do not undertake” restriction, pending calculation and notification, also applies in that situation to creating certain obligations to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, paying variable remuneration in the specified circumstances, and making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital includes

answer_spans.text:
Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must it do before it can pay a cash dividend or issue bonus Shares, and why do those actions count as a CET1 Capital distribution?
expected_answer: Cash dividends and the distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares (or other capital instruments) are both included in what counts as a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. So, when an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule. Until it has calculated that amount and notified the Regulator under the required notification rule, it must ensure it does not undertake a CET1 Capital distribution, which would include paying a cash dividend or issuing bonus Shares [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. In the same period (before calculation and notification), it must also ensure it does not create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and it must not pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. It must also avoid making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments until the required steps are completed [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital includes

answer_spans.text:
Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3

question: If an Authorised Person is below the Combined Buffer Requirement, can it repay amounts paid up in connection with capital, and what steps must happen first given that this is treated as a CET1 Capital distribution?
expected_answer: Repaying amounts paid up in connection with capital is specifically treated as a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, along with other actions like paying cash dividends, issuing bonus Shares, redeeming or purchasing the institution’s own Shares or other capital instruments, and distributing other items eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. Because it is a CET1 Capital distribution, an Authorised Person that fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement must not undertake that repayment until it has completed two prerequisites: it must calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule, and it must notify the Regulator under the required notification rule [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. The restriction is framed as an obligation to ensure the Authorised Person does not take the listed actions until those steps are done, and it also covers creating certain obligations to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, paying variable remuneration in the specified circumstances, and making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital includes

answer_spans.text:
Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3

question: Where an Authorised Person both (i) operates as a Cell Company and (ii) holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, what annual supervision fees must it pay to the Regulator, including any additional amounts tied to the Cell Company structure and the number of Cells?
expected_answer: If the Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company, it must pay the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee that is calculated as a fixed amount for the Cell Company plus a per-Cell amount, namely $8,000 for the Cell Company and $1,000 for each Cell [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Separately, if the same Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, it must also pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $50,000 for either or both of those Regulated Activities [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96]. Read together, an Authorised Person meeting both conditions has two fee components: (1) the $50,000 annual supervision fee linked to the insurance-related Regulated Activities, and (2) the additional annual supervision fee linked to operating as a Cell Company, which increases with each Cell. The total annual amount payable therefore depends on the number of Cells in addition to the fixed fees.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do insurance business as Principal (Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal) and it also operates as a Cell Company, what fees must it pay each year to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells change the amount?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $50,000 for either or both Regulated Activities [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96]. If that same Authorised Person also operates as a Cell Company, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee to the Regulator that is made up of two parts: $8,000 for the Cell Company itself, plus $1,000 for each Cell [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Putting both requirements together, the yearly fees include the fixed $50,000 amount tied to the insurance-related permission, and then an extra amount tied to the Cell Company structure. The extra amount increases as the number of Cells increases, because the per-Cell charge is added on top of the $8,000 Cell Company charge. So the total annual payment is $50,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 multiplied by the number of Cells.

question: When an Authorised Person is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu, how must it apply the exemption from the calculation of T2 Capital within the capital resources framework, and what specific excess amount must be excluded from T2 Capital when calculating capital resources?
expected_answer: Part 4 (Calculating Capital Resources) applies to all firms, and within that framework there is a specific exemption from the calculation of T2 Capital for firms authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4]. Where an Authorised Person is Managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account, it must operationalise that exemption by excluding from T2 Capital the portion of reserves that exceeds a defined risk-based threshold [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. Concretely, the Authorised Person must compare (i) the total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve against (ii) the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the IFR rules, and then exclude from T2 Capital any amount by which the combined reserves are greater than that Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. This exclusion is applied in the context of calculating capital resources under Part 4, and is scoped to the PSIAu authorisation described in the exemption statement [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4].

debug_context.semantic_hook: an exemption from the calculation of T2 Capital

answer_spans.text: T2 Exclusion - Managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account.

question: If an Authorised Person manages a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu, what does it have to leave out of T2 Capital, and how does that fit with the rule that Part 4 capital resources calculations apply to all firms?
expected_answer: Part 4 (Calculating Capital Resources) applies to all firms, but it also contains a specific exemption affecting how T2 Capital is calculated for firms authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4]. For an Authorised Person that is Managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account, the required treatment is to exclude a defined “excess” from T2 Capital rather than including it in the T2 Capital figure used in the capital resources calculation [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. Specifically, the Authorised Person must add together the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve, then compare that total to the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the IFR rules [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. Any amount by which the combined reserves exceed that Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement must be excluded from T2 Capital [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. This is how the PSIAu-scoped exemption is applied within the otherwise generally applicable Part 4 capital resources framework [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4].

debug_context.semantic_hook: an exemption from the calculation of T2 Capital

answer_spans.text: T2 Exclusion - Managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account.

question: What must a Reporting Entity ensure about its availability and internal authority/knowledge for communications with the Listing Authority so that, if the Listing Authority cannot reach the Reporting Entity or the designated contacts cannot address a time-critical continuous disclosure issue promptly, the Listing Authority is not driven to use its power to halt trading by suspending the Listed Entity’s Securities until the issue is resolved?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must put practical arrangements in place so the Listing Authority can reach it quickly and engage with people who can act decisively on urgent disclosure matters. This includes ensuring it is readily contactable by phone and available to discuss pressing Disclosure issues during the normal trading hours of the RIE on which the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading, and for at least one hour either side of those hours each Business Day [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e]. It must also ensure that it, and its relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority, have both the organisational knowledge to have relevant and meaningful discussions on Rule matters and the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and make a Disclosure if required [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e]. These obligations directly mitigate the risk described where a continuous disclosure matter is extremely sensitive and time critical, and where the Listing Authority is not able to contact the Reporting Entity (via its designated contact points) or those contacts lack knowledge or authority to address the matter promptly; in those circumstances, the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities until the matter is properly resolved [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94].

question: What does a Reporting Entity need to have in place so it can be reached quickly and act fast on urgent disclosure issues, and how does that help avoid the Listing Authority suspending the Listed Entity’s Securities when it cannot contact the Reporting Entity or the contacts cannot deal with the issue?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity needs to be set up so the Listing Authority can contact it quickly and speak to people who can actually resolve urgent disclosure problems. Practically, it must be readily contactable by phone and available to discuss pressing Disclosure issues during the normal trading hours of the RIE where the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading, and for at least one hour either side of those hours each Business Day [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e]. It must also ensure that its relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority have the organisational knowledge to discuss Rule matters meaningfully and the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and make a Disclosure if required [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e]. These steps matter because continuous disclosure issues can be extremely sensitive and time critical; if the Listing Authority cannot contact the Reporting Entity through its designated contact points, or those contacts lack the knowledge or authority to address the matter promptly, the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities until the matter is properly resolved [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94].

question: How must an Authorised Person determine and then continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital, specifically where the buffer is the Countercyclical Capital Buffer derived from the Total Risk Exposure Amount and the weighted average of applicable jurisdictional buffer rates for private sector credit exposures?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person has two linked obligations: it must first compute the relevant buffer as a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, and it must then ensure that the required buffer amount is actually maintained as CET1 Capital on an ongoing basis. The calculation step requires the Authorised Person to determine a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. Once that required buffer amount has been calculated, the Authorised Person must maintain that required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, meaning the obligation is continuous rather than point-in-time compliance [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Read together, the framework requires both a prescribed method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and a standing requirement to hold the resulting amount in CET1 Capital without interruption.

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to work out its countercyclical buffer and then keep the required buffer amount in CET1 Capital at all times?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must both calculate and maintain the buffer in CET1 Capital. On the calculation side, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. That produces the required buffer amount for this buffer type. On the holding side, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, so it is not enough to compute the figure; the firm must continuously hold CET1 Capital in at least that amount once determined [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Together, these requirements mean the firm must follow the specified method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and then ensure its CET1 Capital remains sufficient to cover the resulting required buffer amount on an ongoing basis.

question: When Securities are being offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus, how does the prohibition on using a non-current Prospectus apply, and in what circumstances would the Securities qualify as Exempt Securities so that an exemption could disapply that prohibition?
expected_answer: The baseline position is that, unless an exemption applies, Securities to which a Prospectus relates cannot be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus if the Prospectus is not a current Prospectus; this frames a clear prohibition tied to the status of the Prospectus and the act of offering under an Approved Prospectus [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]. Whether that prohibition can be disapplied depends on whether the relevant Securities fall within a prescribed category of “Exempt Securities” as set by the Regulator, because those categories define the types of Securities that can benefit from an exemption. The prescribed Exempt Securities include, for example: limited additional issuances of Shares (less than 10% over 12 months) of a class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; substitution Shares with no increase in issued capital; Securities offered in connection with a Takeover Offer or merger where an equivalent-information document is available; certain rights issues and free/share-dividend offers where specified information documents are made available; employee/director offers meeting class and disclosure-document conditions; conversion/exchange resulting Shares of the same class; and certain cross-market admissions subject to trading history, compliance, and an English summary document approved by the Regulator [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0].
