(1)	Shares representing, over a period of 12 months, less than 10% of the number of Sha

question: For an Issuer planning an offer under an Approved Prospectus, what is the compliance consequence if the Prospectus is not current, and which defined categories of Exempt Securities (including any document-availability conditions) are relevant to determining whether an exemption can be relied upon?
expected_answer: If an Issuer proceeds to offer Securities for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus when the Prospectus is not a current Prospectus, the offer is prohibited unless an exemption applies; the prohibition is expressly conditioned on the absence of an applicable exemption and on the Prospectus being current at the time of the offer [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]. Determining whether an exemption can be relied upon requires mapping the Securities to the Regulator’s defined types of “Exempt Securities.” Those types include: certain small additional Share issuances (under a 10% threshold over 12 months) and substitution issues with no increase in issued capital, each tied to Shares already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; offers connected to a Takeover Offer or a merger where a document regarded by the Regulator as equivalent to a Prospectus is available; rights issues and free/share-dividend offers where a document is made available describing the number and nature of the Securities/Shares and the reasons for and details of the offer; offers to existing or former Director or Employee (or Close Relative) meeting similar class and document conditions; conversion/exchange resulting Shares of the same class; and certain admissions from another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange subject to trading history, ongoing-obligations compliance, and an English summary document approved by the Regulator [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0].

expected_answer: If Securities are offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus, the offer must not proceed where the Prospectus is not a current Prospectus, unless an exemption applies; the prohibition is tied to both the use of an Approved Prospectus and the Prospectus being current at the time of the offer [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]. To assess whether an exemption could apply, you must check whether the Securities fall within the Regulator’s prescribed definition of “Exempt Securities.” The Regulator lists multiple categories, including: small additional issuances of Shares (less than 10% over 12 months) of a class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; substitution Shares with no increase in issued capital; Securities offered in connection with a Takeover Offer or merger where an equivalent-information document is available; rights issues and free/share-dividend offers where a document is made available describing the number and nature of the Securities/Shares and the reasons for and details of the offer; certain offers to an existing or former Director or Employee (or Close Relative) meeting class and document conditions; Shares from conversion/exchange of other Securities; and certain admissions from another market if trading history, compliance, and an English summary document approved by the Regulator are in place [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0].

question: When can you avoid the rule that you must not offer Securities for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus that is not current, and what are some examples of Exempt Securities that matter for that decision?
expected_answer: You can avoid the prohibition only if an exemption applies; otherwise, Securities covered by a Prospectus must not be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus unless that Prospectus is a current Prospectus [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]. Whether an exemption is available depends on whether the Securities match the Regulator’s defined list of “Exempt Securities.” Examples include Shares that, over 12 months, represent less than 10% of the number of Shares of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, and Shares issued in substitution for already-admitted Shares where there is no increase in issued capital. The list also covers Securities offered in connection with a Takeover Offer or a merger if a document is available that the Regulator regards as equivalent to a Prospectus. Other categories depend on making an information document available (for example, for certain rights issues, free/share-dividend offers, and certain offers to an existing or former Director or Employee or their Close Relative), and there are also categories for conversion/exchange Shares and certain admissions from another market subject to trading history, compliance, and an English summary document approved by the Regulator [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0].

question: To prevent commercial interests from undermining the performance of its Regulatory Functions, what must a Recognised Body put in place in terms of systems, controls, and documented governance, and what standard of effort must it apply to ensure those commercial interests do not adversely affect those functions?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body must address the risk that its commercial interests (including profitability) could compromise the performance of its Regulatory Functions by combining (i) an organisational framework and (ii) an outcome-focused standard of conduct. On the framework side, it must have adequate systems and controls, including policies and procedures, designed so that pursuing commercial interests does not adversely impact the performance of its Regulatory Functions [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8]. On the conduct side, it must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5]. Read together, this means the Recognised Body should not rely solely on intentions or ad hoc measures; it must implement and maintain documented policies and procedures within adequate systems and controls, and then actively apply those arrangements through reasonable, ongoing steps aimed at preventing adverse effects from commercial drivers on regulatory performance. The obligation is framed around ensuring non-adverse impact/affect, so both the design of controls and the practical steps taken must be directed to that protective outcome.

answer_spans.text: A Recognised Body must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests

question: If a Recognised Body has commercial interests like profitability, what must it do to make sure those interests do not harm how it carries out its Regulatory Functions?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body must do two connected things to protect the performance of its Regulatory Functions from being harmed by its commercial interests. First, it must have adequate systems and controls in place, and these must include policies and procedures, specifically set up so that pursuing commercial interests (including profitability) does not adversely impact the performance of its Regulatory Functions [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8]. Second, it must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5]. Together, these requirements mean the Recognised Body needs both a structured, documented control environment (systems, controls, policies, and procedures) and active, reasonable action to make sure those arrangements work in practice. The focus is not on promoting commercial goals, but on preventing any adverse impact or adverse effect on regulatory performance, so the Recognised Body’s controls and steps should be aimed at keeping regulatory decision-making and execution insulated from commercial pressures.

answer_spans.text: A Recognised Body must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests

question: In a Takeover or Merger involving Restricted Securities, what must a Listed Entity have in place regarding the holding lock undertaking and the Regulator’s prior written consent, and what additional written agreements and acceptance thresholds must be satisfied before the Regulator will consent to a sale where the transaction is structured as (i) an offer or (ii) a scheme?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must first ensure the holding lock framework is properly established and controlled: within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from an appropriate intermediary (such as a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator deems suitable) and submit that undertaking to the Regulator; the undertaking must commit to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities and not release it without the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. In the context of a Takeover or Merger, the Regulator will not provide its consent to a sale unless specified conditions are met to the extent applicable [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. If the transaction is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all Ordinary Securities (or all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities), holders of at least half of the non-Restricted Securities subject to the offer must have accepted, and if the offer is conditional the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing to immediately re-impose the holding lock on any Securities not bought. If conducted by scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not take effect.

debug_context.semantic_hook: Regulator will not provide its consent unless

answer_spans.text: Timing and Enforcement.

question: If Restricted Securities are involved in a Takeover or Merger, what does the Listed Entity have to do within two Business Days after issue about the holding lock, and what conditions must be met before the Regulator will consent to selling those Restricted Securities under an offer or a scheme?
expected_answer: The Listed Entity has an early timing obligation tied to enforcement of the holding lock: within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from a suitable third party (for example a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submit it to the Regulator; that undertaking must require the third party to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities and not release it without the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. When a Takeover or Merger later involves a proposed sale of Restricted Securities, the Regulator will not give consent unless the applicable transaction conditions are satisfied [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. For an offer, the offer must be for all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities covered by the offer must have been accepted, and if the offer is conditional the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought. For a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.

debug_context.semantic_hook: Regulator will not provide its consent unless

answer_spans.text: Timing and Enforcement.

question: For an Authorised Person, what is the obligation to maintain a minimum level of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital relative to its Base Capital Requirement, and when must this minimum be met and maintained, taking into account both the cross-category requirement and the definition reference?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person, whichever Category it is a member of, is required to hold and maintain a minimum amount of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) that corresponds to, and is not less than, its relevant Base Capital Requirement. This minimum must be satisfied at the time the Authorised Person obtains authorisation and must continue to be met at all times thereafter, making the requirement continuous rather than a one-off threshold. The obligation is framed as a baseline capital floor tied directly to the Base Capital Requirement, and it applies regardless of the Authorised Person’s Category membership [#SRC:ef0be50a-35f4-4cfc-92c5-c7fd6d52a32b]. In addition, the CET1 Capital that must be held is the Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) as defined in Section 3.10, ensuring the capital measure used for compliance is the defined CET1 Capital concept rather than another capital metric [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must hold a minimum amount of CET1 Capital

answer_spans.text: Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital)
Section 3.10

question: What does an Authorised Person have to hold as a minimum, how does it relate to the Base Capital Requirement, and when does this requirement apply (including the fact it applies across Categories and uses a defined term)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must hold Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) at a minimum level that matches its Base Capital Requirement: the CET1 Capital must correspond to the Base Capital Requirement and be not less than the Authorised Person’s relevant Base Capital Requirement. This is not limited to a particular type of firm; it applies to an Authorised Person whichever Category it is a member of, so Category membership does not remove or reduce the obligation [#SRC:ef0be50a-35f4-4cfc-92c5-c7fd6d52a32b]. The timing is also explicit and ongoing: the minimum must be met at the time the Authorised Person obtains authorisation and must be maintained at all times thereafter, meaning the firm must continuously remain above the required floor rather than only meeting it at authorisation. The capital measure used for this test is the defined concept of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital), as defined in Section 3.10, so compliance is assessed using that definition [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a].

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in connection with its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or material Mining Project(s), what specific content must that disclosure include regarding the assumptions used and the underlying Production Target?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. When it makes that type of disclosure, the disclosure must include detailed information about the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions employed, plus all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must include a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required to be provided for that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity can disclose forecast financial information from a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for material Mining Project(s), what does it have to include about the key assumptions and the Production Target itself, especially if some assumptions are commercially sensitive?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, but only in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If it chooses to make that disclosure, it must include specific information about how the forecast was determined: it must set out all material economic assumptions used, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Where the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it still has to address them by stating that they are commercially sensitive and explaining the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. The disclosure must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, together with the full set of information required to accompany that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].

question: For the documents that the Applicant must submit in final form to the Regulator before 9:00am on the day the application is considered, who must sign the documents required for that day, and how does the signing requirement apply where a Sponsor has been appointed?
expected_answer: The Applicant has two linked obligations for the documents due on the day the Regulator is to consider the application. First, the Applicant must submit specified documents, in final form, to the Regulator before 9:00am on that day, including a completed Shareholder statement and, where the transaction is a placing, open Offer or Offer for subscription, a completed pricing statement [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c]. Second, the Applicant must ensure that the documents required for that day are properly executed: they must be signed either by its Sponsor (if a Sponsor has been appointed) or by a duly authorised officer of the Applicant [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017]. Read together, this means the Applicant is responsible both for timely delivery of the final-form submissions to the Regulator by the stated deadline and for ensuring the required documents carry the correct signature authority, with the Sponsor signing where appointed and otherwise an authorised Applicant officer signing.

question: For Counterparty Risk Exposures arising from an SFT that are included in the Trading Book, how should an Authorised Person determine what qualifies as eligible financial Collateral, and under what conditions is the Authorised Person permitted to treat those Exposures as collateralised (including where the collateral takes the form of cash received under a CLN it issued or on-balance-sheet netted loans and Deposits)?
expected_answer: Where Counterparty Risk Exposures arise from an SFT and are included in the Trading Book, the definition of eligible financial Collateral is tied to Trading Book eligibility: eligible financial Collateral includes all instruments that an Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01]. However, even if an instrument meets that eligible-collateral definition, the Authorised Person is permitted to treat Exposures as collateralised only if the relevant CRM conditions are met [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]. In applying this, the Authorised Person should (i) identify the Exposure as a Counterparty Risk Exposure from an SFT included in the Trading Book, (ii) confirm the collateral instrument is one the Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book (thereby meeting the eligible financial Collateral definition), and (iii) ensure the applicable CRM conditions are satisfied before recognising collateralisation. The permission also clarifies that certain items can be included within the collateralisation framework, including cash received under a CLN issued by the Authorised Person and loans and Deposits of a Counterparty to or with the Authorised Person that are subject to an on balance sheet Netting agreement recognised under the CRM framework [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5].

question: If an Authorised Person has Counterparty Risk Exposures from an SFT in its Trading Book, what counts as eligible financial Collateral, and when can the Authorised Person actually treat the Exposure as collateralised (including cash under its own CLN and netted loans or Deposits)?
expected_answer: For Counterparty Risk Exposures that come from an SFT and are included in the Trading Book, eligible financial Collateral is defined broadly by reference to what the Authorised Person may hold in that book: it includes all instruments the Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01]. But meeting that definition is not enough on its own to recognise collateralisation. The Authorised Person can only treat Exposures as collateralised if the relevant CRM conditions are met [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]. Practically, the Authorised Person should first confirm the Exposure is a Counterparty Risk Exposure from an SFT in the Trading Book, then confirm the collateral instrument is Trading-Book-eligible (so it is eligible financial Collateral), and finally check that the CRM conditions required for collateral recognition are satisfied before treating the Exposure as collateralised. The permission also indicates that the collateralisation analysis can encompass specific items, including cash received under a CLN issued by the Authorised Person and loans and Deposits of a Counterparty to or with the Authorised Person where there is an on balance sheet Netting agreement recognised under the CRM framework [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5].

question: When an initial annual fee becomes due part-way through a calendar year, how must the amount payable be calculated based on the months remaining to year-end, and by when must it be paid in full to the Regulator?
expected_answer: Where an initial annual fee becomes due during a calendar year, the payable amount must be prorated for the remainder of that calendar year, and the proration is determined by reference to the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year (i.e., the portion due is based on the remaining months) [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f]. After calculating that prorated portion, the initial annual fee (as so prorated) must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date on which the fee becomes due [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. This means the compliance steps are: (1) identify the date the initial annual fee becomes due; (2) determine how many months remain until the end of the calendar year and use that to calculate the portion due for the annual designation fee; and (3) ensure the resulting prorated amount is remitted in full to the Regulator no later than the twentieth day after the due date. The month-based calculation governs the amount, while the twenty-day requirement governs the payment deadline.

question: How should an entity distinguish between the month-based proration method for an annual designation fee when an initial annual fee falls due mid-year and the fixed advance-payment deadline for subsequent annual fees starting 1 January, and what are the respective payment timing requirements to the Regulator?
expected_answer: The month-based proration method applies to determining the portion due of the annual designation fee when the fee is not covering a full calendar year; in that case, the portion due is calculated based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f]. For the initial annual fee, once that prorated amount for the remainder of the calendar year is determined, it must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date on which it becomes due [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. By contrast, subsequent annual fees relate to the period commencing 1 January and are payable in advance; they must be paid in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. Practically, the distinction is that the month-remaining approach governs the amount for a partial-year initial fee, while subsequent fees follow a fixed annual cycle with an advance payment due by the end of January.

question: When a Non-ADGM Institution is subject to a Foreign Resolution Action, in what circumstances may the Regulator take Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch only if specified preconditions are met, and how can the Regulator’s discretion to refuse recognition of that Foreign Resolution Action affect whether those preconditions can be satisfied?

question: If an ADGM Branch is failing (or likely to fail) and the Non-ADGM Institution is under a Foreign Resolution Action, when is the Regulator allowed to take Resolution Action for the ADGM Branch, and when could the Regulator refuse to recognise that Foreign Resolution Action in a way that matters to this decision?

Separately, even where there is a Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may refuse to recognise it (in whole or in part) if it is satisfied that one or more listed concerns apply—such as harm to financial stability in the ADGM, Resolution Conditions not being met, ADGM Branch action not being necessary to achieve Resolution Objectives, worse treatment of ADGM creditors compared with creditors in the non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba].

question: When an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member (for its own purposes or as an intermediary between a client and a Non-QCCP), how must it determine the exposure measure used to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the Non-QCCP, and what is the required approach for calculating exposure at default for the relevant derivative or long settlement transactions unless an internal model permission applies?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member, whether for its own purposes or as an intermediary between a client and a Non-QCCP, it must calculate Credit RWA in respect of its Trade Exposure to the Non-QCCP and apply an appropriate CRW for the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]. To do so, the exposure measure feeding that Credit RWA calculation must be determined consistently with the required exposure-at-default framework for the underlying instruments: the exposure at default (EAD) of Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions must be calculated in accordance with the specified Section under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. The only stated exception is where the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model, in which case the EAD calculation would not follow that Section. Accordingly, in the clearing-member-to-Non-QCCP context, the Authorised Person must (i) compute EAD for the relevant derivatives/long settlement transactions under the Section unless internal-model permission exists, and (ii) use that exposure basis to calculate Credit RWA for the Trade Exposure and apply the corporate-asset-class CRW for the Non-QCCP.

question: If an Authorised Person is a clearing member dealing with a Non-QCCP (either for itself or between a client and the Non-QCCP), what must it do to calculate Credit RWA for that trade exposure, and how must it calculate EAD for any derivative or long settlement transactions unless it has Regulator permission to use an internal model?
expected_answer: In this situation, the Authorised Person has two linked calculation duties. First, when it acts as a clearing member (for its own purposes or as an intermediary between a client and a Non-QCCP), it must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the Non-QCCP and apply an appropriate CRW for the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]. Second, for the derivative and settlement components that drive the exposure amount used in that Credit RWA process, the exposure at default (EAD) of Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions must be calculated in accordance with the relevant Section under SA-CCR [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. The only stated carve-out is if the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model; in that case, it would not be required to calculate EAD under that Section. Practically, the Authorised Person should ensure the EAD method it uses (standardised Section vs permitted internal model) is aligned with, and supports, the required Credit RWA and CRW application for the Non-QCCP trade exposure.

question: When an Authorised Person proposes to conduct a Regulated Activity in relation to a commodity that is sold for cash and promptly delivered on settlement, what assessment sequence must the Regulator apply to decide whether it can be treated as an Accepted Spot Commodity, and how do the Authorised Person’s responsible and sustainable sourcing standards factor into that decision?
expected_answer: The starting point is to confirm the product is a Spot Commodity by reference to its core transactional characteristics, including that it is a good sold for cash and promptly delivered when the transaction is settled, and that it is not instead a forward-style delivery arrangement beyond the generally accepted standard delivery period, a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets, or a non-good/intangible item. Once the commodity is within that Spot Commodity perimeter, the Regulator then determines, in its opinion, whether it meets the requirements to be an Accepted Spot Commodity by applying the considerations set out for that purpose. In doing so, the Regulator will consider the Authorised Person’s requirements for, and standards used, in relation to responsible and sustainable sourcing, including adherence to internationally recognised certification standards where applicable, alongside broader market fundamentals (such as market practice, liquidity, participant base, transparency, and fair and orderly operation) and any other factors the Regulator considers relevant to whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person’s Regulated Activity. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: If a commodity deal is paid in cash and the goods are delivered promptly when it settles, what does the Regulator look at next to decide if it is an Accepted Spot Commodity, and what does the Authorised Person need to show about responsible and sustainable sourcing?
expected_answer: First, the commodity must fit the meaning of a Spot Commodity, including that it is a good sold for cash and promptly delivered when the transaction is settled, and that it is not a different type of arrangement such as delivery at a future date beyond the market’s standard delivery period for that commodity, a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets, or something that is not a good (for example, an intangible item). After that threshold is met, the Regulator decides whether, in its opinion, the Spot Commodity meets the requirements to be an Accepted Spot Commodity by applying its stated considerations. A key part of that review is the Authorised Person’s requirements for, and standards used, in relation to responsible and sustainable sourcing, including whether the Authorised Person adheres to internationally recognised certification standards where that is applicable to the relevant Spot Commodity. The Regulator also considers market fundamentals (including market practice and characteristics, liquidity and depth of demand and supply, number of active participants, transparency, and fair and orderly operation) and any other factors it considers relevant to whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to it. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: When exercising its powers, may the Regulator publish a decision notice or final notice (and related matter details) at its discretion, and how does that discretion apply where a person refers the decision to the Appeals Panel?
expected_answer: Yes. The Regulator has a discretionary permission to publish a decision notice, a final notice, or any other notice connected with the exercise of its powers, together with details about the matter to which the notice relates, provided the notice is not a warning notice. This discretionary publication power is framed generally as something the Regulator may do, and it extends both to the notice itself and to associated contextual details about the underlying matter. In addition, where a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, the approach described is that appropriate information about that decision will be published, including the notice itself, reflecting how the discretion is intended to be used in that referral scenario. Read together, the TARGET establishes the Regulator’s ability to publish at its discretion, while the SOURCE explains that, in the specific circumstance of an Appeals Panel referral, publication will occur and will include the notice and suitable information about the decision. [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314] [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]

question: When is the Regulator permitted to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, and how do the triggers differ between a particularly complex or novel waiver or modification request and situations involving additional cost or effort for an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision?
expected_answer: Across both provisions, the Regulator is permitted to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, but the circumstances that can justify the requirement are framed differently and should be assessed against the relevant trigger. Under the SOURCE, the supplementary fee power is tied specifically to a request for a waiver or modification, and it may be imposed where, in the opinion of the Regulator, that request is particularly complex or novel [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404]. Under the TARGET, the same type of fee may be required in a broader set of regulatory interactions where the Regulator expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort, including when dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Read together, a supplementary fee may be justified either by the nature of a waiver/modification request (complexity/novelty) or by the Regulator’s expected incremental cost/effort in handling specified processes or supervision, with the Regulator as the decision-maker in each case.

Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing

question: If the Regulator anticipates substantial additional effort in handling a Person’s filing or on-going supervision, and the Person has also submitted a waiver or modification request that the Regulator considers novel, may the Regulator require a supplementary fee on either basis?
expected_answer: Yes. Both texts permit the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, and each provides an independent basis for doing so. The SOURCE authorises the Regulator to require a supplementary fee where the relevant matter is a request for a waiver or modification and, in the opinion of the Regulator, that request is particularly complex or novel [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404]. Separately, the TARGET authorises the Regulator to require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. In the scenario described, the Regulator could rely on the TARGET rationale for the filing or on-going supervision if it expects substantial additional cost or effort, and it could also rely on the SOURCE rationale if the waiver/modification request is, in its opinion, particularly complex or novel. Both are framed as permissions for the Regulator to require payment from the Person.

question: When can the Regulator ask a Person to pay an extra (supplementary) fee—does it apply only to a complex or new waiver/modification request, or can it also apply when the Regulator expects extra work or cost for an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision?
expected_answer: The two passages both allow the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, but they describe different situations where that may happen. In the SOURCE, the trigger is narrow and linked to a request for a waiver or modification: the Regulator may require the supplementary fee where, in the opinion of the Regulator, the request is particularly complex or novel [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404]. In the TARGET, the trigger is broader and focuses on the Regulator’s expected resource impact: the Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. So, it is not limited to waiver/modification requests; it can also apply to other regulatory processes and supervision when the Regulator expects substantial extra cost or effort, while waiver/modification requests have their own specific complexity/novelty basis.

question: When a Framework Contract permits the Payment Service Provider to implement proposed changes unilaterally unless the Payment Service User objects before the effective date, what must the Payment Service Provider communicate about the Payment Service User’s ability to end the Framework Contract without charge, and by when must the proposed changes be provided to the Payment Service User before they take effect?
expected_answer: Where the Framework Contract allows proposed changes to be made unilaterally by the Payment Service Provider if the Payment Service User does not notify the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User of two key points: first, that the Payment Service User will be deemed to have accepted the communicated changes if it does not object; and second, that the Payment Service User has the right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date the changes enter into force [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. In addition to these disclosures tied to unilateral-change mechanics, the Payment Service Provider must also meet the advance-notice timing requirement for delivering the proposed changes themselves: subject to the stated qualification, any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract or to the specified information must be provided to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date on which the changes are to take effect [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. Together, these obligations ensure both timely delivery of the proposed changes and clear notice of the Payment Service User’s no-charge termination option before the effective date.

debug_context.semantic_hook: the Payment Service User has the right to terminate

answer_spans.text: Subject to Rule 19.

question: If the Framework Contract lets the Payment Service Provider make changes unless the Payment Service User objects before the start date, what must the Payment Service Provider tell the Payment Service User about ending the Framework Contract without paying a charge, and how early must the Payment Service Provider send the proposed changes before they take effect?
expected_answer: If the Framework Contract allows the Payment Service Provider to make proposed changes unilaterally when the Payment Service User does not notify the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed effective date, the Payment Service Provider must clearly tell the Payment Service User what that means and what options the Payment Service User has. Specifically, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User that it will be treated as having accepted the changes if it does not object, and that the Payment Service User has the right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date the changes take effect [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. Separately, the Payment Service Provider must also provide the proposed changes themselves within the required lead time: subject to the stated qualification, any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract or to the specified information must be provided to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date they are to take effect [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. These two requirements work together so the Payment Service User receives early notice and can decide whether to accept, object, or end the contract before the changes start.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to submit returns to the Regulator using EPRS, how must it proceed if the Regulator issues a written notice directing submission in a different form, manner, or frequency than otherwise prescribed, and for how long must that direction be followed?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s baseline obligation is to prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in the relevant Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the frequency of submission specified through those EPRS requirements, and then to submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. However, this EPRS-based submission obligation operates subject to the Regulator’s power to vary how returns are submitted: the Regulator may, by written notice, direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner, or frequency other than the otherwise prescribed approach [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. Where such a written direction is issued, the Authorised Person must continue submitting its returns in accordance with that direction, and it must keep doing so until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b].

question: How should an Authorised Person reconcile its obligation to prepare returns under PRU instructional guidelines and EPRS requirements and to submit via EPRS with a written notice from the Regulator that changes the prescribed submission frequency or method?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must first recognise that its ordinary compliance framework for returns includes preparing returns in line with the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the submission frequency detailed in those EPRS requirements, and then submitting the returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. At the same time, the Regulator has an express ability to override the otherwise prescribed approach by issuing a written notice directing the Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. In practice, the Authorised Person must follow the written direction for submission (including any changed frequency or method) even if it differs from what would otherwise be applied under the standard EPRS-related requirements, and it must continue to submit in accordance with that direction until the Regulator provides a subsequent written notice changing or ending it [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b].

If the Regulator issues a written notice directing the Authorised Person to submit its returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than would otherwise apply, the Authorised Person must follow that direction for its submissions [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. The Authorised Person cannot treat the direction as temporary unless the Regulator changes it: it must continue submitting returns in accordance with the written direction until the Regulator, again by written notice, directs otherwise [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b].

question: Under the prohibitions on handling Confidential Information, who is prohibited from disclosing it (including the Regulator side and the primary recipient chain), and what specific prior consents must be obtained before any disclosure is permitted?
expected_answer: Across both regimes, disclosure of Confidential Information is prohibited unless the required prior consents are obtained, and the prohibition applies both to the original holder and to downstream recipients. On the SOURCE side, the prohibition covers the Regulator, its employees, agents, and any person coming into possession of Confidential Information; none of these persons may disclose unless they have prior consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a]. On the TARGET side, the prohibition covers a primary recipient and any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient; disclosure is barred unless there is prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]. Read together, both texts require two consents where the relevant persons differ, and both extend the restriction beyond the initial recipient to others who later possess the information.

The SOURCE expressly extends the prohibition beyond the Regulator and its employees and agents to “any person coming into possession of Confidential Information,” meaning the restriction follows the information into the hands of later possessors; disclosure is only allowed with prior consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a]. The TARGET similarly extends the prohibition beyond the primary recipient to “any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient,” capturing indirect recipients and other downstream parties; disclosure is only allowed with prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]. In combination, the rules require tracing both the source of the information and the separate person protected by confidentiality/relationship, and securing consent from each before any onward disclosure.

In the TARGET, the ban applies to a primary recipient and also to any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient; disclosure is not allowed unless there is consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]. question: When determining the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary that is included in consolidated T1 Capital of the Authorised Person's Financial Group, how must the Authorised Person incorporate the Subsidiary’s and/or Financial Group’s T1 Capital requirement that is expressed as a percentage of Total Risk Exposure Amount, and how must that Total Risk Exposure Amount be calculated for this purpose?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in consolidated T1 Capital by applying a subtraction mechanism: it starts from the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital and subtracts an amount derived by multiplying (i) a specified “lesser of” amount by (ii) a percentage based on the Subsidiary’s capital structure. The “lesser of” amount is tied to the T1 Capital required to meet an 8.0% requirement plus the Combined Buffer Requirement, assessed either on the Subsidiary’s solo basis or on a consolidated basis for the Financial Group as it relates to the Subsidiary [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. To apply that 8.0% requirement, the Total Risk Exposure Amount used in the calculation must be computed by the Authorised Person as the sum of Credit RWA, and the risk exposure amounts associated with Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk, after taking into account the relevant provisions referenced for that computation [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. The percentage multiplier is the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital expressed as a percentage of all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount, after taking into account the provisions of Rule 3

question: In applying the required subtraction to determine qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in consolidated T1 Capital, what components must the Authorised Person include in the Total Risk Exposure Amount that underpins the 8.0% T1 Capital requirement used in the “lesser of” test?
expected_answer: The subtraction required to determine the qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in consolidated T1 Capital depends on identifying a “lesser of” amount that reflects the T1 Capital required to meet an 8.0% requirement of Total Risk Exposure Amount plus the Combined Buffer Requirement, measured either at the Subsidiary level (solo basis) or at the Financial Group level (consolidated basis as it relates to the Subsidiary) [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount that feeds into that 8.0% requirement must be calculated by the Authorised Person as an aggregate measure: it is the sum of (a) Credit RWA, (b) the risk exposure amount associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement, (c) the risk exposure amount associated with the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, (d) the risk exposure amount associated with the CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and (e) where applicable, the risk exposure amount associated with Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, with the calculation performed after taking into account the specified provisions applicable to that computation [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. Once that “lesser of” amount is established, it is multiplied by a percentage equal to the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital as a proportion of all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts, and the product is subtracted from the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14].

expected_answer: To work out how much of a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital is included in consolidated T1 Capital, the Authorised Person must apply a required subtraction. It begins with the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital and subtracts a calculated amount that equals (1) a “lesser of” figure linked to the T1 Capital needed to meet an 8.0% requirement of Total Risk Exposure Amount plus the Combined Buffer Requirement (tested either on the Subsidiary’s solo basis or on a consolidated basis for the Financial Group as it relates to the Subsidiary), multiplied by (2) a percentage reflecting the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital as a share of all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. For the 8.0% test, the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated by the Authorised Person as the sum of Credit RWA and the risk exposure amounts for Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk, with the calculation done after taking into account the specified provisions that apply to that computation [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].

question: When an Authorised Person uses Total Risk Exposure Amount to apply the 8.0% test in the “lesser of” step for a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital inclusion, what must be included in Total Risk Exposure Amount, and how does that connect to the subtraction the Authorised Person must perform?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount by adding together specific components: Credit RWA, plus the risk exposure amounts associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, the CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and—if it applies—the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, with the calculation performed after taking into account the specified provisions relevant to that computation [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. That Total Risk Exposure Amount is then used in the 8.0% T1 Capital requirement that forms part of the “lesser of” amount in the Subsidiary qualifying T1 Capital inclusion method. Specifically, the “lesser of” compares the T1 Capital required to meet (i) the Subsidiary’s solo 8.0% requirement plus its Combined Buffer Requirement and (ii) the consolidated T1 Capital relating to the Subsidiary required to meet the Financial Group’s 8.0% requirement plus its Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. The Authorised Person must multiply that “lesser of” amount by a percentage based on the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital relative to all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts, and subtract the result from the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital to determine what is included in consolidated T1 Capital [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14].

question: When an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date and must pay the late fee to the Regulator, what additional steps may the Regulator take beyond charging that fee?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date, it must pay the Regulator a late payment fee of $500 for that late submission [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]. Separately, the fees framework for late submission of Regulatory Filings also makes clear that the late fee is not the only potential consequence: in addition to imposing the fee, the Regulator is permitted to take further action [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187]. Read together, this means the obligation to pay the specified $500 fee is triggered by submitting after the due date, but payment of that fee does not, by itself, preclude the Regulator from pursuing other measures it is entitled to take in response to the late submission. Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the late fee as a minimum financial consequence for missing the filing deadline, while recognising that the Regulator retains discretion to escalate its response beyond the fee where it considers further action appropriate.

question: If an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body files a Regulatory Filing late and must pay the $500 fee to the Regulator, can the Regulator still do anything else?
expected_answer: Yes. Where an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date, it must pay the Regulator a $500 late payment fee [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]. But the late-fee framework also states that charging a fee is not the Regulator’s only option: in addition to imposing the fee for late submission of Regulatory Filings, the Regulator may take further action [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187]. Putting these together, paying the $500 fee is a required consequence of filing late, but it does not “close the matter” automatically. The Regulator keeps the ability to respond in other ways as well, beyond just collecting the late fee. So, if a filing is late, the entity should be prepared both to pay the required fee and to address any additional steps the Regulator decides to take in response to the late submission.

question: Within the records that must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what documentation must be maintained to evidence that the Authorised Person is not using a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person without the Client’s prior written permission?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure its Resolution Pack includes records that demonstrate compliance with the prohibition on using a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for the Authorised Person’s own purpose or that of another Person unless the Client has given prior written permission [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. The Resolution Pack requirement expressly includes “adequate records and Client’s written permission” relating to the use of Client Investments, which functions as the documentary evidence set needed to show that any use is properly authorised and that unauthorised use is prevented [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Practically, this means the Resolution Pack should contain (i) adequate records describing any intended or actual use of relevant Client assets/investments and (ii) the Client’s written permission where such use is contemplated or has occurred, so that reviewers can verify that the prohibition is respected unless the permission condition is satisfied. In the absence of the Client’s prior written permission, the records should support that no such use took place.

question: How should an Authorised Person align the Resolution Pack record-inclusion requirement for adequate records and Client written permission with the prohibition on using a Client’s Safe Custody Assets without prior written permission, to ensure the Resolution Pack evidences compliance?

The Resolution Pack must include specified records, including the item calling for “adequate records and Client’s written permission” in relation to the use of Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Accordingly, the Authorised Person should ensure the pack contains documentation that (a) identifies and supports any circumstances in which Client assets/investments could be used, and (b) includes the Client’s written permission that authorises such use. This pairing is essential: the prohibition sets the default “must not” position, and the Resolution Pack record set provides the evidence trail showing that any exception is only applied where the Client’s prior written permission exists and is retrievable within the pack.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or for another Person, what must be in the Resolution Pack to show this is not prohibited?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person is considering using a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person, it is prohibited from doing so unless it has the Client’s prior written permission [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. The Resolution Pack requirement supports this by requiring that the pack include “adequate records and Client’s written permission” in relation to the use of Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. So, to show the activity is not prohibited, the Resolution Pack must contain the Client’s written permission (and it must be prior) and the related adequate records that document the relevant use. Without that written permission included in the pack, the Authorised Person cannot demonstrate that the condition for permitted use has been met, and the prohibition would apply. Keeping both the permission and the supporting records together in the Resolution Pack makes it clear whether the Authorised Person stayed within the rule.

question: When a Fund Manager is following the procedure for filing a Prospectus pursuant to the FUNDS Rules and, for the relevant purpose, issues a Supplementary Prospectus, what specific identification details and filing date information must be included in that Supplementary Prospectus, and what filing and distribution steps must be completed in relation to the Regulator, applicants for Units, and the media/channels used for the previous Prospectus?
expected_answer: In the context of filing a Prospectus pursuant to the FUNDS Rules [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae], where a Fund Manager issues a Supplementary Prospectus for the relevant purpose, the Fund Manager must ensure the Supplementary Prospectus is drafted and handled in a way that both ties it clearly to the existing disclosure and completes the required filing and dissemination steps [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. Specifically, the Supplementary Prospectus must clearly identify the Prospectus it supplements, describe the revisions being made, state the date of any material change or new matter that triggered the revision, and state the date of the Supplementary Prospectus, which must be the date it is filed with the Regulator. If the Fund is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must file a copy of the Supplementary Prospectus with the Regulator. The Fund Manager must also provide a copy to each Person who applied for, but has not yet been issued with, Units under the previous Prospectus after the earliest date of the material change or new matter. Finally, the Fund Manager must ensure the Supplementary Prospectus is made available in the same media and through the same channels as, and together with, the previous Prospectus.

debug_context.semantic_hook: Filing a Prospectus pursuant to FUNDS Rules

answer_spans.text: Where a Fund Manager, for the purpose of Rule ‎9.

question: If a Fund Manager is filing a Prospectus under the FUNDS Rules and then issues a Supplementary Prospectus, what must the Fund Manager put in that document to link it to the earlier Prospectus, and what must the Fund Manager do to file it and share it with the Regulator, pending Unit applicants, and through the same channels as the earlier Prospectus?
expected_answer: When a Fund Manager is carrying out the process of filing a Prospectus pursuant to the FUNDS Rules [#SRC:e4deea41-675d-4fa5-ae79-a01f6cae63ae] and issues a Supplementary Prospectus for the relevant purpose, the Fund Manager has specific content, filing, and delivery obligations [#TGT:17adb20e-b7ae-4839-917d-924a2eddb898]. The Supplementary Prospectus must clearly point back to the Prospectus it supplements and must spell out what is being changed (the revisions). It must also include the date of any material change or new matter that caused the revisions, and it must show the date of the Supplementary Prospectus itself; that document date must match the date it is filed with the Regulator. If the Fund is a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must file a copy of the Supplementary Prospectus with the Regulator. The Fund Manager must also give a copy to each Person who applied for Units but has not yet been issued Units under the previous Prospectus, where that application was made after the earliest date of the material change or new matter. In addition, the Fund Manager must make the Supplementary Prospectus available in the same media and through the same channels as, and together with, the previous Prospectus.

question: When an Authorised Person has a securitisation position that falls into the highest risk-weight outcome under the applicable securitisation tables, must it still assign a risk weight to calculate Credit RWA amounts, or can it instead deduct the Exposure value from its CET1 Capital, and how should it determine which approach applies?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to assign a risk weight for any SE Exposure in accordance with the relevant securitisation tables in order to calculate the Credit RWA amounts for that Exposure [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. However, where the securitisation position is one that is assigned a 1000% risk weighting under those tables, the framework also allows an alternative treatment: instead of including the position in the Credit RWA calculation, the Authorised Person may deduct from its CET1 Capital the Exposure value of that position [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88]. In practice, the Authorised Person should first apply the tables to identify the applicable outcome for the exposure (including whether it results in a 1000% risk weight or a “1000% or deduction” outcome) and, if the exposure is in that category, decide between (i) applying the 1000% risk weight to compute Credit RWA amounts or (ii) taking the permitted alternative of deducting the Exposure value from CET1 Capital, consistent with the stated option for such positions [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88].

question: For a securitisation Exposure that the tables indicate is subject to either a 1000% risk weight or a deduction outcome, what must an Authorised Person do to comply with the risk-weight assignment requirement, and under what condition is it permitted to deduct the Exposure value from its CET1 Capital instead of including it in Credit RWA amounts?
expected_answer: To comply, an Authorised Person must apply the securitisation tables to the SE Exposure and assign the risk weight indicated by those tables for the purpose of calculating the Credit RWA amounts for that Exposure [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. The tables themselves contemplate that, at the highest end of the scale, the outcome may be expressed as “1000% or deduction from Capital Resources,” which means the exposure sits in a category where a 1000% risk weight is the default risk-weighting result but an alternative deduction treatment is also contemplated [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. Where the securitisation position is one that is assigned a 1000% risk weighting pursuant to those tables, the Authorised Person is permitted, as an alternative to including the position in its calculation of Credit RWA amounts, to deduct from its CET1 Capital the Exposure value of the position [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88]. Accordingly, the condition for using the deduction is that the position is in the 1000% risk-weight category under the tables; otherwise, the Authorised Person must proceed with risk-weight assignment and Credit RWA calculation as required [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88].

question: If an Authorised Person has an SE Exposure that ends up in the 1000% risk-weight bucket under the securitisation tables, does it have to calculate Credit RWA amounts using that risk weight, or can it choose to deduct the Exposure value from its CET1 Capital instead?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must use the securitisation tables to assign a risk weight for any SE Exposure so it can calculate the Credit RWA amounts for that exposure [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. The tables also show that, at the highest end, the result may be “1000% or deduction from Capital Resources,” which signals that exposures in that category can be treated either by applying a 1000% risk weight or by taking a deduction approach [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. Where the securitisation position is one that is assigned a 1000% risk weighting under those tables, the Authorised Person is permitted to use an alternative to the Credit RWA calculation: it may deduct from its CET1 Capital the Exposure value of the position instead of including it in the Credit RWA amounts computation [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88]. So the required step is to apply the tables and identify the applicable category; if the exposure is in the 1000% category, the Authorised Person can choose between calculating Credit RWA amounts using the risk weight or deducting the Exposure value from CET1 Capital, as allowed [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88].

question: What does an Authorised Person need to do first for any SE Exposure, and when is it allowed to skip adding the position into Credit RWA amounts and instead deduct the Exposure value from its CET1 Capital?
expected_answer: First, an Authorised Person must assign a risk weight for any SE Exposure by following the securitisation tables, and it does this to calculate the Credit RWA amounts for that exposure [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. Those tables include outcomes where the risk weight applied can reach 1000%, and in some cases the table outcome is framed as “1000% or deduction from Capital Resources,” indicating that the highest-risk category is linked to a possible deduction treatment rather than only a risk-weight calculation [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638]. The permission to use the deduction is limited to the situation where the securitisation position is assigned a 1000% risk weighting under the tables: in that case, the Authorised Person may, as an alternative to including the position in its Credit RWA amounts calculation, deduct from its CET1 Capital the Exposure value of the position [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88]. So the sequence is: apply the tables and determine the category; only if it is the 1000% category can the Authorised Person choose the CET1 deduction instead of the Credit RWA calculation [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88].

question: When calculating its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, how must an Authorised Person determine the jurisdictions to which its private sector credit exposures are attributed for purposes of applying the weighted average of applicable buffer rates, and how does that jurisdictional identification feed into the multiplication against the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To determine which jurisdictions’ rates are included in that weighted average, the Authorised Person must, to the best of its ability, identify the geographical location of its private sector credit exposures as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]. In practice, this means the jurisdictional mapping is not based merely on where an exposure is booked or where a counterparty is administered, but on where the underlying credit risk originates, and those identified jurisdictions then define the set of applicable buffer rates used in the weighted average. The resulting weighted average rate is the factor applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount to produce the required CET1 Countercyclical Capital Buffer.

To decide which jurisdictions are relevant for that weighted average, the Authorised Person must identify, to the best of its ability, the geographical location of its private sector credit exposures as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]. This identification step matters because it determines which jurisdictions’ buffer rates are treated as “applicable” to the Authorised Person’s exposures and therefore which rates are included in the weighted average. Once the exposures are attributed to jurisdictions on that basis, the Authorised Person uses the corresponding applicable buffer rates to compute the weighted average, and then applies that single weighted average rate to the Total Risk Exposure Amount to arrive at the CET1 Countercyclical Capital Buffer.

question: When assessing whether an Insider’s communication of Inside Information to another person falls outside the relevant scope, how should compliance distinguish between a disclosure made in accordance with the Insider’s employment, office, profession or duties and a disclosure made otherwise than in the proper course of exercising his employment, profession or duties?
expected_answer: The scope boundary turns on whether the Insider’s disclosure of Inside Information to another person is connected to, and made in line with, the Insider’s role-based functions, versus being made outside that proper role context. On the permission side, the framework recognises that disclosure is not prohibited where the Insider makes the disclosure in accordance with the Insider’s employment, office, profession or duties, i.e., as part of what the role requires or authorises [#SRC:ecc61e9a-8e78-4813-b5ee-b57fdb74268a]. On the scope side, the contrasting situation is expressly characterised as the case where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. Practically, compliance should map the disclosure to the Insider’s stated employment/office/profession/duties and ask whether the communication was made as part of exercising those functions (within the proper course) or instead occurred outside that proper course. If it is outside the proper course, it aligns with the scoped “second” situation; if it is within the role’s proper exercise, it aligns with the permitted category.

debug_context.semantic_hook: does not prohibit the disclosure of Inside Information

answer_spans.text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: If an Insider shares Inside Information with someone else, when is that sharing allowed as part of the Insider’s job or duties, and when is it treated as being outside the proper course of doing that job or duties?
expected_answer: You separate the two situations by checking whether the Insider’s disclosure of Inside Information to another person is tied to the Insider’s work role and done as part of carrying out that role, or whether it is done outside that proper role context. The permission point is that disclosure is not prohibited when the Insider makes the disclosure in accordance with the Insider’s employment, office, profession or duties—meaning it is made as part of what the role involves [#SRC:ecc61e9a-8e78-4813-b5ee-b57fdb74268a]. The scope contrast is the situation described as where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. So, if the sharing is part of exercising the Insider’s employment/office/profession/duties in the proper course, it fits the permitted category; if it is not in the proper course of exercising those functions, it fits the “otherwise than” situation. The key is the connection to, and proper execution of, the Insider’s role-based duties at the time of disclosure.

question: When an Authorised Person determines its Credit RWA as an aggregate measure, how must it combine the RWA components for Credit Risk Exposures, securitisation Exposures, and Counterparty Risk Exposures, and how should exposures arising from repurchase agreements, reverse repurchase agreements, similar transactions, and other deferred settlements be treated within that overall Credit RWA calculation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must determine its Credit RWA as a single total that is built by summing three distinct RWA components: (i) the RWA for all of its Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (ii) the RWA for all of its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (iii) the RWA for its Counterparty Risk Exposures, each calculated under the applicable calculation provisions referenced in the definition [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. In applying that definition to specific transaction types, exposures arising from repurchase agreements, reverse repurchase agreements, similar transactions, and other deferred settlements are within the scope of Credit RWA as a relevant exposure category that must be captured in the overall Credit RWA measure [#TGT:b70a41ab-87bd-4974-ae86-252a529a3dc0]. Accordingly, the Authorised Person should ensure that any RWA attributable to those transactions is reflected in the appropriate component(s) of the summed Credit RWA total, rather than being omitted or treated outside the Credit RWA aggregation framework [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] [#TGT:b70a41ab-87bd-4974-ae86-252a529a3dc0].
