question: How do you add up an Authorised Person’s Credit RWA, and where do repurchase agreements, reverse repurchase agreements, similar transactions, and other deferred settlements fit into that total?
expected_answer: To calculate an Authorised Person’s Credit RWA, you do not look at a single exposure type in isolation; you must add together three RWA amounts to reach one total Credit RWA figure. Specifically, Credit RWA is the sum of the risk weighted assets for (1) all Credit Risk Exposures (called CR Exposures), (2) all securitisation Exposures (called SE Exposures), and (3) the Counterparty Risk Exposures, with each component calculated under the relevant calculation provisions referenced in the definition [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. The reference to “Credit RWA” also covers transaction types such as repurchase agreements, reverse repurchase agreements, similar transactions, and other deferred settlements, meaning these transactions are part of what must be captured when you are determining Credit RWA [#TGT:b70a41ab-87bd-4974-ae86-252a529a3dc0]. In practice, you should ensure the RWA impact of those transactions is included within the summed Credit RWA total, consistent with the requirement that Credit RWA is an aggregate of the three RWA components rather than a standalone line item [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] [#TGT:b70a41ab-87bd-4974-ae86-252a529a3dc0].

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, under what conditions may it treat the general preparation requirement for disclosures that include statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets as not applying, and what preparation framework must still be followed for the disclosure overall?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to treat the otherwise-applicable requirement to comply with the general disclosure preparation rule as not applying where it is disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, but only on the condition that it complies with the specified alternative rules (Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4 and Rule 11.7.6) [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. This permission operates as a conditional carve-out from the general preparation obligation that would otherwise attach to disclosures that include statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. Even where the carve-out is available, the disclosure remains within the category of “requirements for all disclosures” and therefore must still be prepared in accordance with the overarching framework applicable to such disclosures—namely, in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and this chapter [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. In practice, the Mining Reporting Entity should document that the disclosure includes material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, confirm compliance with each of the listed alternative rules, and ensure the disclosure is prepared consistently with the Mining Reporting Standard and chapter-wide requirements.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity reports material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, when can it avoid following the usual disclosure preparation rule, and what does it still have to prepare the disclosure in line with when it includes statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets?
expected_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it can rely on a permission that means it does not need to comply with the usual disclosure preparation rule, but only if it complies with the specified substitute requirements: Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4 and Rule 11.7.6 [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. This matters because the general regime for disclosures says that any disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and this chapter [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. So, even when the Mining Reporting Entity uses the carve-out for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it still needs to prepare the disclosure under the overarching framework for all such disclosures—following a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter requirements—while also meeting the four listed rules that are the condition for not having to comply with the usual preparation rule [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d].

question: When admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, what due diligence must a Recognised Investment Exchange undertake to ensure the Price Reporting Agency satisfies the required procedural, transparency, governance, independence, conflicts, and complaints standards?
expected_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange admits to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, it must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure that the Price Reporting Agency meets the applicable requirements [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da]. That due diligence should be directed to confirming, for the relevant purposes, that the Price Reporting Agency has fair and non-discriminatory price-establishment procedures that are made public; provides adequate transparency over methodology, calculation, and inputs so users can understand how the benchmark or index is derived and its limitations; and, where appropriate, prioritises concluded transactions while adopting measures to minimise selective reporting [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The Recognised Investment Exchange should also verify that the Price Reporting Agency is of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider, maintains a sound corporate governance framework, and has adequate arrangements to avoid staff conflicts of interest that are, or are likely to have, a material adverse impact on the price establishment process [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Finally, due diligence should cover whether the Price Reporting Agency has adequate complaint resolution mechanisms for complaints about its assessment process and methodology [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure

answer_spans.text: For the purposes of Rules 3.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange admits a Financial Instrument to trading and it uses a benchmark or index from a Price Reporting Agency, what checks must the exchange do to make sure the Price Reporting Agency meets the required standards?
expected_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, the exchange must carry out appropriate due diligence to ensure the Price Reporting Agency meets the relevant requirements [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da]. In practical terms, the checks must cover whether the Price Reporting Agency has fair, non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices and whether those procedures are made public; and whether it can demonstrate adequate transparency over its methodology, calculation, and inputs so users can understand how the benchmark or index is derived and what its potential limitations are [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The exchange should also assess whether, where appropriate, the Price Reporting Agency gives priority to concluded transactions and has measures to minimise selective reporting; whether it is of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider; and whether it has a sound corporate governance framework [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The due diligence must further consider whether the Price Reporting Agency has adequate arrangements to avoid staff conflicts of interest that could materially adversely affect the price establishment process, and whether it maintains adequate complaint resolution mechanisms for its assessment process and methodology [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure

answer_spans.text: For the purposes of Rules 3.

question: When the Regulator is considering the tools available to it, how should a firm understand the Regulator’s ability to impose requirements and later change those requirements, and how does this sit alongside the Regulator’s broader suite of supervisory and enforcement powers over Authorised Persons, Approved Persons, and Recognised Bodies?
expected_answer: The Regulator’s available toolkit expressly includes the ability to impose Requirements on a firm, and this should be read together with the stated concept of “imposition and variation of requirements,” which indicates that requirements are not only capable of being imposed but may also be adjusted over time as part of ongoing regulatory oversight [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584] [#TGT:531c02ad-aada-4128-84f2-87914f1a1cc8]. In practice, this power sits within a wider range of powers that the Regulator may deploy depending on the circumstances, including requiring information or documents, requiring a report from a skilled person, and taking action affecting an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission (including varying, suspending, or cancelling it) [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584]. The Regulator may also impose or vary conditions on an Approved Person on its own initiative, and it can issue a Direction to a Recognised Body or revoke a Recognition Order [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584]. Taken together, the “imposition and variation” framing underscores that requirements can be a dynamic supervisory measure within this broader set of regulatory levers [#TGT:531c02ad-aada-4128-84f2-87914f1a1cc8].

debug_context.semantic_hook: The range of powers available to us includes

answer_spans.text: Imposition and variation of requirements.

question: What does it mean, in plain terms, that the Regulator can impose requirements and also vary them later, and what other powers does the Regulator have that relate to firms, Authorised Persons, Approved Persons, and Recognised Bodies?
expected_answer: It means the Regulator can place Requirements on a firm and can later change those requirements, reflecting that requirements may be used and adjusted as part of ongoing regulatory supervision [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584] [#TGT:531c02ad-aada-4128-84f2-87914f1a1cc8]. This sits within a broader set of powers the Regulator says are available to it. For example, the Regulator can require information or documents and can require a report from a skilled person, which can support decisions about whether requirements are needed or should be updated [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584]. The Regulator can also take action affecting an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission, including varying, suspending, or cancelling it, and it can impose or vary conditions on an Approved Person on its own initiative [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584]. In addition, the Regulator can give a Direction to a Recognised Body and can revoke a Recognition Order [#SRC:91136058-cc7e-4ef2-a787-46f73fafb584]. So, “imposition and variation of requirements” is one specific tool within a wider range of regulatory actions [#TGT:531c02ad-aada-4128-84f2-87914f1a1cc8].

debug_context.semantic_hook: The range of powers available to us includes

answer_spans.text: Imposition and variation of requirements.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, may it make the permission to disclose subject to conditions, including requirements around obtaining consents and ensuring the recipient applies disclosure restrictions that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions?
expected_answer: Yes. The framework permits the Regulator, when making a disclosure of Confidential Information, to attach conditions to the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions may address how the disclosure is managed, including requiring the obtaining of consents and, where appropriate, requiring that information received is subjected to restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. This means the Regulator can structure the permission so that disclosure is not unconditional, but instead is controlled through specified safeguards that govern the handling of the Confidential Information by the recipient. The same permission also allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, reinforcing that both onward disclosure and downstream use can be constrained as part of the disclosure arrangement. These powers are described as enabling the Regulator to impose conditions on the information disclosed and to restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and are reflected in the permission to disclose being made subject to conditions (including consents and equivalent restrictions) insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].

question: If the Regulator shares Confidential Information, can it put conditions on that permission—like requiring consents or requiring the receiver to follow confidentiality limits that are at least equivalent to the usual restrictions?
expected_answer: Yes. When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, it is permitted to include conditions as part of the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions can cover practical safeguards around the disclosure, including requiring that consents are obtained and, where appropriate, requiring that the recipient treats the information under restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. In other words, the Regulator can allow disclosure but only on terms that control how the information is handled after it is shared, rather than granting an unrestricted permission. In addition, the same permission allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, so the recipient may be limited not only in whether it can re-disclose the information but also in what it can do with it. This aligns with the statement that the Regulator may impose conditions on the information disclosed (including consents and equivalent restrictions) and may restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and with the permission being expressly subject to such conditions insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].

question: When an Authorised Person applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to undertake additional Regulated Activities, what application fee methodology must be applied—specifically, how do the general requirement to pay the applicable application fees and the rule for multiple or additional Regulated Activities determine which fee is payable and whether extra fees apply for each added activity?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person must pay application fees to the Regulator in accordance with the applicable fee provisions [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. In applying the fee methodology for situations involving multiple Regulated Activities or amendments to add additional Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. In addition, each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that same time triggers an extra application fee, calculated as the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in the Rules for that activity [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. Read together, the amendment application requires payment to the Regulator, and the amount is determined by selecting the highest applicable fee among the activities in scope for that application, plus incremental fees for each additional activity included in the same submission.

answer_spans.text: the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time

question: If an Authorised Person is applying to change an existing Financial Services Permission so it can do more Regulated Activities, what fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how do you work out the fee when more than one Regulated Activity is included in the same application?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission so it can undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay application fees to the Regulator under the applicable fee provisions [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. When the amendment application covers one or more additional Regulated Activities (or otherwise involves multiple Regulated Activities being applied for at the same time), the fee is not calculated by simply adding only one base fee; instead, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the Regulated Activities included in that application at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. On top of that highest fee, each additional Regulated Activity included in the same application also attracts an extra application fee, which is the lesser of $10,000 or the specific application fee set out in the Rules for that activity [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. In practice, you identify all Regulated Activities being requested in the amendment, pay the highest applicable fee among them, and then add the required incremental fee for each additional activity requested at the same time.

answer_spans.text: the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time

question: When an Authorised Person seeks a change to its Financial Services Permission, how should the firm initiate the process, and what discretion does the Regulator have to vary or cancel the permission once the request is made?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person wants its Financial Services Permission changed, the process is initiated by the firm making a request through an application. The firm must apply in the form that we may prescribe, because we may require the application to be made in a particular format before we will act on it. Once the firm’s request is properly made, we may respond by varying the firm’s Financial Services Permission or cancelling it; this is a discretionary power exercised on the application of the firm rather than an automatic outcome. The TARGET frames the topic as “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission” and specifically contemplates “Variation by the Regulator at the request of an Authorised Person,” aligning the actor and trigger for action with the SOURCE’s mechanism of acting “at the request of a firm” via an application in a prescribed form. Accordingly, the firm’s request (as an Authorised Person) is the procedural gateway, and the Regulator’s discretion determines whether variation or cancellation is the resulting regulatory action. [#SRC:20758d17-f668-430e-a76a-a6914464c127] [#TGT:8744a283-2608-48ca-aeb7-af55f02fa148]

question: If an Authorised Person wants its Financial Services Permission changed, what does the firm need to submit, and what can the Regulator do in response to that request?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person wants its Financial Services Permission changed, the firm must make the request by submitting an application, and it must do so in the form that we may prescribe. This means the firm cannot simply ask informally; the request is channelled through an application process that we control in terms of format. Once the firm has applied, we may take action on that request by varying the firm’s Financial Services Permission, and we may also cancel the permission on the application of the firm. The TARGET confirms both the subject matter (variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission) and the trigger for regulatory action (variation by the Regulator at the request of an Authorised Person), which matches the SOURCE’s statement that we act at the request of a firm. Taken together, the passages show that the firm’s application is the required step to start the process, and the Regulator then has discretion to vary or cancel the permission in response to that request. question: In preparing the annual report/annual financial report, what must the Board of Directors/Directors state about the effectiveness of the entity’s Corporate Governance framework, and how must that statement be supported and framed in relation to adoption of the Corporate Governance Principles and any non-adoption or partial adoption of best practice standards?
expected_answer: Both regimes require the annual report package to contain an express Directors-level assessment of the Corporate Governance framework’s effectiveness, supported by appropriate context and evidence. Under the SOURCE obligation, the annual report must include a statement by the Board of Directors stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the relevant governance outcome and promoting compliance with the Principles, and that statement must be accompanied by supporting information and assumptions, with qualifications if necessary [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. Under the TARGET obligation, the annual financial report of a Listed Entity must state whether the Corporate Governance Principles have been adopted; if not fully or only partially adopted, it must explain why and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap; and it must also include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, again with supporting information and assumptions and qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Practically, the Directors’ effectiveness statement should be consistent with, and informed by, the adoption/disclosure narrative and any described remediation actions.

answer_spans.text: Annual reporting on compliance.

question: When the annual report and annual financial report are prepared, what do the Board of Directors/Directors have to say about whether the Corporate Governance framework works, and what extra details must be included to back up that statement—especially if the Corporate Governance Principles or best practice standards are not fully adopted?
expected_answer: You need a Directors-level statement in the annual reporting that directly addresses whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective, and you must support that view with the right detail. In the SOURCE text, the annual report must include a statement by the Board of Directors saying whether or not, in its opinion, the Reporting Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in achieving the required governance outcome and promoting compliance with the Principles; the statement must include supporting information and assumptions, and it may include qualifications if necessary [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. In the TARGET text, the annual financial report of a Listed Entity must (i) state whether the Corporate Governance Principles have been adopted, (ii) if adoption is not full or is only partial, explain why and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the shortfall, and (iii) include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, again with supporting information and assumptions and qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Together, this means the effectiveness statement should be backed by the adoption status, explanations for gaps, and any actions taken.

question: In relation to a securitisation, how must an Originator ensure it does not provide non-contractual support intended to shield investors from losses, and if such support is nevertheless provided, what investor disclosure and regulatory capital treatment must the Originator apply as the Authorised Person?
expected_answer: An Originator must not provide Implicit Support to a securitisation transaction where the purpose is to reduce potential or actual losses to investors outside of its contractual obligations, and the same prohibition also applies to a Sponsor [#TGT:a7d00358-0608-4ba6-b012-36de1be9cc2f]. If, in respect of a securitisation, an Originator fails to comply with the relevant requirements governing Implicit Support, it must treat the securitisation as if it had not occurred for specified prudential outcomes: it must include all the underlying Exposures of the securitisation in its calculation of Credit RWAs as if those Exposures were on the balance sheet of the Authorised Person, and it must not recognise any gain on sale of assets to the securitisation [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c]. In addition, it must disclose to investors that the Authorised Person has provided non-contractual support and must disclose the regulatory capital impact of doing so, aligning investor transparency with the prohibition on providing such support in the first place [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c].

question: When working on a securitisation, what must an Originator or a Sponsor not do if the aim is to protect investors from losses beyond the contract, and if an Originator ends up giving that kind of support anyway, what must it tell investors and how must it treat the underlying Exposures and any gain on sale?
expected_answer: An Originator or a Sponsor of a securitisation must not provide Implicit Support where the intent is to reduce potential or actual losses to investors outside of its contractual obligations [#TGT:a7d00358-0608-4ba6-b012-36de1be9cc2f]. If, despite that, an Originator fails to comply with the applicable Implicit Support requirements for a securitisation, the Originator must take specific follow-on actions as the Authorised Person [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c]. First, it must include all the underlying Exposures of the securitisation in its calculation of Credit RWAs as if those Exposures had not been securitised and were on the balance sheet of the Authorised Person. Second, it must not recognise any gain on sale of assets to the securitisation. Third, it must disclose to investors that the Authorised Person has provided non-contractual support and disclose the regulatory capital impact of doing so, so investors understand both that support occurred and its prudential consequences [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c].

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, what must it do to ensure the required satisfactory arrangements are in place for timely discharge and clearing and settlement, and how should those arrangements be framed by reference to the requirements set out elsewhere?
expected_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge (including by performance, compromise or otherwise) and the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange. This obligation focuses on ensuring that the arrangements cover both timing and the full lifecycle of clearing and settlement for transaction-related rights and liabilities. In addition, the satisfactory arrangements that are required in this context should be drafted and structured so that they reference the requirements set out in Rule 4.3.3, thereby aligning the arrangements with those specified requirements rather than treating them as standalone provisions. Taken together, the Recognised Investment Exchange must both (i) put in place arrangements that achieve timely discharge and clearing/settlement outcomes when using a Clearing Service, and (ii) ensure that the content of those arrangements explicitly points to and is informed by the requirements set out in Rule 4.3.3, as part of meeting the required standard for “satisfactory arrangements.” [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616] [#SRC:549c69d5-2c89-4747-8878-9ae4ce57346e]

question: When an Authorised Person is required to hold regulatory capital in line with the capital requirements applicable to a Recognised Investment Exchange, what form must that regulatory capital take, and how must the amount of capital be determined (including any operational-expense baseline and any buffer that may apply unless the Regulator directs otherwise)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is subject to the capital framework aligned to the requirements a Recognised Investment Exchange must meet is required to hold its regulatory capital in fiat form, rather than in another form of asset, because the regulatory capital held by an Authorised Person must be in fiat form under the applicable capital requirements [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d]. The amount of capital to be held is determined by reference to the Recognised Investment Exchange standard: a Recognised Investment Exchange shall hold capital equal to 6 months’ operational expenses, plus (unless the Regulator directs otherwise) an additional buffer amount of up to a further 6 months’ operational expenses [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]. Read together, the cross-reference means the Authorised Person’s regulatory capital must both (i) be held in fiat form and (ii) be sized consistently with the operational-expense-based minimum and the potential additional buffer contemplated for a Recognised Investment Exchange, subject to any direction by the Regulator regarding the buffer.

question: Where an Authorised Person proposes to stake Virtual Assets that are held as a Client's Safe Custody Assets, is the Authorised Person prohibited from doing so on the basis that staking is treated as use for the Authorised Person’s own purpose, unless the Client has given prior written permission?
expected_answer: Yes. The Regulator’s interpretive position is that, for the relevant purposes, the use of Virtual Assets for “staking” is treated as use for the purposes of the Authorised Person [#SRC:ee60daeb-c185-4221-bf81-7a1bbeb8badc]. Separately, the prohibition applicable to an Authorised Person is that it must not use a Client's Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person without that Client's prior written permission; the operative compliance threshold is the Client’s “prior written permission,” and the key modality is “must not” [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. Read together, if the Virtual Assets being staked are a Client's Safe Custody Assets, staking would be characterised as use for the Authorised Person’s own purpose, which falls within the prohibited category unless the Client has provided prior written permission. The same analysis applies if the staking arrangement would be for the purpose of another Person, because the prohibition covers both the Authorised Person’s own purpose and that of another Person, and still requires the Client’s prior written permission.

debug_context.semantic_hook: consider the use of Virtual Assets for the purpose

answer_spans.text: must not

question: If an Authorised Person wants to stake Virtual Assets that belong to a Client and are held as the Client's Safe Custody Assets, must the Authorised Person avoid doing this unless it has the Client’s prior written permission, since staking is treated as use for the Authorised Person’s own purpose?
expected_answer: Yes. The Regulator’s stated approach is that using Virtual Assets for the purpose of “staking” is considered to be use for the purposes of the Authorised Person [#SRC:ee60daeb-c185-4221-bf81-7a1bbeb8badc]. Separately, the rule for an Authorised Person is that it must not use a Client's Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person without that Client's prior written permission; the concrete compliance requirement is “prior written permission,” and the prohibition is expressed as “must not” [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. Putting these together, if the Virtual Assets being staked are part of the Client's Safe Custody Assets, staking would be treated as the Authorised Person using those assets for its own purpose, which is prohibited unless the Client has already provided prior written permission. The same restriction applies if the staking is framed as benefiting another Person, because the prohibition also covers use for “another Person” and still requires the Client’s prior written permission.

question: When a Listed Entity enters into an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is expressly conditional on holder approval, and the proposed issue would otherwise exceed the permitted maximum number of Equity Securities under the new-issue restriction formula, what is the prohibition on proceeding without the holders of Ordinary Securities approving the issue, and how does that approval interact with the calculation of the maximum and relevant issues?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing Equity Securities under a conditional agreement unless the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue before the issue is made; if the Listed Entity relies on that conditional-agreement exception, it must not proceed to issue without the required approval. This prohibition operates alongside the broader restriction that a Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number calculated under the formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities. Accordingly, where the contemplated issue would exceed the calculated maximum, the Listed Entity must obtain holder approval to avoid breaching the restriction on new issues, and that same approval is also the condition that must be satisfied before any issuance can occur under the conditional agreement. In addition, approvals under the relevant approval rules affect the formula mechanics by excluding approved issuances or agreements from “Relevant Issues” and by allowing certain approved issuances to be included in the “Base Amount,” which can change the maximum number permitted. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

debug_context.semantic_hook: must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval

answer_spans.text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities .

question: If a Listed Entity signs a deal to issue Equity Securities but says it will only go ahead if holders approve, can it still issue the Equity Securities without that approval, especially if the deal would put it over the maximum number allowed under the new-issue limit?
expected_answer: No. If a Listed Entity relies on an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue before it is made, the Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing the Equity Securities unless and until that approval has been obtained; it must not issue without such approval. Separately, the Listed Entity is also prohibited from issuing, or even agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities. This means that where the proposed issue (or agreement) would exceed the calculated maximum, holder approval is required to avoid breaching the new-issue restriction, and the same approval is also the gating condition for any issuance under the conditional agreement. The approval is also relevant to how the limit is measured: issuances or agreements made with holder approval are carved out from “Relevant Issues,” and certain approved issuances can be counted in the “Base Amount,” which can affect the maximum number permitted. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When documents referenced in the Rules have already been Disclosed, how does that affect whether an Issuer must make an additional continuous disclosure, given that the continuous disclosure regime operates alongside periodic/financial reporting and broader legal disclosure duties (including prospectus and transaction documents)?
expected_answer: Where the documents referred to in the relevant paragraphs have already been Disclosed, the Listing Authority treats the information contained in those documents as having entered the market, so it is not expected to be the subject of a separate, additional continuous disclosure under the continuous disclosure regime. This is a permission/relief effect tied to the status of the information after disclosure: once the specified documents are Disclosed, the information is regarded as already “within the market,” and therefore does not require a further standalone disclosure under the continuous disclosure obligation. [#SRC:0bb0c147-7d66-4abf-b7a7-624b435bfba6] The scope boundary for applying that relief should be assessed in the context that continuous disclosure operates closely with other disclosure frameworks, including periodic/financial disclosure obligations and general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM) and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM), which can include Prospectus Offer documents and bidders’ and targets’ statements. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f] Accordingly, the interaction turns on whether the information has already been made available through those Disclosed documents, rather than duplicating disclosures across overlapping regimes.

question: If a Listed Entity has already Disclosed the documents mentioned in the Rules, does it still need to make a separate continuous disclosure, and how does this fit with the wider set of periodic/financial reporting and other legal disclosure duties (like prospectus and deal documents)?
expected_answer: If the documents referred to in the relevant paragraphs have been Disclosed, the Listing Authority will treat the information in those documents as already being in the market, so a separate additional disclosure under the continuous disclosure obligation is not required for that same information. This means the Listed Entity can rely on the fact of that prior Disclosure to avoid duplicating the same content through a further standalone continuous disclosure. [#SRC:0bb0c147-7d66-4abf-b7a7-624b435bfba6] This conclusion sits within a broader scope where continuous disclosure is designed to operate closely with other disclosure regimes, including periodic/financial disclosure obligations and general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM) and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM). Those wider obligations can include Prospectus Offer documents and bidders’ and targets’ statements, among other materials. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f] Practically, the key boundary is whether the information has already been made available through the Disclosed documents that feed into these overlapping disclosure frameworks.

question: When an Authorised Person communicates information to a Person about a Specified Investment, and the communication is made in the broader context of an Offer of Securities in ADGM and any related ADGM Green Bond Designation or ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation assertions by an ADGM Issuer, what must the Authorised Person do to ensure the communication meets the required standard?
expected_answer: Across both passages, the core obligation is that an Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure that any communication to a Person, when made in relation to a Specified Investment, is presented in a way that is clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:48bcaa58-c3a9-4d7f-8042-bfb462cf2949] and this same standard is expressly required when communicating information in relation to a Specified Investment or a Regulated Activity [#TGT:a8ef44c9-fb33-4526-bbf5-6c7986418bb7]. In practice, this means the Authorised Person should apply this communications standard not only to general investment-related messaging, but also when communications sit alongside, or refer to, ADGM offer-related requirements and any indication that an ADGM Issuer is issuing a debenture it asserts aligns with Qualifying Green Debenture Principles or Qualifying Sustainability-Linked Debenture Principles [#SRC:48bcaa58-c3a9-4d7f-8042-bfb462cf2949]. The obligation is framed as taking “reasonable steps,” so the Authorised Person must actively manage how information is drafted and presented to avoid ambiguity, imbalance, or misleading impressions, regardless of whether the communication concerns only the Specified Investment or also touches a Regulated Activity [#TGT:a8ef44c9-fb33-4526-bbf5-6c7986418bb7].

The source passage adds that, in ADGM, there are requirements on a Person who makes or intends to make an Offer of Securities, and that the Regulator has developed the ADGM Green Bond Designation and the ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation to indicate that an ADGM Issuer is issuing a debenture it asserts is in accordance with relevant qualifying principles [#SRC:48bcaa58-c3a9-4d7f-8042-bfb462cf2949]. So, if the Authorised Person’s message references an offer context or these designations, the Authorised Person must still apply the same “reasonable steps” standard to ensure the overall message remains clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:a8ef44c9-fb33-4526-bbf5-6c7986418bb7].

question: When determining the market value of Securities and the value of Collateral, what must a firm do to ensure the calculation is aligned with the CRM-based valuation approach while also meeting the requirement to reflect interest that has accrued on cash lodged?
expected_answer: In valuing the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral, the firm should perform the calculation using the CRM provisions referenced for those valuations, so that the methodology and treatment of collateral value follow the specified CRM-based approach [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. At the same time, the firm must ensure that, where the valuation concerns cash lodged, the amount used is not limited to principal but also captures any accrued interest, because the MV of Securities and the value of cash lodged must include accrued interest [#TGT:974348fa-78ad-4ea9-8c8f-a3ef02fb80ff]. Read together, this means the CRM-aligned calculation should be applied to the relevant valuation inputs, and the cash component must be adjusted to include accrued interest so the resulting collateral and cash values are complete and compliant. Practically, the valuation output should therefore reflect both (i) CRM-consistent calculation for Securities and Collateral and (ii) inclusion of accrued interest for cash lodged, without treating these as separate or optional steps.

question: If you are working out the market value of Securities and the value of Collateral, what do you need to do to follow the CRM calculation approach and also make sure cash lodged is valued correctly?
expected_answer: You need to do two things together. First, when you calculate the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral, you should base that calculation on the CRM provisions that govern how those values are worked out, rather than using an unrelated method [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. Second, if part of what you are valuing is cash lodged, you must not record only the cash amount paid in; you must include any interest that has built up, because the MV of Securities and the value of cash lodged must include accrued interest [#TGT:974348fa-78ad-4ea9-8c8f-a3ef02fb80ff]. Putting these together, your valuation process should apply the CRM-based calculation framework for Securities and Collateral, and it should also adjust the cash lodged figure so it includes accrued interest. If the MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer, it must also ensure it has effective systems and controls to operationalise that permission: it must admit only Securities of Exempt Offers made on its own platform, identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. In addition, the MTF must have controls to comply with the applicable admission-to-trading requirements and to allow users to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents, so that trading access and information access align with the platform’s Exempt Offer admission framework [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].

question: When an Authorised Person’s positions are held with trading intent and meet the value thresholds that trigger the requirement to maintain a Trading Book, what must the Authorised Person do to consistently distinguish Trading Book activity from Non Trading Book activity, and what other compliance step must it take in relation to the applicable appendix requirements?

Once it is in that category—i.e., it must have a Trading Book—the Authorised Person must take two linked actions to ensure its business is properly organised around that Trading Book status: first, it must comply with the requirements of the specified appendix section; and second, it must differentiate its business between Trading Book activity and Non Trading Book activity on a consistent basis [#SRC:aba54eac-db1f-431a-be16-6e410fca8f27]. In practice under these obligations, the differentiation requirement applies as an ongoing, consistent classification approach across the Authorised Person’s business, and it sits alongside (not instead of) the separate duty to comply with the relevant appendix requirements that govern the Trading Book framework [#SRC:aba54eac-db1f-431a-be16-6e410fca8f27] and the conditions that trigger having a Trading Book [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0].

question: In determining the scope of the Market Abuse regime, when may a Person rely on compliance with the Price Stabilisation framework so that Price Stabilisation activity is treated as not breaching the relevant prohibition and also falls outside the definition of Market Abuse for these Regulations?
expected_answer: A Person may treat Price Stabilisation conduct as outside the Market Abuse regime only where the conduct is carried out in accordance with the applicable Price Stabilisation Rules and the Person can establish that this is the case. On the SOURCE side, the permission is framed as a conditional safe outcome: if a Person establishes that they carried out Price Stabilisation in accordance with MKT 6.2, then that conduct will not contravene the relevant prohibition, because MKT 6.2 contains the Rules that must be complied with when carrying on Price Stabilisation [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e]. On the TARGET side, the scope exclusion for Market Abuse applies where Behaviour conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules, meaning that conforming conduct does not amount to Market Abuse for the purposes of these Regulations [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1]. Read together, the boundary is not a blanket exemption for all stabilisation activity: it depends on conformity with the specified Rules (MKT 6.2/Price Stabilisation Rules) and the Person’s ability to demonstrate that conformity.

question: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, if an Authorised Person liquidates part of its stock of HQLA to generate cash for outflows and, as a result, its HQLA level falls below what is required for its LCR Requirement, what notification must it make to the Regulator and when must that notification be made?

However, if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement as a consequence of that liquidation and resulting reduction in HQLA, or if it becomes aware of circumstances arising from the stress and outflows that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This obligation applies at any time, and expressly includes periods of stress, so the permissibility of drawing down HQLA to manage outflows does not remove the requirement to provide immediate written notice when the LCR Requirement is not met or is at risk of not being met [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].

question: When calculating regulatory capital, what deductions must an Authorised Person apply for (i) direct or indirect holdings of its own capital instruments that it may be required to purchase under existing contractual obligations, and (ii) holdings in Relevant Entities that create reciprocal cross-holdings inflating Capital Resources, and how do these required deductions operate across both AT1 Capital and T2 Capital calculations, including any underwriting holding-period exclusion?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must make parallel, instrument-specific deductions when calculating both AT1 Capital and T2 Capital. For AT1 Capital, it must deduct direct and indirect holdings of its own AT1 Capital instruments, including instruments where it is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase due to an existing contractual obligation, and it must also deduct holdings of AT1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where reciprocal cross-holdings artificially inflate the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8]. For T2 Capital, it must likewise deduct direct and indirect holdings of its own T2 Capital instruments, including own T2 instruments it could be obliged to purchase as a result of existing contractual obligations, and it must deduct holdings of T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where reciprocal cross holding has the effect of artificially inflating Capital Resources [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab]. In both regimes, the deductions also extend to holdings in Relevant Entities depending on whether the Authorised Person has a significant investment, and both provide an underwriting-related exclusion tied to a five-working-day holding period (AT1: five working days or fewer; T2: fewer than five working days), which limits what must be deducted for underwriting positions.

answer_spans.text: T2 regulatory deductions and exclusions.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out its AT1 Capital and its T2 Capital, what items must it subtract for (1) its own instruments it might have to buy because of a contract, and (2) cross-holdings with Relevant Entities that make its Capital Resources look bigger, and how does the underwriting time limit change what gets deducted?
expected_answer: In both calculations, the Authorised Person must subtract certain holdings so the capital figure is not overstated. For AT1 Capital, it must deduct its direct and indirect holdings of its own AT1 Capital instruments, including cases where it has an actual or contingent obligation to purchase under an existing contractual obligation, and it must deduct holdings of AT1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where reciprocal cross-holdings artificially inflate the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8]. For T2 Capital, it must similarly deduct direct and indirect holdings of its own T2 Capital instruments, including own T2 instruments it could be obliged to purchase because of existing contractual obligations, and it must deduct holdings of T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where reciprocal cross holding has the effect of artificially inflating Capital Resources [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab]. Both sets of rules also require deductions for holdings in Relevant Entities depending on whether the Authorised Person has a significant investment, but each includes an underwriting exclusion tied to a five-working-day threshold, meaning certain underwriting positions held only briefly are excluded from the deduction requirement.

question: How must a Listed Entity operationalise the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach to the Corporate Governance Principles in its annual financial report, including the required disclosures where the APP 4 best practice standards are not fully adopted and the role of Directors’ statements?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must implement the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach to the Corporate Governance Principles by making specific, structured disclosures in its annual financial report. The report must first state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. Where those standards have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted, the Listed Entity must provide an explanation of the reasons for the shortfall and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. In addition, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors addressing whether, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if necessary. These annual reporting requirements give effect to the “comply or explain” approach adopted by the Regulator in respect of the Corporate Governance Principles [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] and constitute the concrete annual reporting obligations applicable to the Listed Entity [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: the "comply or explain" approach adopted by the Regulator

answer_spans.text: Annual reporting on compliance.

question: If a Listed Entity does not fully follow the APP 4 best practice standards, what must it say in its annual financial report to match the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach to the Corporate Governance Principles, and what must Directors add?
expected_answer: To align with the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach for the Corporate Governance Principles, a Listed Entity must use its annual financial report to clearly disclose both its level of adoption and, where relevant, its explanations. The report must state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted by the Listed Entity. If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the Listed Entity must explain why full adoption did not occur and also describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. Beyond the entity’s own explanation, the annual financial report must also include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if necessary. This annual reporting structure is the practical expression of the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] and is required content for the Listed Entity’s annual financial report [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

question: For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, how should an Authorised Person assess whether information derived from market-user research or analysis can still satisfy the “not generally available” limb of Inside Information, and what additional elements must be met for it to qualify as Inside Information?
expected_answer: Inside Information in this context requires a cumulative assessment. Under the definition, the information must be of a precise nature, must not be generally available, must relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments (or to the instruments themselves, including Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities), and must be such that, if it were generally available, it would likely have a significant effect on price [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. The Source clarifies how to treat the “generally available” concept: information is only Inside Information if it is not generally available and has not been made available to the public, and information that can be obtained by research or analysis conducted by, or on behalf of, users of a market is to be regarded as generally available to those users [#SRC:5107d7d4-642e-466e-a4c5-17377a88b6af]. Accordingly, where the relevant market users could obtain the information through such research or analysis, it should be treated as generally available to them, meaning it would fail the “not generally available” condition even if it has not been publicly disseminated. Only if the information remains not generally available (and the other definitional criteria are met) can it qualify as Inside Information.

That means if market users could get the information through such research or analysis, it is treated as generally available to them, so it would not meet the “not generally available” requirement. Separately, the Target definition says that, for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information must be information of a precise nature that is not generally available, that relates directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers (or to the instruments themselves), and that would likely have a significant effect on price if it were generally available [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. So research-derived information only qualifies if it is not treated as generally available and also meets the relation and price-effect tests.

question: When the Customer is not a Natural Person, to what extent may the Customer and the Third Party Provider contractually allocate or waive the default regime on charging for Customer-requested information, including by agreeing in writing that the relevant charging rules do not apply while still permitting charges for information that is outside the standard information package or delivery method?
expected_answer: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider are permitted to agree in writing that the rules governing charges for information do not apply, meaning they can contract out of the default charging framework for information-related obligations identified in the Source [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Separately, under the Target, the Third Party Provider and the Customer may agree on charges for information provided at the Customer’s request when that information falls outside the baseline information regime—specifically where it is additional to what must be provided or made available, provided more frequently than specified, or transmitted using a communication method other than those specified in the Governing Contract [#TGT:409ed483-98f6-44e5-812d-17a33796c543]. Read together, the parties have two layers of permission: (i) a general ability (for non-Natural Person Customers) to disapply the charging rules by written agreement, and (ii) an express ability to agree charges for certain categories of extra or differently delivered information requested by the Customer. Any such arrangement should be documented in writing to align with the Source’s condition for disapplying the charging rules and to evidence the agreed charging basis for the Target’s permitted charge categories.

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to switch off the usual rules on charges for information, and still agree to charge for extra information the Customer asks for (or for more frequent or differently delivered information)?
expected_answer: Yes, but the permissions operate in slightly different ways and should be aligned. Under the Source, where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that the rules dealing with charges for information do not apply, which allows them to contract out of that default rule set by written agreement [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Under the Target, the Third Party Provider and the Customer may also agree on charges for information provided at the Customer’s request when the information is outside the standard information requirements—such as information that is additional, provided more frequently, or sent using a different communication method than the Governing Contract specifies [#TGT:409ed483-98f6-44e5-812d-17a33796c543]. Putting both together: if the Customer is not a Natural Person, the parties can (a) agree in writing not to apply the default charging rules at all, and/or (b) even within a charging framework, agree specific charges for the kinds of “extra” or differently delivered information described in the Target. The safest approach is to record clearly, in writing, whether the default charging rules are disapplied and what charges apply to each permitted information category.

question: How should a firm determine whether a communication can be treated as an Exempt Communication because it is prescribed by the Regulator, and therefore falls outside the defined scope of an Offer of Securities and is not caught by the general prohibition?
expected_answer: A firm should start by assessing whether the communication would otherwise meet the definition of an Offer of Securities—i.e., whether it is a communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information on the terms of the offer and the securities offered in a way that enables an investor to decide to buy or subscribe. If it meets that threshold, the firm must then evaluate whether it is excluded from that definition, including where it is “any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication” [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. The Source clarifies that the Regulator has the power to prescribe certain communications to be Exempt Communications and that, once prescribed, such communications are not subject to the relevant prohibition because they fall outside the definition of an Offer of Securities [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f]. Accordingly, the compliance conclusion depends on both (i) whether the communication would otherwise be an Offer of Securities under the definition and (ii) whether it is within the category the Regulator has prescribed as exempt in Rules.

answer_spans.text: General prohibitions and definitions.

question: When is a message to someone about securities not treated as an Offer of Securities because it is an exempt communication, and what role does the Regulator play in making it exempt?
expected_answer: First decide if the message is an Offer of Securities under the definition: it must be a communication (any form or means) that gives information on the terms of the offer and the securities offered, in a way that lets an investor decide to buy or subscribe [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. If it fits that description, check whether it is excluded from the definition. One exclusion is “any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication” [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. The Source explains how that exclusion is triggered in practice: the Regulator has the power to prescribe certain communications to be Exempt Communications, and once a communication is prescribed as exempt it is not subject to the general prohibition because it falls outside the definition of an Offer of Securities [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f]. So, a message becomes “not an Offer” for these purposes when it is the kind of communication the Regulator has prescribed as exempt in Rules, even if it otherwise looks like an offer communication.

question: When an MTF Operator or OTF Operator applies the MIR rulebook requirements that it must follow by treating references to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange as references to itself, how must it interpret any MIR/COBS cross-references that use the terms “Investment(s)” or “Financial Instrument(s)” in the context of COBS Chapter 8—specifically, what substitutions must be made and how does that affect the scope of the obligations it must comply with?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is an MTF Operator or an OTF Operator must comply with the specified MIR rulebook requirements that apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, but it must do so by reading references to those entities in the relevant rules as references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator itself [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094]. Where those obligations (including any incorporated material) interact with COBS Chapter 8 terminology for the purposes identified in the SOURCE, the firm must apply the mandated interpretive substitutions: any reference to “Investment” or “Investments” is to be read as a reference to “Spot Commodity” or “Spot Commodities,” and any reference to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated via COBS Rule 8.2.1) is to be read as a reference to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” as applicable [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]. Practically, this means the MTF Operator or OTF Operator should scope and implement its required MIR compliance (e.g., systems and controls, transparency, and market abuse-related requirements) on the basis that the relevant COBS Chapter 8 concepts map to spot commodities and accepted spot commodities, rather than investments or financial instruments, when those terms arise in the specified interpretive context.

So, when the firm is implementing the MIR obligations it must follow, and the relevant COBS Chapter 8 context is engaged for those purposes, it should treat the obligations as applying to spot commodities and accepted spot commodities rather than to investments or financial instruments.

question: How must a VC Manager evidence that it can meet its liabilities as they fall due, and how does that obligation align with the requirement on an Authorised Person to maintain and demonstrate adequate resources (including financial, systems, and human resources) to conduct and manage its affairs?
expected_answer: A VC Manager must be able to show, on an ongoing basis, that it can meet its liabilities as they fall due and that it has adequate financial resources to manage its affairs prudently and soundly [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d]. In parallel, an Authorised Person must not only maintain adequate resources but also be able to demonstrate the existence of those resources to conduct and manage its affairs, with the concept of “resources” expressly encompassing adequate financial resources, adequate system resources, and adequate and competent human resources [#TGT:68b818e2-d47f-4969-a001-20a713c5f104]. Read together, the liability-meeting requirement for the VC Manager is a specific expression of the broader resources principle: the VC Manager’s demonstration should cover its capacity to pay obligations when due and the sufficiency of its financial position, while also supporting (where applicable) the wider expectation that the firm can evidence the overall adequacy of its resources for running the business, including operational systems and staffing competence. This framing is particularly important given that the VC Manager may be exempt from certain ongoing capital minima but remains subject to these demonstration-based obligations [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] and the general resources principle [#TGT:68b818e2-d47f-4969-a001-20a713c5f104].

answer_spans.text: Principle 4   Resources: An Authorised Person must maintain and be able to demonstrate the existence of adequate resources to conduct and manage its affairs

expected_answer: Even where a VC Manager is not required to maintain certain ongoing capital minima, it must still demonstrate that it can meet its liabilities as they fall due and that it has adequate financial resources to manage its affairs prudently and soundly [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d]. This obligation focuses on solvency and prudent financial management, requiring the VC Manager to be able to evidence that it can satisfy obligations when due and that its financial resources are sufficient for sound operation. The same overall compliance posture is reinforced by the broader requirement that an Authorised Person must maintain and be able to demonstrate the existence of adequate resources to conduct and manage its affairs, explicitly including adequate financial resources, adequate system resources, and adequate and competent human resources [#TGT:68b818e2-d47f-4969-a001-20a713c5f104]. Accordingly, the VC Manager’s demonstration of liability coverage should be understood as part of a wider expectation to evidence resource adequacy, not limited to balance-sheet strength but also extending to the operational and staffing capacity needed to run the business effectively. The combined effect is that exemption from particular capital metrics does not remove the need to substantiate ongoing financial resilience and overall resource sufficiency [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] in line with the resources principle [#TGT:68b818e2-d47f-4969-a001-20a713c5f104].

question: For an Authorised Person, what is prohibited regarding the aggregate level of non-exempt Large Exposures, and how must the firm ensure its overall Large Exposures remain within the applicable 800% limit when considering the relevant capital base and funding sources?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from allowing the sum of its non-exempt Large Exposures to exceed 800% of its Capital Resources where the Exposures are funded by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:db3cd227-c8cd-4596-93f0-8f5f3857fd67]. In parallel, the firm has an affirmative duty to manage and monitor its Large Exposures so that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1 [#SRC:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697]. Read together, this means the Authorised Person must implement controls that prevent any breach of the 800% ceiling under both measures: (i) a prohibition focused on non-exempt Large Exposures measured against Capital Resources for exposures funded by Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs, and (ii) an overarching obligation to ensure the total Large Exposures remain within 800% of Tier 1. Compliance therefore requires tracking the aggregate Large Exposures population, identifying which exposures are non-exempt and within the specified funding scope, and ensuring both aggregate calculations remain below the stated threshold.

expected_answer: An Authorised Person must not let the sum of its non-exempt Large Exposures go above 800% of its Capital Resources when those Exposures are funded by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:db3cd227-c8cd-4596-93f0-8f5f3857fd67]. At the same time, it must ensure that the overall sum of its Large Exposures stays within an 800% limit measured against its Tier 1 [#SRC:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697]. Putting these together, the firm needs to manage Large Exposures in a way that avoids a breach under either framing: the specific prohibition for non-exempt exposures in the stated funding category (measured against Capital Resources) and the broader requirement to keep total Large Exposures under the Tier 1-based cap. Practically, the Authorised Person should calculate the aggregate Large Exposures total, separately identify the non-exempt subset that falls within the funding condition, and check both totals against the 800% threshold so it does not exceed the limit in either case.

question: When a Relevant Person maintains required CDD, customer relationship, transaction reconstruction, and suspicious activity records but keeps them outside the ADGM, what must it do to ensure those records can be produced without delay for regulatory inspection, and how does this obligation apply across the full set of records it is required to retain for the minimum retention period?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person must first ensure it is maintaining the full set of required records where relevant, including documents and information gathered for initial and ongoing CDD or due diligence on business partners, customer business relationship records (such as correspondence, transaction records sufficient to reconstruct individual transactions, and internal findings/analysis for unusual or suspicious matters), internal suspicious activity notifications to its MLRO, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting materials, relevant communications with the FIU, and any other matters expressly required to be recorded, and it must retain these for at least six years based on the latest of the specified trigger events [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. Where the records referred to are kept outside the ADGM, the Relevant Person must take reasonable steps to ensure the records are held in a manner consistent with the Rules, ensure they are easily accessible to the Relevant Person, and—critically—upon request by the Regulator, ensure the records are immediately available for inspection [#SRC:1c5a2e03-760c-4263-88bd-eb100e0368b4]. Practically, this means the offsite storage arrangement must support rapid retrieval and presentation of any of the retained record categories throughout the retention period.

debug_context.semantic_hook: ensure that the records are immediately available for inspection

question: If a Relevant Person keeps its required AML records outside the ADGM, what does it have to do so that the Regulator can inspect them right away, and which kinds of records does this cover?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person must keep, where relevant, a defined set of AML-related records, including CDD and due diligence documents and information, customer business relationship records (such as business correspondence, transaction records that allow transactions to be reconstructed, and internal findings/analysis for unusual or suspicious activity), internal suspicious activity notifications to its MLRO, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting documents and information, relevant communications with the FIU, specified documents, and any other matters it is expressly required to record, and it must retain them for at least six years based on the latest applicable event [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. If the records referred to are kept outside the ADGM, the Relevant Person must take reasonable steps to ensure they are held consistently with the Rules and are easily accessible to the Relevant Person, and it must also ensure that, when the Regulator asks, the records are immediately available for inspection [#SRC:1c5a2e03-760c-4263-88bd-eb100e0368b4]. This applies across the record types it is required to maintain and throughout the required retention period, so the storage and retrieval process must support immediate production on request.

question: When the Financial Services Regulatory Authority issues Guidance intended to be read alongside FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT), how should an Authorised Person determine what qualifies as “Guidance” for these purposes, including whether it covers both rule notations and material not incorporated into the Rules, and what is its binding effect?
expected_answer: For the purposes of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority’s framework, “Guidance” should be understood by combining the issuance context with the definitional criteria. The SOURCE establishes that the Guidance is issued by the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (“FSRA”) under FSMR and is intended to be read together with FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT), which frames its scope as interpretive material accompanying those instruments [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f]. The TARGET then defines what qualifies as “Guidance” and its legal character: it is indicative and non binding, and it may take two forms—(i) Guidance made and issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules, and (ii) any Guidance issued by the Regulator that has not been incorporated into the Rules [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd]. Read together, an Authorised Person should treat both embedded rule-notation guidance and separate, non-incorporated guidance issued by the Regulator as falling within the same category, while recognising that, regardless of form, it does not itself impose binding requirements but is meant to be used alongside FSMR and MKT.

expected_answer: In this setting, you identify “Guidance” by looking at both why it is issued and how it is defined. The SOURCE explains that the Guidance is issued by the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (“FSRA”) under FSMR and should be read together with FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT), so it is positioned as material that accompanies and supports those instruments rather than standing alone [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f]. The TARGET then clarifies what counts as “Guidance” and what it does: it is indicative and non binding, and it can include (a) Guidance made and issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules and (b) Guidance issued by the Regulator that has not been incorporated into the Rules [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd]. Putting these together, you should treat both types—notations attached to the Rules and separate guidance outside the Rules—as “Guidance” for reading alongside FSMR and MKT, but you should not treat it as creating binding obligations because it is expressly described as non binding.
