question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on a MTF and plans to make an offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what makes that offer an “Exempt Offer,” and can the Issuer run it at the same time as another Exempt Offer (and are there any limits on which Exempt Offer circumstances can be combined)?
expected_answer: An Offer is an Exempt Offer when it fits within one of the circumstances prescribed by the Regulator. One such circumstance (excluding Debentures and Sukuk) is an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility; meeting those elements is what makes the offer fall within the Exempt Offer definition for that pathway [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc]. In the specific context of an Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF, the described permission is that the Issuer may utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more Exempt Offer circumstances, but there is a stated carve-out: one particular circumstance is excluded from being relied on in that combined way [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. The same permission also indicates that simultaneous Exempt Offers are contemplated, such as making an Exempt Offer to up to 200 non-Professional Clients while also making an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, which aligns with the separate prescribed circumstance for offers directed only at Professional Clients [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] and [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].

question: Where an Authorised Person both operates as a Cell Company and holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how must the Cell-based component be calculated?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in this combined position must account for two separate annual supervision fee obligations payable to the Regulator, each triggered by different characteristics of the Authorised Person’s business. First, because the Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee comprised of a fixed amount for the Cell Company plus a variable amount that scales with the number of Cells (i.e., a base $8,000 for the Cell Company and $1,000 for each Cell). This Cell Company amount is expressly described as an “additional” annual supervision fee and therefore must be calculated by identifying the Cell Company status and counting the Cells to determine the per-Cell component [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Second, because the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must also pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both Regulated Activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must pay to the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee

answer_spans.text: Captive Insurers and Insurance Special Purpose Vehicles.

question: If an Authorised Person is a Cell Company and also does insurance business as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what yearly fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how do Cells affect the amount?
expected_answer: In that situation, the Authorised Person has two fee obligations that apply for different reasons and both are payable to the Regulator. Because it operates as a Cell Company, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee made up of two parts: a fixed $8,000 for the Cell Company itself, plus $1,000 for each Cell. That means the total Cell Company-related amount increases as the number of Cells increases, so the Authorised Person must determine how many Cells it has in order to calculate the per-Cell portion correctly [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Separately, if the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000, and that $5,000 applies for either or both of those Regulated Activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].

question: When a person is responding to a requirement under this Part/Part 17, what conduct is prohibited regarding supplying information that is materially false or misleading, and how does the prohibition treat knowing versus reckless provision in purported compliance?
expected_answer: Both passages prohibit a person from supplying information that is false or misleading in a material particular when doing so in purported compliance with a regulatory requirement. Under the TARGET, the prohibition applies where a person either provides information he knows is materially false or misleading, or recklessly provides materially false or misleading information, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under the Part [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96]. The SOURCE aligns with this by characterising deliberate or reckless provision of materially false or misleading information in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement as non-compliance that constitutes a contravention, reinforcing that both intentional (deliberate/knowing) and reckless states of mind are captured [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]. Read together, the prohibited conduct is not limited to outright deception; it also includes situations where the person proceeds with disregard as to whether the information is materially accurate. The common trigger is that the information is provided as if to satisfy the relevant requirement, even though it is materially false or misleading.

question: If a person is trying to comply with a requirement under this Part (or a Part 17 requirement), what must they not do if the information they give is materially false or misleading, and does it matter whether they knew it was wrong or were just reckless?
expected_answer: A person must not give information that is false or misleading in a material particular when they are presenting it as part of complying with a requirement. The TARGET states that, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under the Part, a person is prohibited from providing information they know is materially false or misleading, and is also prohibited from recklessly providing materially false or misleading information [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96]. The SOURCE mirrors this approach in the Part 17 context by treating deliberate or reckless provision of materially false or misleading information in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement as non-compliance that amounts to a contravention [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]. Taken together, it matters in the sense that both mental states are covered: the rule applies whether the person knowingly supplies materially wrong information or supplies it while being reckless about its truth or accuracy, so long as it is given as if to meet the requirement.

question: When an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 experiences a drop in its Capital Resources to below the specified buffer relative to its Capital Requirement, what notifications must it make to the Regulator, how quickly must it act, and what additional formality is required beyond the initial notification?
expected_answer: For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the trigger event is its Capital Resources falling below 120% of its Capital Requirement. When that threshold is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately, reflecting the urgency of the obligation and the expectation that the Regulator is informed without delay once the shortfall occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. In addition to making the immediate notification, the Authorised Person must also confirm the notification in writing, meaning the communication is not complete with only an immediate alert and must be followed by a written confirmation to the Regulator [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. The combined requirements therefore impose both (i) a timing requirement (immediate notification upon the threshold breach) and (ii) a documentation/form requirement (written confirmation), each tied to the same capital-resources trigger and the same specified categories of Authorised Person.

debug_context.semantic_hook: must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 falls below the required Capital Resources level compared with its Capital Requirement, what must it do to tell the Regulator, and does it also need to follow up in writing?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 finds that its Capital Resources have fallen below 120% of its Capital Requirement, it has an immediate duty to notify the Regulator as soon as that condition occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. The obligation is not limited to a rapid initial alert: it must also confirm the notification in writing, so there is a required written follow-up (or written confirmation) to the Regulator after the immediate notice [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. In practical terms, the rule sets a clear trigger (Capital Resources below the 120% threshold), identifies exactly who it applies to (Authorised Persons in Categories 3B, 3C or 4), and requires two linked actions: immediate notification and written confirmation. Both steps are mandatory once the threshold is crossed, and both are directed to the Regulator.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange is setting and applying its Business Rules to ensure that Units in a collective investment fund can be traded fairly, orderly and efficiently, which specific assessment factors must it take into account for open-ended versus closed-ended funds as part of its admission-to-trading framework?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure, through its Business Rules, that Financial Instruments it admits to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and this obligation should be operationalised by applying the specified assessment procedure for Units in collective investment funds [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. In practice, when assessing Units, it must differentiate between open-ended and closed-ended structures and take into account the prescribed aspects. For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund, the Recognised Investment Exchange must consider: (1) how the Units are distributed to the public; (2) whether appropriate market-making arrangements exist, or alternatively whether the Fund Manager provides appropriate arrangements for investors to redeem the Units; and (3) whether the value of the units is sufficiently transparent to investors via periodic publication of the net asset value [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131]. For a closed-ended Investment Fund, it must consider: (1) distribution of Units to the public; and (2) whether value transparency is achieved either through publication of information on the Fund’s investment strategy or through periodic publication of a net asset value [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131].

debug_context.semantic_hook: take the following aspects into account

answer_spans.text: (b)	The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is admitting Units in a collective investment fund to trading, what must it check to support its Business Rules requirement that the Units can trade fairly and efficiently, and how do the checks differ for open-ended and closed-ended funds?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must have Business Rules that ensure any Financial Instruments it admits to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and it should support that requirement by following the stated assessment approach for Units in collective investment funds [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. When it assesses Units, it must look at different factors depending on whether the fund is open-ended or closed-ended. For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund, it must take into account: how widely and in what way the Units are distributed to the public; whether there are appropriate market-making arrangements or, if not, whether the Fund Manager provides appropriate alternative arrangements for investors to redeem the Units; and whether investors can see the value of the units clearly through periodic publication of the net asset value [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131]. For a closed-ended Investment Fund, it must consider the public distribution of the Units and whether value transparency is provided either by publishing information on the Fund’s investment strategy or by periodically publishing a net asset value [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131].

debug_context.semantic_hook: take the following aspects into account

answer_spans.text: (b)	The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and is therefore subject to the obligation to publish a Prospectus, in what circumstances may the Regulator publish information itself, and what is the trigger for that power?
expected_answer: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer is subject to the requirements applicable to Offers of Securities, which include an obligation to publish a Prospectus. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] In the related Prospectus regime, the Regulator is permitted to step in only if there is a failure by the person making a Prospectus Offer to publish information that the person is required to publish by or under the Regulations. In that event, the Regulator may publish the missing required information, and it must do so in the manner prescribed in the Rules. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] Read together, the obligation side establishes that a Prospectus publication duty can arise for an Issuer making a public Offer of Securities in or from ADGM, while the permission side clarifies the enforcement backstop: the Regulator’s publication power is triggered by non-publication of required information by the Prospectus Offer maker, and the Regulator’s publication is constrained to the prescribed manner.

Where a person making a Prospectus Offer fails to publish any information which that person is required to publish by or under these Regulations, the Regulator may publish such info

question: If an Issuer is making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and must publish a Prospectus, what can the Regulator do if the person making the Prospectus Offer does not publish required information?
expected_answer: An Issuer that wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM is subject to the requirements for Offers of Securities, and those requirements include an obligation to publish a Prospectus. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus context, the person making a Prospectus Offer fails to publish any information that the person is required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator is allowed to publish that information instead. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The key condition is the failure to publish required information; the Regulator’s action is not automatic for every Prospectus Offer, but is a response to non-compliance with a publication requirement. When the Regulator publishes, it must do so in the manner prescribed in the Rules. Taken together, this means the Prospectus publication obligation applies to the relevant securities offer, and the Regulator has a specific back-up power to ensure required information is made public if the Prospectus Offer maker does not publish it as required.

question: Where an Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, what annual supervision fee must it pay to the Regulator, and how does the amount differ between (i) each Regulated Activity and (ii) Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility as the only Regulated Activity?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that has a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay an annual supervision fee to the Regulator, and this payment is expressly stated to be in addition to the supervision fees otherwise due for each Regulated Activity the Authorised Person undertakes [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]. The applicable annual supervision fee amount depends on the nature and scope of the Regulated Activity: the fee is $15,000 for each Regulated Activity, but it is $60,000 where the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]. The Source aligns the same fee levels to annual supervision fees for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, and it also identifies the $60,000 level in the specific context of seeking to operate an MTF in relation to Virtual Assets [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0]. Read together, the pair establishes both the obligation to pay to the Regulator and the fee schedule that applies to Virtual Asset-related permissions and activities [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8].

debug_context.semantic_hook: annual supervision fees for an Authorised Person conducting

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay to the Regulator, in addition to the supervision fees due in respect of each Regulated Act

expected_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay an annual supervision fee to the Regulator, and this fee is payable in addition to the supervision fees that are due for each Regulated Activity the Authorised Person undertakes [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]. The Source sets the same annual supervision fee levels for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, and it also highlights that the higher $60,000 level is tied to seeking to operate an MTF in relation to Virtual Assets [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0]. question: When an Applicant must demonstrate compliance with the audited accounts publication/filing requirement, under what conditions may the Regulator modify or waive that requirement, and how does the investor-information test interact with the minimum prior period coverage of three years (or a shorter period the Regulator accepts)?
expected_answer: An Applicant is required to have published or filed audited accounts that meet specified criteria, including that they cover a prior period of three years, unless a shorter period is acceptable to the Regulator, and that they are consolidated, prepared under acceptable standards, and audited under IAASB or other acceptable auditing standards [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. In parallel, the Regulator has discretion to modify or waive the relevant requirement if it is satisfied that doing so is desirable in the interests of investors and that investors have the necessary information available to arrive at an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which admission to the Official List is sought [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca]. Read together, the Applicant’s baseline obligation is to provide audited financial statements meeting the three years coverage benchmark (or an accepted shorter period), but the Regulator’s ability to modify or waive hinges on an investor-protection assessment: the Regulator must be satisfied both that the modification/waiver serves investors’ interests and that investors still have sufficient information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares.

answer_spans.text: three years

question: If an Applicant has not published or filed audited accounts covering three years, what must it normally do, and when can the Regulator change or waive that requirement based on whether investors still have enough information to judge the Issuer and the Shares?
expected_answer: Normally, an Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts that satisfy the audited financial statements requirements, including that the accounts cover a prior period of three years (or a shorter period that the Regulator accepts), are consolidated for the Applicant and any subsidiary undertakings, are prepared under IFRS or other acceptable standards, and are audited and reported on under IAASB or other acceptable auditing standards [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. However, the Regulator is permitted to modify or waive the relevant requirement if it is satisfied that doing so is desirable in the interests of investors and that investors have the necessary information available to reach an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which admission to the Official List is sought [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca]. In practice, this means the three years benchmark is the default expectation for the Applicant’s audited accounts, but the Regulator can allow a different approach only where it concludes both that investor interests are served and that the overall information available to investors remains sufficient for an informed assessment of the Issuer and the Shares.

question: When determining which capital instruments must be identified for inclusion in an Authorised Person’s Available Stable Funding, how should the Authorised Person treat instruments that qualify as AT1 Capital, and what specific AT1 components must be recognised for that purpose?
expected_answer: In identifying capital instruments to be included in its Available Stable Funding, an Authorised Person must perform an eligibility-based assessment of its capital elements and then identify the instruments that are to be included on that basis [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. Where the instruments under review are intended to be treated as AT1 Capital, the Authorised Person should apply the AT1 Capital definition to determine what constitutes that capital element: AT1 Capital is the sum of (i) capital instruments that meet the relevant eligibility criteria and (ii) the share premium accounts related to those instruments [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. Accordingly, for ASF identification purposes, the Authorised Person should ensure it captures not only the qualifying AT1 capital instruments themselves but also any associated share premium accounts that are part of AT1 Capital, while still conducting the broader ASF eligibility review across the specified capital-element requirements and applying any stated exclusions when identifying instruments for inclusion [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1].

AT1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements:
(a)	capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.

question: For an Authorised Person working out which capital instruments to include in Available Stable Funding, what does AT1 Capital include, and how does that definition affect what the Authorised Person must identify?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must identify the capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by looking at which capital elements meet the stated eligibility requirements and then selecting the instruments for inclusion on that basis [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. If the Authorised Person is considering instruments that fall within AT1 Capital, the AT1 definition clarifies what must be counted as that capital element: AT1 Capital is made up of two components—capital instruments that meet the applicable eligibility criteria and the share premium accounts related to those instruments [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. This means that, when identifying what to include for ASF purposes, the Authorised Person should not stop at listing only the qualifying AT1 instruments; it should also recognise any related share premium accounts as part of the AT1 Capital element being assessed, while continuing to apply the ASF identification approach that is based on the relevant eligibility requirements and any exclusions specified for instruments being included [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1].

AT1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements:
(a)	capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.

question: When an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to make an Exempt Offer to a limited number of Persons who are not Professional Clients, how is the relevant Exempt Offer circumstance defined, and to what extent may the Issuer also rely on additional Exempt Offer circumstances at the same time?
expected_answer: An Offer will qualify as an Exempt Offer where it falls within a prescribed circumstance set by the Regulator, including the circumstance that (other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk) an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. This definition establishes the key triggers: the ADGM nexus, the 200-person cap, the offeree status, and the platform/MTF context. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Where the Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in the specific circumstance described in the SOURCE, the Issuer is permitted to utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within the Exempt Offer circumstances list, except for the excluded circumstance referenced in the SOURCE. In practice, this permits a simultaneous structure combining the limited non-Professional Client limb with another qualifying limb, such as an Offer made only to Professional Clients, alongside the MTF admission context. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: For an Issuer planning a simultaneous Exempt Offer in connection with admission of Securities to trading on an MTF, what criteria determine whether the non-Professional Client tranche is an Exempt Offer, and what permission exists to combine that tranche with an additional Exempt Offer tranche aimed at Professional Clients?
expected_answer: The non-Professional Client tranche is an Exempt Offer only if it fits within a prescribed circumstance identified by the Regulator, including the circumstance (excluding Debentures and Sukuk) where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. These elements collectively define the qualifying conditions for that tranche: the ADGM location nexus, the numerical limit, the status of offerees, and the MTF/Private Financing Platform context. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the MTF admission scenario described in the SOURCE, the Issuer may also utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances from the same set, subject to the stated exception. This permission supports a combined approach, such as running the capped tranche to up to 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients while simultaneously making an Offer directed at only Professional Clients without a numerical cap, provided each tranche independently meets its relevant Exempt Offer circumstance. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: If an Issuer wants to admit its Securities to trading on an MTF and make an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what makes that offer an “Exempt Offer,” and can the Issuer also run another Exempt Offer at the same time?
expected_answer: An Offer is an Exempt Offer only if it matches one of the circumstances prescribed by the Regulator. One of those circumstances covers (other than Debentures and Sukuk) an Offer in or from the ADGM that is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. That definition sets the conditions you must check: the ADGM connection, the 200-person limit, who the offerees are, and the use of a Private Financing Platform or an MTF. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the specific MTF admission situation described in the SOURCE, the Issuer is permitted to utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances from the same list, except for the one excluded in the SOURCE. This means the Issuer can structure a simultaneous offering, combining the capped tranche to non-Professional Clients with another tranche that separately qualifies—such as an Offer made only to Professional Clients—so long as each tranche meets its own Exempt Offer conditions. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: In an MTF admission deal, how do you tell whether the “up to 200 non-Professional Clients” part is an Exempt Offer, and what does the rule allow the Issuer to add alongside it?
expected_answer: To decide whether the “up to 200 non-Professional Clients” part is an Exempt Offer, you must match it to the Regulator’s prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances. The relevant circumstance applies (other than for Debentures and Sukuk) where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. So the key checks are: ADGM nexus, the 200-person cap, the offeree categories, and the platform/MTF condition. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Where the Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in the circumstance described in the SOURCE, the Issuer may also utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances from the same set, with the stated exception. Practically, the Issuer can add a second Exempt Offer tranche at the same time, such as an Offer directed only at Professional Clients, while keeping the non-Professional Client tranche within the capped conditions. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: When a material change occurs in information a PFP Operator has published, what must the PFP Operator do to update that information and notify PFP Clients, and how must the PFP Operator document those disclosures and related due diligence records over time?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator must take two linked sets of actions. First, where information it has published is subject to a material change, the PFP Operator must update the published information to reflect that change and must provide notice of the material change to PFP Clients within a reasonable timeframe following the change [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. Second, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep a record for a minimum of six years of all disclosures made in accordance with the relevant disclosure requirements, which would include the disclosures associated with publishing and updating information and providing notice to PFP Clients [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. In addition, the PFP Operator must retain for at least six years the documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, as well as the due diligence undertaken under the applicable due diligence requirement [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. Together, these obligations require timely updating and notification, supported by long-term recordkeeping of the disclosures, related transaction documentation, and due diligence.

debug_context.semantic_hook: for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record

answer_spans.text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the information published in accordance with Rule 18

question: How should a PFP Operator align its obligation to provide timely notice to PFP Clients of material changes in published information with its obligation to retain records of disclosures, transaction documentation, and due diligence for a defined minimum period?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator must operationally connect its change-management process with its record-retention process. On the change-management side, the PFP Operator must ensure that information it has published is updated to reflect material changes, and it must provide notice of such material change to PFP Clients within a reasonable timeframe following the change [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. On the retention side, the PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure requirements, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, and the due diligence undertaken under the applicable due diligence requirement [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. Practically, this means the PFP Operator should preserve evidence of the updated published information and the notice provided to PFP Clients as part of the disclosure record set, and ensure that any related communications or documents connected to the change (including those involving the Body Corporate and the PFP Prospect) are retained within the same six-year recordkeeping framework [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: If the published information changes in an important way, what does a PFP Operator have to do for PFP Clients, and what records must it keep for at least six years about those disclosures and related work?
expected_answer: If there is a material change to information a PFP Operator has published, the PFP Operator must update the published information so it reflects the material change, and it must give PFP Clients notice of that material change within a reasonable timeframe after the change happens [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. Alongside that timely update-and-notice duty, the PFP Operator must keep a clear audit trail for a minimum of six years. Specifically, it must maintain and keep a record of all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure requirements, which would capture the disclosures connected to publishing, updating, and notifying PFP Clients [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. It also must retain, for at least six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, plus the due diligence it undertook under the applicable due diligence requirement [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. In short: update and notify promptly, and keep the related disclosure, documentation, and due diligence records for the required minimum period.

question: What does a PFP Operator need to do after a material change to published information, and how long must it keep records of the disclosures and the due diligence and documents linked to PFP Client(s) and the PFP Prospect?
expected_answer: After a material change to information it has published, a PFP Operator must make sure the published information is updated to reflect the material change, and it must provide notice of that material change to PFP Clients within a reasonable timeframe following the change [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. At the same time, the PFP Operator must keep records that support what it published and communicated. For a minimum of six years, it must maintain and keep a record of all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure requirements, which would include disclosures tied to the published information and any updates and notices [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. It must also keep, for at least six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, and it must retain the due diligence it undertook under the applicable due diligence requirement [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. These duties work together: prompt updating and notification, backed by long-term recordkeeping.

question: When an Appointed auditor becomes aware of information suggesting a potentially significant contravention, loss of going-concern status, or an inability to give an unqualified accounts-related statement, what must the Appointed auditor communicate to the Regulator, and how does this interact with the broader duty on each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors to disclose matters indicating a breach or likely breach or non-compliance and to maintain notification systems and procedures?
expected_answer: An Appointed auditor must communicate to the Regulator information on, or the auditor’s opinion on, the relevant matters when the auditor reasonably believes there is or may have been a contravention applicable to the person concerned that may be materially significant to the Regulator’s exercise of powers; when the information or opinion may be materially significant to whether the person concerned satisfies and will continue to satisfy the Threshold Conditions (or, for a Recognised Body, the Recognition Requirements); when the person concerned is not, may not be, or may cease to be a going concern; or when the auditor is precluded from stating in the auditor’s report that the annual accounts or other required financial reports have been properly prepared, conform with applicable Rules, or include required statements of facts. This auditor-to-Regulator reporting obligation sits alongside the broader requirement that each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors disclose to the Regulator any matter indicating a breach or likely breach, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules, and that each Authorised Person and Recognised Body establish and implement systems and procedures enabling compliance with those notification requirements, including by its Auditors [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b].

question: If an Appointed auditor thinks something may be seriously wrong (like a likely contravention, a going-concern problem, or they cannot make a clean statement about the accounts), what must they tell the Regulator, and what do the Authorised Person and Recognised Body have to put in place so their Auditors can meet the wider disclosure and notification duties?
expected_answer: The Appointed auditor must communicate to the Regulator the information they have, or their opinion, about the relevant matters when they reasonably believe a contravention affecting the person concerned exists or may have existed and could be materially significant to the Regulator’s decision to use its powers; when the information or opinion could be materially significant to whether the person concerned meets and will continue to meet the Threshold Conditions (or, for a Recognised Body, the Recognition Requirements); when the person concerned is not, may not be, or may stop being a going concern; or when the auditor cannot state in their report that the annual accounts or other required financial reports were properly prepared, conform with applicable Rules, or include required statements of facts. In parallel, each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors must disclose to the Regulator any matter that may indicate a breach or likely breach, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules. To support this, each Authorised Person and Recognised Body must establish and implement systems and procedures that enable compliance with these notification requirements, including compliance by its Auditors [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b].

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain charging-related rules do not apply. In that scenario, is the Third Party Provider still prohibited from charging under a Framework Contract for providing or making available information that is required to be provided or made available under the relevant provisions, and how should the parties reconcile the written agreement with that prohibition?
expected_answer: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider are permitted to agree in writing that specified rules, including those dealing with charges for information, do not apply between them [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, the charging position must still be assessed against the separate prohibition that, under a Framework Contract, a Third Party Provider may not charge for providing or making available information that is required to be provided or made available under the relevant provisions [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]. Practically, this means the parties’ written agreement can only operate within the scope of what the rules allow them to disapply; it does not convert required information into chargeable information. Accordingly, even where the parties have agreed that the charging-related rules do not apply, the Third Party Provider should treat information that is required to be provided or made available as non-chargeable, and ensure any fees relate only to items not captured by the requirement to provide or make available that information. This approach aligns the permitted contractual flexibility with the stated prohibition.

debug_context.semantic_hook: Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing

answer_spans.text: A Third Party Provider may not charge for providing or making available information which is required to be provided or made available under the provisions of Section 20

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider can agree in writing that some rules about charges for information do not apply. Even with that written agreement, can the Third Party Provider charge for information it is required to provide or make available under the Framework Contract?
expected_answer: When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider are allowed to agree in writing that certain listed rules do not apply, including the rules described as covering charges for information [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. At the same time, there is a clear prohibition under a Framework Contract: a Third Party Provider may not charge for providing or making available information that is required to be provided or made available under the relevant provisions [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]. Read together, the written agreement does not create a general right to charge for required information. Instead, the Third Party Provider should assume that any information it is required to provide or make available remains non-chargeable, regardless of the parties’ agreement to disapply certain rules. The written agreement may affect whether particular charging-related rules apply between the parties, but it should not be used to justify charging for information that the Third Party Provider is required to provide or make available under the Framework Contract.

question: For purposes of the obligation to calculate NSFR at an appropriate frequency and also when changes to Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding could materially affect NSFR, which Authorised Person categories are within scope of that expectation, and who is outside it?
expected_answer: The expectation to calculate NSFR with an appropriate frequency—so the firm can monitor its ongoing satisfaction of the NSFR requirement at all times—and to perform additional calculations when the firm believes a change to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding may materially change its NSFR, applies only where the entity is an Authorised Person that falls within the categories covered by the relevant Section. Specifically, the scope limitation is that the Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. Accordingly, an Authorised Person in any of those categories should implement a process to calculate its NSFR at a frequency that enables continuous monitoring and to trigger additional calculations when it believes ASF or RSF has changed in a way that might materially affect NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. Conversely, an Authorised Person not in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 is outside the stated scope of this Section and therefore is not captured by this particular expectation as framed here [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

debug_context.semantic_hook: calculate its NSFR with appropriate frequency

answer_spans.text: This Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5.

question: When setting the frequency for NSFR calculations and deciding whether a perceived change in Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding requires an additional NSFR calculation, which Authorised Persons must apply this approach based on the Section’s stated scope?
expected_answer: In determining how often to calculate NSFR and when to run additional calculations due to perceived changes in Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding, the key applicability boundary is the Section’s scope. The Section is stated to apply to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. For an Authorised Person within those categories, the approach is that it should calculate its NSFR with an appropriate frequency to ensure it can monitor satisfaction of the NSFR requirement at all times, and it should also calculate NSFR additionally where it believes a change has happened to its ASF or RSF that might result in a material change to the level of its NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. This means the frequency is not fixed in the text; rather, it must be sufficient for continuous monitoring, with an event-driven trigger tied to the firm’s belief that ASF or RSF has changed in a way that could materially affect NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. Authorised Persons outside Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5 are not within the Section’s stated scope [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

debug_context.semantic_hook: calculate its NSFR with appropriate frequency

answer_spans.text: This Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5.

question: If an Authorised Person needs to work out its NSFR often enough to keep track of compliance and also re-calculate when it thinks Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding has changed in a way that could materially move NSFR, which categories of Authorised Person does this apply to?
expected_answer: This expectation applies only to the Authorised Persons that fall within the Section’s stated scope. The scope statement is that the Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. For an Authorised Person in one of those categories, it should calculate its NSFR with an appropriate frequency so that it can monitor, at all times, whether it is satisfying the NSFR requirement, and it should also do an additional NSFR calculation where it believes a change has happened to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding that might cause a material change in its NSFR level [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. In other words, the text sets both a regular monitoring expectation (the frequency must be “appropriate” to allow continuous monitoring) and a specific trigger for extra calculations (the firm’s belief that ASF or RSF has changed in a way that could materially affect NSFR) [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. If an Authorised Person is not in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, it is outside this Section’s scope [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

question: Who is covered by the rule that says an Authorised Person should calculate NSFR regularly and also when it thinks a change to Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding could materially change NSFR?
expected_answer: Coverage depends on the Section’s scope and the NSFR-calculation expectation described. The Section is expressly limited to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. Within that scope, the expectation is that an Authorised Person should calculate its NSFR with an appropriate frequency to ensure it can monitor its satisfaction of the NSFR requirement at all times, and it should also calculate NSFR additionally where it believes that a change has happened to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding that might result in a material change to the level of its NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. So, the covered population is not “all firms,” but only Authorised Persons in those listed categories, and for them the obligation has two parts: ongoing calculations frequent enough for continuous monitoring, plus extra calculations when the firm believes ASF or RSF has changed in a way that could materially affect NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. Authorised Persons outside Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5 are not within the Section’s stated scope [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

question: When the Regulator reaches a decision on an application for admission of Securities to the Official List and that decision is to grant an Application for Listing, what written notification must the Regulator provide to the Applicant, and what must that notice cover?
expected_answer: Where the Regulator has made its decision on the Applicant’s application for admission of Securities to the Official List, it is required to notify the Applicant in writing of that decision [#SRC:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e]. In the specific circumstance that the Regulator decides to grant an Application for Listing, the Regulator must give the Applicant written notice of its decision [#TGT:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c]. Read together, these obligations mean that the Regulator’s written communication is not optional: it must be provided to the Applicant and it must convey the Regulator’s decision in relation to the relevant application, including when the outcome is a grant. The notice should therefore clearly identify that it is the Regulator’s decision, be in written form, and be directed to the Applicant, so the Applicant is formally informed of the outcome of the application process for admission/listing on the Official List.

debug_context.semantic_hook: notify the Applicant in writing of its decision

answer_spans.text: If the Regulator decides to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision

question: If the Regulator decides to approve an Application for Listing, does it have to tell the Applicant in writing, and is this tied to the decision on admission of Securities to the Official List?
expected_answer: Yes. The Regulator has an obligation to notify the Applicant in writing of its decision in relation to the application for admission of Securities to the Official List [#SRC:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e]. In addition, when the Regulator’s decision is to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision [#TGT:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c]. Taken together, these requirements mean that once the Regulator has decided the outcome of the relevant application process, the Applicant must receive a written notice communicating that decision, and this includes the scenario where the application is granted. The key compliance point is that the communication must be in writing, must come from the Regulator, and must be provided to the Applicant as the formal notification of the decision connected to admission/listing on the Official List.

question: For an Authorised Person whose dealing activity is limited to acting only to execute Clients’ orders, what conditions must be satisfied for it to be treated as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal, and how does that classification affect which category its dealing activities fall within?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person’s dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, those activities fall within the scope of Category 3A, rather than being treated as Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) for Category 2 purposes [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. An Authorised Person is treated as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal only if it enters into transactions as a principal solely to fulfil its Clients’ orders, and any positions it holds for its own account arise only because Clients’ orders could not be matched [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. In addition, the total market value of those positions must not exceed 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources, and the positions must be incidental and held only for the time reasonably required to carry out a transaction of that nature [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. Read together, the source establishes the category consequence of being limited to Matched Principal activity, while the target provides the operative criteria that must be met to rely on that classification [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc].

question: If an Authorised Person says it only deals to fill Clients’ orders, what does it need to do (and not do) to count as acting as a Matched Principal, and what category does that put its dealing activities into?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person’s dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the source text states that those dealing activities fall within Category 3A [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. To count as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal, the target definition requires that the Authorised Person enters into transactions as a principal only to fulfil its Clients’ orders, rather than taking principal risk for its own purposes [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. It may hold positions for its own account only when it fails to match Clients’ orders, and even then the total market value of those positions must be no more than 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. The positions must also be incidental and strictly limited to the time reasonably required to carry out a transaction of that nature [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. Putting these together: meeting the target conditions supports the “Matched Principal” label, and being limited to that activity drives the Category 3A treatment described in the source [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc].

question: When the Regulator has exercised its discretion to approve an Offer document (including any conditions or restrictions it imposes), what must be done to ensure the approved document is made available to the public, and in what timing and format?
expected_answer: Where the Regulator has decided to approve an Offer document under its discretionary power, including on any conditions or restrictions it sees fit, the approval triggers a separate publication obligation. Specifically, once the Offer document has been approved in accordance with the applicable approval process, it must be made available to the public as soon as reasonably practicable, and it must be made available in the form approved by the Regulator. In practice, this means the party responsible for publication cannot treat approval as the final step: it must promptly take steps to publish or otherwise provide public access, and it must ensure that the version released matches the form the Regulator approved (including any changes needed to reflect conditions or restrictions attached to the approval). The Regulator’s ability to approve subject to conditions or restrictions frames what “the form approved” entails, while the obligation governs the timing and public availability following that approval. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca]

question: If the Regulator approves an Offer document (and may add conditions or restrictions), what has to happen next so the public can access it, and how quickly and in what version must it be shared?
expected_answer: If the Regulator chooses to approve an Offer document using its power to do so (including where it imposes any conditions or restrictions it considers appropriate), that approval is followed by a mandatory step to make the document publicly available. Once the Offer document has been approved through the relevant approval process, it must be made available to the public as soon as reasonably practicable. It also must be made available in the form approved by the Regulator, meaning the publicly released version must match the approved form rather than an earlier draft or a modified version that has not been approved. Read together, the Regulator’s permission to approve (and to attach conditions or restrictions) determines what counts as the approved document, and the obligation then requires prompt public availability of that approved form. This links the approval decision to a concrete publication outcome: approval is not optional once granted, but public access in the approved form and without undue delay is required. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca]

question: For Quarterly Reports – Mining Exploration Reporting Entities, what must a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity disclose for each quarter of its financial year, and by when must it make that disclosure after the quarter ends?
expected_answer: A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose a quarterly report for each quarter of its financial year, and it must do so no later than 1 month after the end of the quarter. The quarterly report must cover the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis, if applicable, and include: details of activities relating to mining (Exploration or a statement of no Exploration; and production and development or a statement of no such activities); a summary of expenditure incurred relating to Exploration activities and to production and development; the Mining Tenements held at quarter end, including location and percentage interest held (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Mining Tenements (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements) acquired or disposed of during the quarter, including their location. In addition, at least once every 12 months, the report must include the Summary of Reserves and Resources unless it is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and will be made. These content and timing obligations apply together to satisfy the quarterly disclosure requirement [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] within the specified post-quarter deadline [#SRC:8e80c422-3b41-4546-b511-41bb90ad9e79].

answer_spans.text: Quarterly Reports – Mining Exploration Reporting Entities.

question: What does a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity have to put in its quarterly report, and how soon after the quarter ends must it disclose that report?
expected_answer: A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose a report for each quarter of its financial year, and it must disclose it no later than 1 month after the end of the quarter. The report must cover the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, on a consolidated basis if applicable, and it must include specific mining-related information. This includes: what activities occurred (Exploration, and production and development) or clear statements that there were no such activities; a summary of expenditure for Exploration activities and for production and development; the Mining Tenements held at the end of the quarter with their location and the percentage interest held (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and the Mining Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements) with their location. The report must also, at least once every 12 months, include the Summary of Reserves and Resources unless it is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and will be disclosed. Meeting both the required content [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] and the deadline [#SRC:8e80c422-3b41-4546-b511-41bb90ad9e79] is necessary for compliance.

question: For an Authorised Person, how should its categorisation be determined where its Financial Services Permission includes authorisation to Accept Deposits or manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAu, but it is also authorised for activities such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of an express trust, or Providing Money Services? Identify the determinative permissions and the exclusion tests that must be applied to decide whether it falls in Category 1 or Category 3C.
expected_answer: Categorisation turns on which Regulated Activities the Authorised Person is authorised to carry on under its Financial Services Permission and on the relevant exclusion tests. Under the Category 1 definition, an Authorised Person is in Category 1 if its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance confirms that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more of Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services (as trustee of at least one express trust), or Providing Money Services, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5; the guidance similarly treats those authorisations (and the absence of certain other authorisations) as determinative [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm meets the Category 1 trigger and is not Category 5, it is Category 1; Category 3C is only available if the firm does not meet Category 1 (and the other listed categories) while meeting the Category 3C activity trigger.

question: If an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission lets it Accept Deposits or manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAu, but it also lets it manage assets or funds, provide custody (not for a Fund), act as trustee for an express trust, provide money services, or manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAr, how do you decide whether it is Category 1 or Category 3C?
expected_answer: Start by checking which permissions are treated as decisive for each category and then apply the “not in other categories” tests. Category 1 applies when the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance makes clear that this specific authorisation is what determines Category 1 even if the firm can do other Regulated Activities as well [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. Category 3C applies when the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more of Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services (as trustee of at least one express trust), or Providing Money Services, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5; the guidance similarly treats those authorisations (and the absence of certain other authorisations) as determinative [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. So, if the firm has the Category 1 trigger permission and is not Category 5, it is Category 1; it can only be Category 3C if it meets the Category 3C activity trigger and is not in Category 1 (or the other excluded categories).

question: When seeking authorisation to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, what must a PFP Applicant/applicant demonstrate to the satisfaction of the FSRA/Regulator regarding resources, fitness and propriety, supervisory capability, and compliance arrangements, and how do these requirements align across both regimes?
expected_answer: Across both texts, the applicant’s obligation is framed as a threshold demonstration that must satisfy the relevant authority before authorisation is granted. Under the SOURCE, a PFP Applicant must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the FSRA that it meets four core conditions: it has adequate and appropriate resources (including financial resources), it is fit and proper, it is capable of being effectively supervised, and it has adequate compliance arrangements (including policies and procedures) enabling compliance with all applicable legal requirements [#SRC:05a7c46a-5ae7-46dc-9959-0022589fb3c0]. The TARGET mirrors the same four-part demonstration for an applicant seeking to become authorised to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, requiring the applicant to satisfy the Regulator on the same elements of resources, fitness and propriety, supervisory capability, and compliance arrangements [#TGT:af65ff3c-f0e5-4696-bfa9-e84675e773cb]. A key alignment point is that both require “adequate compliance arrangements” supported by policies and procedures; the TARGET further clarifies that the legal requirements to be complied with include the Rules, reinforcing that the compliance framework must be designed to meet rule-based obligations as well as other applicable legal requirements [#TGT:af65ff3c-f0e5-4696-bfa9-e84675e773cb].

question: If a PFP Applicant (or any applicant) wants to be authorised to carry on Regulated Activities, what does it have to prove to the FSRA/Regulator about its money and other resources, whether it is fit and proper, whether it can be supervised, and whether it has the right compliance policies and procedures?
expected_answer: Both passages require the applicant to actively show—before authorisation—that it meets a set of baseline conditions to the satisfaction of the relevant authority. In the SOURCE, the Threshold Conditions require a PFP Applicant to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the FSRA that it (a) has adequate and appropriate resources, including financial resources, (b) is fit and proper, (c) is capable of being effectively supervised, and (d) has adequate compliance arrangements, including policies and procedures, that will enable it to comply with all applicable legal requirements [#SRC:05a7c46a-5ae7-46dc-9959-0022589fb3c0]. The TARGET sets out the same four things an applicant must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator in order to become authorised to carry on one or more Regulated Activities: adequate and appropriate resources (including financial resources), fit and proper status, effective supervisability, and adequate compliance arrangements supported by policies and procedures [#TGT:af65ff3c-f0e5-4696-bfa9-e84675e773cb]. The practical takeaway from reading both together is that the applicant must be prepared to evidence not only financial and operational capacity and suitability, but also a compliance framework that is designed to meet all applicable legal requirements; the TARGET explicitly notes that these include the Rules, so the policies and procedures should be capable of supporting rule compliance as well [#TGT:af65ff3c-f0e5-4696-bfa9-e84675e773cb].

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, may the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to disapply the rule on withdrawal of consent, and if so how does that affect whether the Customer can withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction before the point at which it can no longer be revoked?
expected_answer: Yes. Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that specified rules do not apply, including Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent) and Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order) [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. In the absence of such a written agreement disapplying the withdrawal-of-consent rules, the Customer may withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the point at which the Third Party Transaction can no longer be revoked as set out in Rule 20.8.2, i.e., the Customer “may withdraw its consent” within that pre-revocation window [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. If the parties validly agree in writing that the withdrawal-of-consent rules do not apply, that agreement can alter whether and how the Customer can exercise the permission described for withdrawing consent, because the target permission is framed by the rule-set that the source allows the parties to switch off for a non-Natural Person Customer. Any such agreement should be explicit about the scope (e.g., disapplying Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 and/or Rule 20.8.2) to avoid ambiguity about the withdrawal timing tied to revocation.

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing that the withdrawal-of-consent rules do not apply, and what does that mean for whether the Customer can withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction before it can no longer be revoked?
expected_answer: Yes. When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain rules do not apply, including Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent) and Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order) [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Separately, the Customer is permitted to withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the point when that Third Party Transaction can no longer be revoked, with that point defined by Rule 20.8.2; in other words, the Customer “may withdraw its consent” up to that revocation cut-off [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. Putting the two together, the target permission operates as the default position, but the source allows the parties (only in the non-Natural Person scenario) to contract out of the withdrawal-of-consent framework by written agreement. If they do so, the Customer’s ability to withdraw consent on the timing described in the target may be changed or removed to the extent the agreed disapplication covers the relevant rules, so the written agreement should clearly state what is being disapplied and what, if anything, replaces it.

question: When an MTF or OTF uses arrangements to make trading information public, what conditions must those arrangements meet, and how does that obligation align with the expectation for how publicly released information should be formatted and the discretion a Recognised Investment Exchange has over the structure it uses?
expected_answer: Where an MTF or OTF uses arrangements to make information public (including trading information that must be disclosed), those arrangements must meet multiple operational conditions: they must be reliable, monitored continuously, and make the information available to the public on a non-discriminatory basis [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. In addition to these conditions, the dissemination format must be consistent and structured, even though the venue can choose the particular format structure it uses [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. This aligns with the expectation that information made public should conform to a consistent and structured format based on industry standards, while also recognising that Recognised Investment Exchanges can choose the structure they use [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504]. Taken together, the requirements and expectations point to a combined compliance outcome: the publication mechanism must be operationally robust and fair in access, and the output must be presented in a consistent, structured way, with flexibility on the chosen structure so long as it meets the consistency/structure standard and, in the target framing, reflects industry standards [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef] [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must satisfy a number of conditions, including that it is reliable

answer_spans.text: Information that is made public should conform to a consistent and structured format based on industry standards.

question: If an MTF or OTF makes information public, what must it do to ensure the publication method is dependable and fair, and what does the guidance say about using a consistent, structured format and letting Recognised Investment Exchanges pick the structure?
expected_answer: An MTF or OTF that uses arrangements to make information public must ensure those arrangements meet key conditions: they must be reliable, monitored continuously, and provide the information to the public on a non-discriminatory basis [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. Beyond how the system operates, there is also a formatting requirement: even though the MTF or OTF can choose the format structure used for dissemination, the format must still be consistent and structured [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. The target guidance reinforces the same direction for the published output by stating that information made public should use a consistent and structured format based on industry standards, and it similarly notes that Recognised Investment Exchanges can choose the structure they use [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504]. Read together, the source sets baseline operational safeguards (reliability, continuous monitoring, non-discriminatory access) and a consistency/structure requirement, while the target adds that the consistent, structured approach should be grounded in industry standards and confirms discretion over the chosen structure [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef] [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504].

question: When managing a Qualified Investor Fund, what core obligations must a Fund Manager still comply with despite any exemption from detailed requirements, and how must those obligations be reflected in the way it manages the Fund and Fund Property and follows governing documents and regulatory conditions?
expected_answer: Even where a Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund is exempt from many detailed requirements applicable to Public Funds and Exempt Funds, it remains subject to most of the main, overarching obligations applicable to Fund Managers and should manage the Qualified Investor Fund with those continuing duties in mind [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e]. In practical terms, the Fund Manager must manage the Fund, including the Fund Property, in accordance with the Fund’s Constitution and the most recent Prospectus, and it must perform the functions conferred on it by the Fund’s Constitution and by or under the applicable Rules [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b]. In addition, the Fund Manager must comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed by the Regulator, including those on its Financial Services Permission or in respect of the Fund, and must comply with any requirements or limitations imposed under the Rules, including limits relating to financial interests it or any of its associates may hold in a Fund for which it acts as the appointed Fund Manager [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b].

question: If a Fund Manager runs a Qualified Investor Fund and is exempt from many detailed rules, what must it still do day to day to meet its main obligations—especially about following the Fund’s Constitution and Prospectus and any Regulator conditions or limits?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund may be exempt from many detailed requirements that apply to Public Funds and Exempt Funds, but it still remains subject to most of the main obligations of Fund Managers and should treat those overarching obligations as continuing to apply when managing the Qualified Investor Fund [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e]. Operationally, that means the Fund Manager must manage the Fund (including the Fund Property) in line with the Fund’s Constitution and its most recent Prospectus, and it must carry out the functions given to it by the Fund’s Constitution and by or under the applicable Rules [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b]. It also must comply with any conditions or restrictions the Regulator imposes, including those attached to its Financial Services Permission or those applying to the Fund, and it must comply with any requirements or limitations under the Rules, including limits on financial interests it or any of its associates may hold in a Fund where it is the appointed Fund Manager [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b].
