question: Where a rule framework refers to “Investments” (and therefore “Client Investments”) but the activity is in relation to Virtual Assets, what must an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody do to ensure it applies the correct conduct and client protection requirements, including where Client Money is held or controlled?
expected_answer: For the specified purposes, references to “Investment” or “Investments” (and the related references to “Client Investments”) are to be interpreted as also covering “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable [#SRC:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0]. Accordingly, when an Authorised Person is conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, it should treat any obligations that are triggered by “Investments” or “Client Investments” as potentially triggered by Virtual Assets as well, and then apply the relevant conduct and safeguarding framework that the Virtual Asset regime points to. In particular, in addition to the general requirements applicable to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapters 14, 15 and 16 [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0]. Further, where the Authorised Person’s Virtual Asset activity holds or controls Client Money, it must comply with the Client Money Rules in Chapter 14 as amended by the specified Virtual Asset requirements [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0].

debug_context.semantic_hook: shall be read as encompassing “Virtual Asset”

Guidance
An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets which hold or control Client Money must comply with the Client Money Rules set out in Chapter ‎14, as amended by the requirement

question: If a requirement talks about “Investments” or “Client Investments”, but the firm is dealing with Virtual Assets, how should an Authorised Person apply the custody and client money obligations when it is Providing Custody for Virtual Assets?
expected_answer: You should read the terms “Investment” or “Investments” (and the related term “Client Investments”) as also including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable, for the stated purposes [#SRC:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0]. That means an Authorised Person cannot assume that obligations framed around “Investments” are irrelevant just because the product is a Virtual Asset; instead, it should treat Virtual Assets as falling within that terminology where the cross-reference applies, and then follow the Virtual Asset-specific compliance pathway. When the Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapters 14, 15 and 16, in addition to the general requirements that apply to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0]. Also, if the Virtual Asset activity holds or controls Client Money, the Authorised Person must comply with the Client Money Rules in Chapter 14, as amended by the specified Virtual Asset requirements [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0].

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it do to ensure the disclosure is both properly attributed to named Competent Person(s) and not released without the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent as to the form and context of the presentation?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must satisfy two linked requirements when it discloses Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves. First, the disclosure must include specific attribution statements: it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must also state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer); and it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Second, the statement referred to in the relevant framework must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]. Together, these obligations mean the Petroleum Reporting Entity must both obtain the required written consent for the presentation and include the required identification and status details for the named Competent Person(s) in the disclosure.

debug_context.semantic_hook: must only be disclosed with the prior written consent

answer_spans.text: Competent Persons .

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity publishes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it say about the named Competent Person(s), and what consent must it have before it discloses the relevant statement and supporting information?
expected_answer: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, it must include clear information about the Competent Person(s) and also ensure the disclosure is authorised in the required way. On content, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if the Competent Person is not, it must give the name of the Competent Person’s employer. In addition, it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Separately, the statement referred to in the framework must only be disclosed if the Petroleum Reporting Entity has the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and the supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e].

question: At what minimum interval must an Authorised Person perform the required evaluation of its Exposure to interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, and how does this timing interact with the requirement to measure risk Exposures by material currency where balance sheet positions span different currencies?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. The minimum frequency for that evaluation is once each year, meaning the evaluation must be performed at least annually (and may be performed more frequently, but not less) [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5]. Where the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, the evaluation must be supported by measuring its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies, so that the annual assessment reflects currency-specific material risk rather than only an aggregated view [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. In practice, this means the annual cycle should include (i) completing the evaluation of interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities and (ii) ensuring that, for multi-currency balance sheets, the measurement component is performed for each material currency as part of the same evaluation process, meeting both the action requirement and the minimum timing requirement [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3].

debug_context.semantic_hook: the minimum frequency of the evaluation referred to

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities

question: How often does an Authorised Person have to do the evaluation of interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book activities, and what extra step is required if it has balance sheet positions in more than one currency?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. The minimum required frequency for that evaluation is once each year, so the Authorised Person must ensure it completes the evaluation at least annually [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5]. If the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must also measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies, rather than treating the exposure as a single undifferentiated amount [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Put together, the annual evaluation should incorporate currency-by-currency measurement where relevant, so that the required evaluation is both performed on time (at least once per year) and is based on measurements that cover each material currency exposure when multiple currencies are present [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3].

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the relevant pre-settlement methodology, how may the Authorised Person recognise the effect of that Collateral, and in what circumstances must it instead calculate E* (and substitute E* for E) for all its CR Exposures to a single Counterparty under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement when using the FCCA?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified pre-settlement approach, it is permitted to recognise the effect of that Collateral, but only by applying the collateral-recognition provisions referenced for that purpose [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Separately, when the same Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and it is using the FCCA, it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, following the referenced App4 methodology (including where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used) [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. In that FCCA/netting scenario, the Authorised Person must then substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under the applicable credit risk framework [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. Read together, the permission to recognise collateral effects operates within the pre-settlement exposure determination, while the FCCA/netting case imposes a mandatory E* calculation and substitution for the covered Counterparty exposures.

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Count

question: If an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, when can it take that Collateral into account for the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, and when must it calculate E* for all CR Exposures to one Counterparty and use E* instead of E under the FCCA and a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT may take the Collateral’s impact into account for the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, but only where that pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified pre-settlement approach and the Collateral is recognised using the referenced collateral-recognition rules [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. However, if the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and it is using the FCCA, it has a separate mandatory requirement: it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty that is covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, using the referenced App4 calculation approach (including the cases where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used) [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. After calculating E*, the Authorised Person must replace E with E* when it calculates the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for those CR Exposures to that Counterparty under the applicable credit risk section [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776].

question: For an Authorised Person, how does the scope of its Financial Services Permission determine whether it is classified in Category 1 versus Category 3B, and what exclusionary category tests must be satisfied in each case?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s category turns on which Regulated Activities its Financial Services Permission authorises and on specified exclusion tests. For Category 1, the permission must authorise the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm must not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance emphasises that this specific authorisation is determinative even if the firm is also authorised for other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3B applies where the permission authorises one or more of the Regulated Activities of Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; the guidance similarly notes that the custody-for-a-Fund or trustee authorisation, together with the absence of authorisation for certain other activities, is determinative even if other activities are also authorised [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe].

Category 1 is met where the Financial Services Permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance clarifies that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. Therefore, a custody/trustee-authorised firm would be prevented from being treated as Category 3B, and instead be treated as Category 1, if its permission also includes Accepting Deposits or Managing a PSIAu and it is not within Category 5, because that would cause it to meet Category 1 and fail the Category 3B exclusion test.

question: When Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 and are being admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, is a person prohibited from having those Securities admitted to trading unless there is an Approved Prospectus, or is that prohibition disapplied (subject to Rule 4.4.2) because it does not apply to that admission to trading?
expected_answer: The general position is that a person shall not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities, and this prohibition is expressly stated as applying “subject to subsection (3)” and uses the term “shall not” [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]. However, the scope carve-out provides that the prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and this disapplication is itself subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. Read together, the admission-to-trading limb of the “shall not” prohibition is not intended to apply in the specific case where the Securities qualify as Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, but only within the boundary set by Rule 4.4.2’s requirement. Accordingly, compliance analysis must confirm both the Exempt Securities status under Rule 4.4.1 and satisfaction of Rule 4.4.2 before treating the Approved Prospectus condition as inapplicable for that admission to trading.

debug_context.semantic_hook: does not apply to the admission to trading

answer_spans.text: shall not

question: If someone wants Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, do they have to avoid doing so unless there is an Approved Prospectus, or does that “shall not” rule not apply when the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 (as long as Rule 4.4.2 is met)?
expected_answer: Under the prohibition, a person shall not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities, and this is framed as being “subject to subsection (3)” and uses the explicit prohibition term “shall not” [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]. But the scope text narrows that outcome for a particular category: it states that the prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and it adds that this non-application is subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. Putting both together, the “shall not” restriction on admission to trading is not meant to bite where the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, but only if the Rule 4.4.2 requirement is satisfied. So the key checks are: (1) the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and (2) Rule 4.4.2’s requirement is met; otherwise the Approved Prospectus condition remains the operative prohibition.

question: When a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect a person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, is that person permitted to refer the matter to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and are any categories of decisions excluded from referral under the broader framework described?
expected_answer: Yes. Where a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, that person may refer the decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. The broader framework described alongside this permission indicates that the referral right is framed to cover decisions that may affect rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect interests, but it also notes an exclusion for operational decisions from the set of decisions that may be referred for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. In addition, the framework explains that certain other decisions—specifically including decisions such as the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers—may also be referable to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even where they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Taken together, the permission to refer in the Regulations operates for affected persons, while the broader description clarifies both an operational-decision carve-out and that some additional non‑Part 21 decisions may still be referable.

The accompanying framework description reinforces that the referral mechanism is intended to capture decisions with that kind of impact, but it expressly identifies operational decisions as excluded from the category of decisions that may be referred for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. At the same time, it clarifies that there are “certain other decisions” that may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even though they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure, with the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers given as an example [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Accordingly, the permission to refer Rules and decisions under the Regulations is complemented by a broader statement that both limits referral for operational decisions and extends referral to some additional non‑Part 21 decisions.

question: Where a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, what systems and procedures must it maintain to support segregation and portability for Client positions and related collateral, and how must those arrangements operate across Member and other participant defaults?
expected_answer: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, the segregation-and-portability requirements apply as part of the set of requirements expressly applicable to that service context [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]. In that scope, the Recognised Clearing House must have systems and procedures that enable segregation and portability of positions of the Clients of its Members and other participants on its facilities, together with any collateral provided to it in respect of those positions [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571]. Those systems and procedures must be capable of maintaining Client positions and related collateral either in individual Client accounts or in Omnibus Client Accounts, so that the Recognised Clearing House can operationally support the chosen account structure while still meeting segregation objectives [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571]. In addition, the Recognised Clearing House must structure its portability arrangements so that, if a Member or other participant defaults, the positions and collateral of that defaulting entity’s Clients can be transferred to one or more other Members or participants, ensuring portability is workable in a default scenario within the Central Counterparty Services framework [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] and within the applicable requirements set for such a Recognised Clearing House [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6].

expected_answer: When a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, it falls within the scope of requirements that are stated to apply to that type of Recognised Clearing House, including the requirements on segregation and portability [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]. In that context, the Recognised Clearing House must have systems and procedures that enable segregation and portability of positions of the Clients of its Members and other participants on its facilities, as well as any collateral provided to it in relation to those positions [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571]. Practically, those systems and procedures must allow the Recognised Clearing House to keep Client positions and related collateral either in individual Client accounts or in Omnibus Client Accounts, so the account model still supports segregation [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571]. They must also support portability by being structured so that, if a Member or other participant defaults, the positions and collateral of that defaulting Member’s or other participant’s Clients can be transferred to one or more other Members or participants [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571]. This ties the operational obligation back to the stated applicability for a Recognised Clearing House providing Central Counterparty Services [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6].

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure about a Production Target, under what conditions may its later disclosure omit the detailed assumptions and other required Production Target content that would otherwise have to be included, and what must the later disclosure still do to remain consistent with the required content for the original disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to streamline a later disclosure about a Production Target by not repeating the information that would otherwise be required, but only if the later disclosure is tied back to an earlier disclosure that already met the full content requirements for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 (including the required coverage of material economic assumptions or, if commercially sensitive, a sensitivity statement plus methodology, other material assumptions, any statement on forecast commodity pricing being on reasonable grounds, and the required breakdown and statements regarding the proportions based on reserves/resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. To rely on that permission, the later disclosure must reference the earlier compliant disclosure and confirm that all material assumptions underpinning the Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. In addition, where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement corresponding to those cases, even though other required details may be omitted [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].

answer_spans.text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already disclosed a Production Target with all the required assumptions and related details, when can it make a later Production Target disclosure without repeating those details, and what does it still need to include in that later disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include specific content about how the Production Target was determined, including all material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement and the methodology used), all other material assumptions, any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, and the required breakdown of what proportions of the Production Target are based on reserves/resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target, together with the required statements for those categories [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure about the same Production Target may omit the information that would otherwise need to be repeated, but only if it points back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant and it confirms that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or if it is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement for those situations, even though it can avoid re-stating the rest of the detailed required content [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].

question: When is an Authorised Person prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client or providing related advice/arrangements, and how does that prohibition interact with the requirement to reassess the relevant client assessment annually or upon a material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or from providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first completed an assessment of the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance and can reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. In addition, the assessment that underpins this gatekeeping must be kept current through reassessment by the Authorised Person on an annual basis, and also earlier where there is any material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance before the annual reassessment [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]. Read together, the prohibition means the Authorised Person should not rely on an outdated assessment when engaging in the restricted activities; instead, it must ensure the prerequisite assessment has been completed and, where required, reassessed so that the reasonable conclusions about experience, risk understanding, and liquid resources remain valid at the time of offering, advising, or arranging.

expected_answer: An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements for a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first completed an assessment covering the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance, and can reasonably conclude the Retail Client both understands the potential risk of loss (through adequate experience and skill) and has enough liquid financial resources to absorb potential losses from trading [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. That “first completed” assessment is not a one-off: it must be reassessed by the Authorised Person on an annual basis, and it must also be reassessed earlier if there is any material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance before the annual review point [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]. Putting these together, the restriction on offering/advising/arranging continues to apply unless the required assessment has been done and kept up to date through the required reassessment timing, so the Authorised Person’s conclusions about the Retail Client’s risk understanding and liquid resources remain reasonably supportable.

question: When a person is required to attend an interview after receiving written notice to answer questions, what is prohibited as a basis for refusing to answer, and how does that prohibition align with the rule that a person must not treat self-incrimination or confidential communications as a reasonable excuse to refuse inspection/production obligations or to answer questions under an information-gathering requirement?
expected_answer: Where a person is required to attend an interview, they are first given written notice requiring attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer merely because the answer may incriminate them, expose them to a penalty, or reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification regarding confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. In parallel, the prohibition in the information-gathering context makes clear that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of information or a Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) information or a Document, or to answer questions, on the grounds that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Read together, the interview obligation and the broader prohibition both foreclose reliance on self-incrimination or confidentiality as a refusal rationale for answering questions, and the target text extends the same principle to inspection/copying and production duties when imposed under the relevant requirements.

debug_context.semantic_hook: not entitled to refuse or fail to answer

question: If someone gets written notice to attend an interview and answer questions, are they prohibited from refusing to answer because it could incriminate them or reveal something said in confidence, and does the same “no reasonable excuse” rule also apply to refusing to let documents be inspected/copied or produced under a requirement?
expected_answer: Yes. In the interview setting, a person who is required to attend an interview is first provided written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer just because the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification about confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. The related prohibition goes further by stating that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of any information or Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) any information or Document, or to answer questions, when the refusal is based on the ground that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Together, these passages mean a person cannot rely on self-incrimination or confidentiality concerns as the reason to avoid answering questions at interview, and cannot use those grounds as a “reasonable excuse” to avoid inspection/copying or production duties when required.

debug_context.semantic_hook: not entitled to refuse or fail to answer

question: For purposes of insider dealing controls, how is the first type of Behaviour defined when an Insider engages in, or tries to engage in, a transaction involving a Financial Instrument or the other specified asset classes, and how does that definition align with the rule that prohibits an Insider from acting directly or indirectly on Inside Information?
expected_answer: The first type of Behaviour is defined as conduct where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, and does so on the basis of Inside Information that relates to the particular Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities involved. This definition captures both completed transactions and attempted transactions, and it ties the trigger to the use of Inside Information connected to the instrument or asset in question [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25]. In parallel, the prohibition requires that an Insider must not directly or indirectly deal or attempt to deal in any of those same categories (including a Related Instrument) when the conduct is on the basis of Inside Information [#SRC:5f2fca21-b189-4f85-bd15-8b59c4eca817]. Read together, the definition describes the relevant behavioural pattern (dealing or attempting to deal using Inside Information relating to the relevant asset), while the prohibition makes that pattern impermissible regardless of whether the Insider acts directly or through indirect means.

question: What does the rule treat as the first kind of insider Behaviour when an Insider tries to trade, and what does it say the Insider must not do (even indirectly) if the action is based on Inside Information?
expected_answer: The first kind of Behaviour is when an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, and the dealing or attempted dealing is done on the basis of Inside Information that relates to the specific Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities involved [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25]. The prohibition then states the compliance outcome: an Insider shall not directly or indirectly deal or attempt to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, an Accepted Spot Commodity, or a Related Instrument when the conduct is on the basis of Inside Information [#SRC:5f2fca21-b189-4f85-bd15-8b59c4eca817]. Together, these passages mean that both an actual trade and an attempted trade fall within the defined Behaviour when driven by Inside Information, and that the same conduct is prohibited whether the Insider acts personally or through an indirect route.

question: For the purpose of identifying Behaviour that secures the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level, how does the Regulator assess whether the conduct creates or is likely to create an artificial price, and what specific indicators will it consider in that assessment?
expected_answer: Behaviour may fall within the relevant category where it involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices, and the conduct either gives (or is likely to give) a false or misleading impression as to supply, demand or price, or secures the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. In considering whether conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, the Regulator is likely to take into account a set of factors focused on the person’s incentives and observable market effects [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1]. These include the extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset or Accepted Spot Commodity; whether price, rate or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) are outside normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly ranges for the instrument in question; and whether the person has successively and consistently increased or decreased their bid, Offer, or the price paid. Taken together, these indicators help the Regulator evaluate whether the trading behaviour is likely to be associated with an artificial or abnormal price outcome.

question: When trading activity might be seen as creating an artificial price, what does the Regulator look at, and how does that connect to the definition of Behaviour that uses transactions or orders to trade to create a false impression or keep prices at an abnormal or artificial level?
expected_answer: The definition focuses on Behaviour where a person effects transactions or orders to trade without legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices, and the activity either gives (or is likely to give) a false or misleading impression about supply, demand or price, or secures the price at an abnormal or artificial level for one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. When the Regulator considers whether conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, it is likely to take into account practical indicators that show whether the trading could be driving an artificial outcome [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1]. These indicators include: (1) how much the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant instrument or asset; (2) whether price, rate or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) are outside normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly ranges; and (3) whether the person repeatedly and consistently moved their bid, Offer, or the price paid up or down over time. The Regulator uses these factors to connect observed trading patterns to the risk of a false impression or an abnormal/artificial price level.

question: When a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund elects to perform fund administration for the Fund, what must it do to ensure the Fund’s operational risks are adequately addressed, and how does the requirement to separate risk management from portfolio functions condition that arrangement?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may perform fund administration for the Fund only in circumstances where its risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated, which sets a structural condition for taking on administration activities [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc]. In parallel, the Fund Manager must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, taking due regard of the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]. Read together, the permission to self-perform administration is not standalone; it must be implemented within a governance and operating model that preserves adequate separation between risk management and portfolio functions while still meeting the overarching obligation to address operational risks. This means the Fund Manager should align its administration arrangement with its risk framework and investment process, and ensure that the roles typically performed by Fund Administrators, Eligible Custodians, and any prime brokers are appropriately considered in how risks are identified and addressed, even where the Fund Manager itself performs administration.

debug_context.semantic_hook: perform fund administration for the Fund in circumstances

answer_spans.text: Risk management.

question: If a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund wants to do the Fund’s administration work itself, what must it ensure about risk management and portfolio functions, and what is it required to do about the Fund’s operational risks given the roles of Fund Administrators, Eligible Custodians, and any prime brokers?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund is permitted to perform fund administration for the Fund, but only where risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated, so the Fund Manager must first ensure that this separation exists in the circumstances in which it takes on administration tasks [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc]. Separately and in all cases, the Fund Manager must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]. Putting these together, doing administration in-house does not reduce the Fund Manager’s responsibility for operational risk; instead, the Fund Manager must structure its internal functions so that risk management remains adequately separated from portfolio functions while also considering how administration, custody, and any prime brokerage roles affect how operational risks are addressed in practice.

question: When seeking authorisation under the RegLab framework, what must the applicant demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator regarding its ability to define test parameters and safeguards, and how may the Regulator correspondingly constrain the FinTech Participant’s testing through client and exposure limits to control scope and scale?
expected_answer: To become authorised under the RegLab framework, the applicant must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator that it can clearly define the FinTech Proposal’s test parameters, control boundaries, key milestones, and intended outcomes, and that it can satisfactorily detail safeguards and show they are appropriate to the FinTech Proposal being tested, the risks posed, and the type of clients likely to be affected [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d]. In parallel, under the RegLab’s blank-sheet approach—where certain Rules may be waived or modified for the FinTech Participant—the Regulator may set client and exposure limits specifically to limit the scope and scale of the FinTech Participant’s test activities, thereby controlling client impact and protecting clients’ interests [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]. Read together, the applicant’s obligation is to present a well-defined, controlled testing plan with appropriate protections, while recognising that the Regulator is permitted to operationalise those controls by imposing quantitative limits on clients and exposures as part of the authorisation conditions.

At the same time, because the RegLab uses a blank-sheet approach in which certain Rules may be waived or modified for the FinTech Participant, the Regulator is permitted to set client and exposure limits to limit the scope and scale of the FinTech Participant’s test activities, helping ensure client impact is controlled and clients’ interests are protected [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]. In practice, this means the applicant must come prepared with a clear, bounded testing design and client-focused safeguards, and should expect that the Regulator may formalise those boundaries by imposing specific limits on how many clients can be involved and how much exposure the test can create.

question: When a Relevant Person is assessing geographical and jurisdictional risk to decide whether a customer may be treated as low risk, what sources must it rely on to identify countries with effective AML systems, low corruption/criminal activity, and alignment with and implementation of FATF Recommendations, and what types of materials qualify as those sources?
expected_answer: When undertaking a risk-based assessment of a customer and deciding whether to assign a low-risk rating, a Relevant Person must take into account all relevant risk factors that reasonably apply, including geographical and jurisdictional risk factors that depend on whether countries are identified or assessed by “credible sources” as having effective systems to counter money laundering, low levels of corruption or other criminal activity, and requirements consistent with, and effective implementation of, the FATF Recommendations [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90]. In applying that obligation, the definition of what counts as a credible source includes (without limitation) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]. Accordingly, the Relevant Person should ground its country-risk conclusions in those kinds of external evaluations and reports from the listed bodies (and comparable International Organisations), and then incorporate the resulting country findings into the overall customer risk assessment alongside other relevant customer and product/channel factors before determining whether a low-risk rating is appropriate [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90].

question: In considering whether a customer connected to a lower-risk jurisdiction should receive a low-risk rating, how must a Relevant Person evidence that the jurisdiction is lower risk using credible sources, and which issuing organisations and report types fall within that concept?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person considering whether to assign a low-risk rating must take into account relevant risk factors, including whether the customer is resident, established, registered, or conducts business in a geographical area or jurisdiction of lower risk, and the related requirement to evaluate geographical and jurisdictional risk factors by reference to whether countries are identified or assessed by credible sources as effective in countering money laundering, low in corruption or other criminal activity, and consistent with and effective in implementing the FATF Recommendations [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90]. To evidence that a jurisdiction is “lower risk” for these purposes, the Relevant Person should rely on materials that meet the definition of credible source, which includes (but is not limited to) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]. Practically, this means the Relevant Person should document which of those reports it used to support its view of the jurisdiction’s AML effectiveness, corruption/criminality profile, and FATF consistency/implementation, and then incorporate those findings into the overall risk-based assessment before concluding on the customer’s low-risk rating [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90].

To meet that requirement, the Relevant Person should use information that fits the definition of a credible source. Credible sources include (and are not limited to) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]. So, the Relevant Person should base its country-risk view on those kinds of external evaluations and reports from the listed bodies (or similar International Organisations), and then reflect those findings in the overall customer risk-based assessment before deciding whether the customer can reasonably be rated low risk [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90].

question: During a customer risk-based assessment, how should a Relevant Person use credible sources to judge whether a country has strong AML controls and low corruption, and which specific report types and issuers are included as credible sources?
expected_answer: As part of a risk-based assessment of a customer, a Relevant Person must take into account relevant risk factors that reasonably apply, including geographical and jurisdictional risk factors that look at whether countries are identified by credible sources as having effective systems to counter money laundering, low corruption or other criminal activity, and whether they have been assessed as having requirements consistent with, and effectively implementing, the FATF Recommendations [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90]. The meaning of “credible source” for this purpose includes, but is not limited to, mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]. In practice, the Relevant Person should consult and record the relevant mutual evaluation or assessment/follow-up reports from those issuers (or comparable International Organisations) to support its view of the country’s AML effectiveness and corruption/criminality profile, and then use that evidence as part of the overall set of risk factors considered when deciding whether a low-risk rating is appropriate [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90].

debug_context.semantic_hook: a credible source includes, but is not limited to

answer_spans.text: When undertaking a risk-based assessment of a customer and considering whether or not to assign a low-risk rating under ‎7.

question: When the Rules in this Section apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm (rather than as a Branch), what capital adequacy obligation must that Authorised Person meet, and on what ongoing basis?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm, the Section’s allocation of applicability makes clear that the Domestic Firm-specific requirements in this part of the Rules are the ones that govern that operating status, rather than the provision identified for an Authorised Person operating as a Branch [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. In that Domestic Firm context, the Authorised Person has a continuous capital adequacy obligation: it must maintain Capital Resources at a level that is at least equal to its Capital Requirement, and it must do so at all times, not merely at reporting dates or periodic intervals [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e]. Practically, this means the firm must monitor both its Capital Resources and its Capital Requirement on an ongoing basis and ensure that the former never falls below the latter while it is operating as a Domestic Firm. The obligation is framed as a minimum threshold (equal to or exceeding the Capital Requirement) and is expressed as a standing condition of operation for an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, consistent with the Section’s delineation of which rules apply by operating form [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] and the specific Domestic Firm capital standard [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: Rules apply to an Authorised Person operating

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement

question: If an Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm under this Section (not as a Branch), what must it do about its Capital Resources compared with its Capital Requirement, and how often must it meet that test?
expected_answer: Under this Section, the Rules are applied based on how an Authorised Person is operating: one identified rule applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch, while a different set of rules applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, the key obligation is an ongoing capital adequacy requirement. It must have Capital Resources that are at least equal to (or greater than) the amount of its Capital Requirement, and it must satisfy this condition at all times rather than only at specific checkpoints [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e]. In other words, once the Authorised Person is in the Domestic Firm operating category described in the Section, it is required to continuously maintain sufficient Capital Resources so that they never drop below its Capital Requirement. This ties the scope trigger (operating as a Domestic Firm under the Section’s applicability split) [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] directly to the substantive requirement (maintain Capital Resources equal to or exceeding Capital Requirement at all times) [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: Rules apply to an Authorised Person operating

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement

question: When the Regulator is engaging with Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators, what permission exists for the Regulator to co-operate with other persons (in ADGM or elsewhere) who have similar functions or Financial Crime prevention/detection functions, and how does that align with the stated cooperation, assistance and support framework for Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators?
expected_answer: The SOURCE establishes that the Regulator has specific authority to co-operate with other persons in ADGM or elsewhere where those persons have functions similar to those of the Regulator or functions related to the prevention or detection of Financial Crime, and that such co-operation may include sharing information that the Regulator is not prevented from lawfully disclosing [#SRC:30321c41-3b60-4c89-8840-ba67df61afaa]. The TARGET frames this in the cross-border supervisory context by describing “Cooperation, assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators” and noting the Regulator’s right to co operate with others [#TGT:fbe59cc5-3a41-487b-bb74-517451ef4558]. Read together, the permission to co-operate with relevant persons (including outside ADGM) provides the operational basis for delivering cooperation, assistance, and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators, while the lawful-disclosure limitation in the SOURCE clarifies that any information sharing within that cooperation must remain within what the Regulator can lawfully disclose. This pairing therefore supports a compliance interpretation that cooperation is permitted and can be information-enabled, but bounded by legal disclosure constraints, in service of assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators.

debug_context.semantic_hook: enables the Regulator to co-operate with other persons

answer_spans.text: Cooperation, assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators.

question: If the Regulator is helping Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators, what does the material say about the Regulator being allowed to work with other people (in ADGM or elsewhere), including sharing information, and how does that fit with the idea of cooperation, assistance and support to those Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators?
expected_answer: The SOURCE says the Regulator has specific authority to co-operate with other persons in ADGM or elsewhere when those persons have functions similar to the Regulator’s functions, or functions connected to preventing or detecting Financial Crime, and it adds that co-operation may include sharing information that the Regulator is not prevented from lawfully disclosing [#SRC:30321c41-3b60-4c89-8840-ba67df61afaa]. The TARGET describes the broader purpose and setting for that activity by referring to “Cooperation, assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators” and stating the Regulator’s right to co operate with others [#TGT:fbe59cc5-3a41-487b-bb74-517451ef4558]. Putting both together, the Regulator’s ability to co-operate with relevant persons (including outside ADGM) is a key mechanism for providing cooperation, assistance, and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators, and the SOURCE’s lawful-disclosure condition explains that information sharing is part of cooperation only to the extent the Regulator is legally able to disclose it. This combined reading supports practical coordination while keeping disclosure within legal limits.

question: When the Regulator proposes to exercise a power that triggers a warning notice requirement, what procedural framework must it follow and to whom must the warning notice be given before the power is exercised?
expected_answer: When the Regulator proposes to exercise any of the specified powers, it has two linked procedural duties. First, it must give a warning notice to any person in relation to whom the power is proposed to be exercised; this notice obligation applies across the listed categories of proposed actions (for example, decisions connected with granting, varying, cancelling or refusing a Financial Services Permission; withdrawing approval; refusing or conditioning approvals or applications; issuing Directions; publishing a statement; imposing a financial penalty; and other listed regulatory actions) [#TGT:360c3e8a-b2b5-4026-ac9c-7054a0f24530]. Second, where the Regulator proposes to exercise any of its powers within the scope described in the procedure passage, it must follow the procedure set out in Part 21 of FSMR, which sets out the steps the Regulator is required to follow for Part 21 Decisions to support a consistent approach to decision-making [#SRC:fabcfd4c-8eaa-4349-9d07-999f9ed0be48]. Read together, the warning notice is a required step directed to the affected person, and the broader sequencing and decision-making steps must be carried out under the Part 21 procedure before proceeding with the proposed exercise of power.

question: If the Regulator is planning to use one of the listed powers, what notice must it give, who gets it, and what set procedure must it follow while making that decision?
expected_answer: If the Regulator proposes to exercise any of the listed powers, it must give a warning notice, and it must give that warning notice to the person in relation to whom the power is proposed to be exercised [#TGT:360c3e8a-b2b5-4026-ac9c-7054a0f24530]. At the same time, when the Regulator proposes to exercise powers that fall within the scope described in the procedure passage, it must follow the procedure set out in Part 21 of FSMR [#SRC:fabcfd4c-8eaa-4349-9d07-999f9ed0be48]. That Part 21 procedure is described as setting out the steps the Regulator is required to follow for Part 21 Decisions, and it is intended to facilitate a consistent approach to decision-making [#SRC:fabcfd4c-8eaa-4349-9d07-999f9ed0be48]. Putting these together, the warning notice is the required communication to the affected person when a listed power is proposed, and the Regulator must also run the decision through the Part 21 steps that govern how it makes and processes those decisions [#TGT:360c3e8a-b2b5-4026-ac9c-7054a0f24530] [#SRC:fabcfd4c-8eaa-4349-9d07-999f9ed0be48].

question: In what circumstances may a Reporting Entity defer disclosure of information that will appear in a scheduled periodic or financial document, and how does that deferral sit within the scope of the continuous disclosure regime’s interaction with chapter 10 periodic/financial obligations and broader disclosure duties under FSMR and other applicable commercial and corporate laws?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity may, in limited circumstances, defer Disclosing information that is intended to be included in a scheduled document, where the Listing Authority does not generally expect early disclosure ahead of that document’s scheduled release date, provided the relevant conditions are satisfied (i.e., the limbs referenced for deferral are met) or the Listing Authority does not consider disclosure is required to prevent a false market. This permission to defer is not a blanket carve-out from continuous disclosure; rather, it operates within a framework where the continuous disclosure obligations are described as operating closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations in chapter 10 and with general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM), and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM), including disclosure in Prospectus Offer documents and other transaction-related statements. Accordingly, even when deferral is contemplated for a scheduled chapter 10 document, the Reporting Entity must remain alert that, during preparation of a financial disclosure, Inside Information may come to light that ought to be immediately Disclosed under the continuous disclosure obligation, notwithstanding the planned later publication. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]

debug_context.semantic_hook: does not generally expect a Reporting Entity to Disclose

answer_spans.text: HOW DOES RULE 7.

question: When can a Reporting Entity wait to disclose information until the planned release date of a periodic or financial document, and how does that fit with the continuous disclosure duty working alongside chapter 10 reports and other legal disclosure requirements (like FSMR and ADGM Commercial Laws)?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity can sometimes wait to Disclose information until the scheduled release date of the document where that information will appear, because the Listing Authority does not generally expect early disclosure in that situation. However, this is conditional: the deferral is only contemplated where the stated conditions for deferral are met or where the Listing Authority does not consider disclosure is required to prevent a false market. This timing flexibility must be understood in the broader scope of how continuous disclosure operates: the continuous disclosure obligations are said to operate closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations in chapter 10 and also with general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM), and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM), including disclosures in Prospectus Offer documents and other market documents. Importantly, even if the Reporting Entity is preparing a chapter 10 financial disclosure for later release, Inside Information may emerge during that preparation that ought to be immediately Disclosed under the continuous disclosure obligation, rather than being held back for the scheduled document. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and is therefore required to publish a prospectus, how should the Issuer manage the risk of misleading or deceptive statements or omissions in that prospectus, and in what circumstances could the Issuer rely on a defence based on information provided by another person?
expected_answer: Where an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities brings the offer within the applicable requirements for Offers of Securities, including an obligation to publish a prospectus [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. In preparing and publishing that prospectus, the Issuer should address the specific risk that the document (or related disclosures) could contain misleading or deceptive statements or omissions, because that is a distinct compliance concern highlighted alongside a potential defence [#TGT:c2dbe9d1-7386-4961-a367-1be69f10e457]. Practically, this means the Issuer should implement controls to ensure statements are not misleading and that material information is not omitted, and should document the basis for any statements sourced from third parties. If the Issuer has relied on information given by another person, the Issuer should be able to demonstrate that its reliance was reasonable in the circumstances to support the availability of the defence referenced in the target text [#TGT:c2dbe9d1-7386-4961-a367-1be69f10e457], while still meeting the prospectus publication obligation applicable to the offer [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd].

debug_context.semantic_hook: the obligation to publish a Prospectus under

answer_spans.text: Misleading and deceptive statements or omissions.

question: If an Issuer is making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and must publish a prospectus, what should the Issuer do to avoid misleading or deceptive statements or missing information, and when can it say it reasonably relied on information from someone else?
expected_answer: If an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer is subject to the requirements for Offers of Securities, which include an obligation to publish a prospectus [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. Because the target text flags the compliance risk of misleading and deceptive statements or omissions, the Issuer should treat accuracy and completeness as core requirements when preparing the prospectus and any related disclosures [#TGT:c2dbe9d1-7386-4961-a367-1be69f10e457]. In practice, the Issuer should check that statements are not misleading, ensure important information is not left out, and keep records showing how key facts were verified. Where the Issuer uses information supplied by another person, the target text indicates there may be a defence based on reasonable reliance on that information [#TGT:c2dbe9d1-7386-4961-a367-1be69f10e457]. To support that position, the Issuer should be able to show that relying on the other person’s information was reasonable in the circumstances, while still fulfilling the prospectus publication obligation that applies to the offer [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd].

debug_context.semantic_hook: the obligation to publish a Prospectus under

answer_spans.text: Misleading and deceptive statements or omissions.

question: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, what must it do, and how can the Regulator’s discretion to direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds affect the Captive Insurer’s available compliance options?
expected_answer: Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it has a mandatory choice: it must either establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds or notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. Separately, the Regulator has residual discretion and may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. Read together, the Captive Insurer’s obligation to choose between establishing funds or providing the written notification operates as the baseline compliance requirement, but the Regulator’s discretionary power can require establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds notwithstanding that baseline. Accordingly, even if the Captive Insurer would otherwise prefer to rely on the written notification that it is deemed a single Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must be prepared to comply with a direction to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for the relevant business or part of it.

answer_spans.text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.

question: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company has Long-Term Insurance Business that must sit in a Long-Term Insurance Fund, what does it have to do, and can the Regulator still require it to set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds?
expected_answer: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must take one of two required steps: either (a) establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds, or (b) notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. In addition to that required choice, the Regulator has a separate discretionary power: it may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of that business [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. This means the Captive Insurer cannot treat the written notification option as guaranteed in all cases. Even where the Captive Insurer would otherwise comply by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Regulator can still direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for the relevant business (or part of it), and the Captive Insurer must then align its actions with that direction.

answer_spans.text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company

question: When an Authorised Person is permitted to classify a Person as a Market Counterparty because the Person qualifies as a “deemed” Professional Client and the applicable requirements have been met, what steps must the Authorised Person take before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty regarding notice and any opportunity to request a different classification?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty only where the Person qualifies as a “deemed” Professional Client and the relevant requirements have been met [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. In addition to meeting those preconditions, the Authorised Person must complete specific procedural safeguards before making the classification where the Person is a Professional Client. Specifically, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, the Authorised Person must ensure the Person has been given a prior written notification that they will be classified as a Market Counterparty, and that the notice is framed either for a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction or for all Regulated Activities and Transactions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The Authorised Person must also ensure the Person has not requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in that notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. Taken together, the permission to classify is conditional on status and requirements, and the obligation requires advance written notice plus a chance to opt for a different classification within the stated period.

expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person seeks to classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, the classification is only permitted if the Person qualifies as a “deemed” Professional Client and the applicable requirements have been met [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Even when those conditions are satisfied, the Authorised Person must, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, ensure two further conditions are met. First, the Professional Client must have received a prior written notification of the intended classification as a Market Counterparty, and that notification must specify whether it applies in relation to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction or instead applies in respect of all Regulated Activities and Transactions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. Second, the Authorised Person must ensure the Professional Client has not requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. Accordingly, the Authorised Person’s ability to classify depends both on the Person’s qualifying status and requirements, and on completing the notice-and-no-objection process before the classification is made.

question: If an Authorised Person can classify a Person as a Market Counterparty only when the Person is a deemed Professional Client and the requirements have been met, what must the Authorised Person do before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is permitted to classify a Person as a Market Counterparty only if the Person qualifies as a “deemed” Professional Client and the relevant requirements have been met [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Before the Authorised Person actually classifies a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, the Authorised Person must also make sure the Professional Client has received a prior written notice saying they will be classified as a Market Counterparty [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. That notice must make clear whether the classification is for a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction, or whether it applies to all Regulated Activities and Transactions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. In practice, this means the Authorised Person needs both the underlying eligibility (deemed Professional Client plus requirements) and the procedural steps (written notice and no contrary request within the notice period) before treating the Professional Client as a Market Counterparty.

question: When an Authorised Person takes out and maintains professional indemnity insurance, what features must the cover have to be suitable for its business, what liabilities and costs should it address (including those arising from Employees), and what ongoing reporting and notification duties to the Regulator apply?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is expected to take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance that is appropriate to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and this obligation is ongoing rather than one-off [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]. In structuring that insurance, the cover should be arranged via a contract with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer, and it should include cover for claims for which the Authorised Person may be liable arising from the conduct of both itself and its Employees, together with appropriate cover for legal costs arising from a claim [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71]. In addition to maintaining the cover, the Authorised Person must provide the Regulator with a copy of the insurance at least annually for the following 12-month period and be able to demonstrate that the cover is adequate against its business profile [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]. It must also notify the Regulator of any material changes to that cover, including changes to the level of cover and any renewal or termination [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b].

It must also notify the Regulator of any material changes, including changes in the level of cover and any renewal or termination [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b].
