question: When a Reporting Entity is subject to the financial reporting obligation, what must it do to prepare and submit its annual financial report to the Regulator, and what standard governs the content and form of that report under both the governing framework and the Rules?
expected_answer: Both the governing framework and the Rules impose the same core obligation on a Reporting Entity regarding annual financial reporting. Under the governing framework, a Reporting Entity is required to prepare an annual financial report and file it with the Regulator, and it must do so in accordance with requirements that are prescribed in the Rules [#SRC:807de7e5-9f29-42d9-bf38-2e96beeea347]. The Rules restate and operationalize that obligation by specifying that the annual financial report must be prepared and filed with the Regulator and that the report must comply with the requirements prescribed in the Rules [#TGT:3bca170f-d68a-4646-be80-ea962f6c7a80]. Read together, the action is twofold—preparation and filing—and the compliance benchmark for how the report is prepared is the set of requirements prescribed in the Rules. Accordingly, a Reporting Entity should treat the Rules as the controlling source for the detailed requirements while ensuring the report is actually filed with the Regulator as part of the annual financial reporting duty reflected in both texts.

debug_context.semantic_hook: shall prepare and file with the Regulator

answer_spans.text:
Annual financial report
A Reporting Entity shall prepare and file with the Regulator an annual financial report in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules

question: What does a Reporting Entity have to do each year about its financial report, who must it be sent to, and what rules must it follow when preparing it under both texts?
expected_answer: Across both texts, the obligation is consistent and directed at the same actor. A Reporting Entity must (1) prepare an annual financial report and (2) file that annual financial report with the Regulator, meaning the report is not only created but also submitted to the Regulator as part of the annual process [#SRC:807de7e5-9f29-42d9-bf38-2e96beeea347]. In addition, both texts make clear that the way the annual financial report is prepared is not left to discretion: it must be prepared in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules [#TGT:3bca170f-d68a-4646-be80-ea962f6c7a80]. Put simply, the Reporting Entity’s yearly task is to produce the annual financial report, ensure it meets the requirements set out in the Rules, and then file it with the Regulator. The two passages align on the same required actions (prepare and file), the same recipient (the Regulator), and the same governing standard for preparation (the requirements prescribed in the Rules).

question: Where investments are made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets, how must an Authorised Person that falls within Category 1, 2 or 5 calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, including the required scope of positions and the permitted calculation approaches?
expected_answer: Where investments are made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets, an Authorised Person is required to calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with the applicable market risk framework [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e]. For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5, that calculation must cover commodity positions in both the Trading Book and the Non Trading Book, and it must be performed using one of two specified approaches [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]. Specifically, the Authorised Person must either apply its internal Market Risk model, provided that model has been approved by the Regulator for the purpose of calculating the Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, or it must apply the Rules set out in Section A6.5 [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]. Read together, these requirements mean that commodity-linked Musharaka or Mudaraba investments trigger the obligation to compute the Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, and for Category 1, 2 or 5 firms the computation must be executed across both books using an approved internal model or the prescribed ruleset [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe].

The firm may apply its internal Market Risk model only where that model has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose, which makes Regulator approval a condition precedent to using the internal-model approach [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]. Alternatively, if it does not use an approved internal model, it must apply the Rules set out in Section A6.5 to determine the requirement [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]. Accordingly, commodity-based Musharaka or Mudaraba investments create the need to compute the Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, and Category 1, 2 or 5 firms must ensure the computation spans both books and follows either an approved internal model or the specified rules [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe].

question: When assessing whether an offering of a digital/virtual token should be treated as a regulated Security, may the Regulator formally re-characterise the token as a Security by written notice, and how does that permission align with the FSRA’s case-by-case assessment approach and investor-protection rationale?
expected_answer: In the context of an offering of a digital/virtual token, the FSRA conducts an assessment on a case-by-case basis to determine whether the offering is regulated, applying an approach consistent with its treatment of conventional Securities and focused on investor protection where the token’s status may not be clear without review [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. Where that assessment indicates the token exhibits the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, the regulatory outcome contemplated is that the token is treated as a Security (i.e., as a “Digital Security”) following FSRA review [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. The TARGET text provides the operative permission for the Regulator to implement such a treatment decision by issuing a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, and it may attach terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. Read together, the FSRA’s procedural assessment and rationale supply the basis for the determination, while the Regulator’s written-notice power supplies the mechanism to give that determination formal effect, potentially with conditions tailored to the specific offering [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

If, through that review, the token is assessed to exhibit the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA’s approach is to treat the token as a Security (a “Digital Security”) following its assessment [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. Separately, the TARGET text confirms that the Regulator may, by written notice, deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, and may also exclude the application of any requirements, in each case subject to such terms and conditions as it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. Taken together, an Applicant should expect the FSRA’s case-by-case assessment to precede and inform whether the Regulator uses its written-notice powers to re-characterise the token and/or tailor the applicable requirements through exclusions and conditions, reflecting the specific facts of the offering [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

question: If a company is offering a digital/virtual token, can the Regulator decide it should be treated like a Security, and does that depend on the FSRA reviewing the token’s features case by case?
expected_answer: Yes. The FSRA describes its approach to an offering of a digital/virtual token as a case-by-case assessment of whether the offering is regulated, consistent with how it treats conventional Securities and driven by investor-protection concerns where the token’s status may not be clear without FSRA review [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. Under that approach, if the token being offered is assessed to exhibit the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA’s stated outcome is to treat the digital/virtual token as a Security (a “Digital Security”) following its assessment [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. The TARGET text provides the formal permission for the Regulator to implement that kind of outcome: by written notice, the Regulator may deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may impose terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. So, the FSRA’s review supplies the basis for deciding whether the token looks like a Security, and the Regulator’s written notice is the tool that can give that decision regulatory effect, potentially with conditions tailored to the offering [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

If the token is assessed to exhibit the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA’s approach is to treat the token as a Security (a “Digital Security”) following that assessment [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. The TARGET text then sets out what the Regulator can do by written notice: it may deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, and it may also exclude the application of any requirements [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. The same permission is expressly subject to such terms and conditions as the Regulator considers appropriate, meaning the notice can be tailored to the circumstances [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. Read together, the FSRA’s case-by-case review informs whether the token should be treated as a Security, and the Regulator’s notice power can both apply that treatment and adjust requirements, with conditions, to fit the specific offering [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

question: In what circumstances may the Regulator revoke a Direction or vary it, and whose application or consent is required for a variation where the Direction applies/relates to a particular person?
expected_answer: Across both passages, the permission is framed around two distinct actions concerning a Direction: revocation and variation. First, the Regulator is permitted to revoke a Direction without any stated precondition tied to an application or consent in either text, indicating revocation is available as a standalone regulatory option. Second, variation is permitted only where there is a procedural trigger connected to the person affected by the Direction: the variation may be made on the application of that person or with that person’s consent. The SOURCE expresses this as varying a Direction “on the application of, or with the consent of, the person to whom it applies,” while the TARGET mirrors the same condition by referring to “the person to whom it relates.” Read together, the consistent requirement is that a variation depends on either an application from, or consent by, the person the Direction applies/relates to, whereas revocation does not carry that stated condition. This aligns the Regulator’s powers and the affected person’s role in initiating or agreeing to a change. [#SRC:80551e2c-3255-4e5d-a299-9a7e3074be88] [#TGT:7bdefcca-c5ac-4d6b-8197-8d5f24109ebf]

debug_context.semantic_hook: revoke a Direction; or vary a Direction

answer_spans.text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	revoke a Direction; or
(b)	vary it on the application, or with the consent, of the person to whom it relates

question: When can the Regulator cancel a Direction, and when can it change a Direction only if the person it applies/relates to asks for it or agrees?
expected_answer: Both texts describe what the Regulator is allowed to do with a Direction, and they draw the same line between cancelling it and changing it. On the one hand, the Regulator may revoke (cancel) a Direction; neither passage adds any extra condition such as needing an application or consent for that revocation. On the other hand, changing (varying) a Direction is permitted only if the person affected by the Direction is involved in one of two ways: either that person applies for the change, or that person consents to it. The SOURCE states the variation can occur “on the application of, or with the consent of, the person to whom it applies,” and the TARGET uses equivalent wording by referring to “the person to whom it relates.” Taken together, the practical rule is: revocation is available as a direct option for the Regulator, but variation requires a request from, or agreement by, the person the Direction is about. This ensures the affected person has a defined role in any modification. [#SRC:80551e2c-3255-4e5d-a299-9a7e3074be88] [#TGT:7bdefcca-c5ac-4d6b-8197-8d5f24109ebf]

debug_context.semantic_hook: revoke a Direction; or vary a Direction

answer_spans.text:

question: When compiling the Resolution Pack, how must an Authorised Person identify individuals (within the Authorised Person or elsewhere) who are critical or important to operational functions, particularly where those functions relate to Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Asset reconciliations or client documentation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must include in its Resolution Pack a document that identifies all senior manager, directors and other individuals, and the nature of their responsibility, where those individuals (within the Authorised Person or elsewhere) are critical or important to the performance of operational functions related to obligations imposed on the Authorised Person by the chapter [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. In determining which individuals fall within this “critical or important” category for operational functions, the Authorised Person should treat as in-scope, at a minimum, individuals necessary to carry out both internal and external Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Asset reconciliations, as well as those in charge of client documentation involving Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1]. Practically, the identification should therefore cover the relevant roles and name the individuals (or otherwise clearly identify them) and describe their responsibilities in relation to these reconciliation and documentation functions, including where such responsibilities sit outside the Authorised Person (for example, with individuals “elsewhere”) but remain critical to the operational performance of the Authorised Person’s obligations.

question: In its Resolution Pack, what does an Authorised Person need to write down about people who are critical to key operational work, like doing Client Money/Relevant Money/Safe Custody Asset reconciliations or handling client documentation?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must put into its Resolution Pack a document that identifies all senior manager, directors and other individuals who are critical or important to operational functions, and it must also describe the nature of each person’s responsibility, including where the person is within the Authorised Person or elsewhere [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. To decide who counts as “critical or important” for these operational functions, the Authorised Person should include (as examples of in-scope individuals) those necessary to carry out both internal and external Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Asset reconciliations, and those in charge of client documentation involving Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1]. So, the Resolution Pack should not just list names; it should connect each identified person to the relevant operational function (reconciliations and/or client documentation) and explain what they are responsible for, so that the operational dependencies tied to Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets are clearly mapped.

question: How must a firm and an Authorised Person ensure their risk management arrangements are designed and maintained so they provide the practical capability to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor risks, including in a way that can be evaluated through internal self-assessment and supervisory review?
expected_answer: A firm must ensure its risk management systems provide it with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control its risks, and it should be able to evidence this capability through its own internal risk self-assessment and the controls and mitigation programmes it has in place, which may be reviewed as part of an external assessment of how those risks impact supervisory objectives and the likelihood of occurrence [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]. In parallel, an Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls that enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks, meaning the arrangements must be operationally effective and kept current rather than being a one-off design exercise [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21]. Read together, the obligations require both the existence and ongoing maintenance of systems and controls, and that those systems demonstrably provide the tools and processes needed to manage risks across the full lifecycle from identification and assessment through mitigation, control, and monitoring, with documentation and self-assessment supporting reviewability.

question: What must a firm and an Authorised Person put in place and keep up to date so they can identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor their risks, and so that their own risk self-assessment and controls can be reviewed?
expected_answer: A firm must make sure its risk management systems actually give it the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control its risks, and it should be able to show this through its internal risk self-assessment and by explaining what controls and mitigation programmes it has in place for each risk, since these may be reviewed alongside an external assessment of risk impact, likelihood, and alignment with supervisory objectives [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]. Separately but consistently, an Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls that enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks, which emphasizes both implementation and ongoing upkeep of the systems and controls [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21]. Taken together, the requirements mean the organisation must have functioning risk processes and controls that cover the full set of risk management steps, and it must maintain them in a way that supports credible self-assessment and effective review of how risks are managed in practice.

question: Where an applicant intends to carry on a Regulated Activity and the client is a Retail Client, what requirements must an Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission satisfy in relation to systems and controls, COBS compliance arrangements, Employee competence, and Complaints handling?
expected_answer: Where an applicant intends to carry on a Regulated Activity and the client is a Retail Client, the requirements apply to an Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission to carry on that Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884]. In that scoped scenario, the applicant must have adequate systems and controls for carrying on Regulated Activities with or for a Retail Client. The applicant must also maintain adequate systems and controls, including policies and procedures, designed to ensure compliance with the requirements in COBS that are relevant to Retail Clients. In addition, the applicant must have adequate systems and controls to ensure that its Employees remain competent and capable to perform the functions assigned to them, with particular focus on functions that involve dealing with Retail Clients. Finally, the applicant must have adequate Complaints handling policies and procedures. Together, these obligations set the minimum operational, compliance, competence, and complaints framework that must be in place as part of the application to carry on the Regulated Activity where the Retail Client condition is met [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884].

question: Where an Authorised Person has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities, what annual supervision fee must it pay to the Regulator, and in what circumstances may the Regulator also impose an additional supplementary fee related to the branch’s jurisdictional regulatory cooperation arrangements?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to the Regulated Activities it undertakes from that branch, with the initial supervision fee to be prorated and paid in the manner specified for initial payments [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c]. In addition to this required annual supervision fee, the Regulator is permitted to charge a supplementary fee on top of the otherwise specified fees where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction in which there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. Accordingly, the compliance outcome is twofold: the annual supervision fee is mandatory for the qualifying branch activity, while the supplementary fee is a conditional, jurisdiction-driven add-on that may apply depending on the adequacy of cross-regulator cooperation arrangements for the branch location.

expected_answer: If an Authorised Person has established a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from that branch, it must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities it carries on from the branch, and the first supervision fee is to be prorated and paid following the applicable initial payment approach [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c]. Separately, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee in addition to the otherwise specified fees when the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. In practical terms, the annual supervision fee is the baseline required payment for operating the outside-ADGM branch, while the supplementary fee is an additional amount that can be imposed only if the branch’s jurisdiction lacks adequate regulatory cooperation arrangements with the Regulator.

question: When establishing effective arrangements to monitor and enforce compliance with its rules (including, for a Recognised Investment Exchange, monitoring transactions to detect disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse), what procedures must a Recognised Body also include to ensure complaints about the conduct of Persons using its facilities are properly handled and escalated where necessary?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body must design its overall compliance framework so that the “effective arrangements” it maintains for monitoring and enforcing compliance with its rules (and, where it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, for monitoring transactions to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse) are complemented by formal complaint-handling procedures. Specifically, the arrangements must include procedures for investigating complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons in the course of using the Recognised Body’s facilities, ensuring that potential misconduct identified through complaints can be examined alongside issues detected through rule monitoring and transaction surveillance [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]. In addition, the arrangements must include procedures for the fair, independent and impartial resolution of appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body, so that enforcement or other decisions taken under the rules are subject to an appropriate appeal mechanism within the same governance structure [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]. Together, these elements ensure monitoring/enforcement is not only proactive (through surveillance) but also responsive (through complaint investigation and impartial appeals).

question: A Recognised Body must monitor and enforce compliance with its rules (and if it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, monitor transactions to spot disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse). The arrangements must also include procedures for the fair, independent and impartial resolution of appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body, ensuring that when the Recognised Body makes a decision—potentially following monitoring, enforcement action, or a complaint investigation—there is a defined route for an impartial review of that decision [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]. These requirements together link surveillance and enforcement with complaint investigation and an independent appeal process.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target, what must it include about the Production Target and the assumptions used, including how it must address any commercially sensitive material economic assumptions and the required breakdown and cautionary statements where the Production Target relies on Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must also include the full set of information required for that Production Target disclosure. This means the disclosure must cover all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions used, and if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology used to determine those assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. In addition, the Production Target disclosure must state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if so, that the pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, and it must specify the proportions of the Production Target attributable to Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target. It must also include the required statements addressing that Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target are not determining factors in viability and do not feature significantly in the early mine plan, plus the prescribed prominent cautionary statements and supporting explanations/technical study requirements where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].

debug_context.semantic_hook: disclosure pursuant to ust include

answer_spans.text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information and that forecast is based on a Production Target, what information must it include about the assumptions and the Production Target, especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive or if the Production Target uses Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, its disclosure must include the Production Target that the forecast is derived from, and it must also include the required information that accompanies a Production Target disclosure [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. On assumptions, it must disclose all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions used; if it considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. For the Production Target itself, it must state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if they were, confirm those forecast prices were arrived at on reasonable grounds. It must also break down the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, and include the required prominent cautionary statements and related explanations where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target, including the additional support requirements when it is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].

question: Where an Authorised Person operating an MTF seeks to become a Recognised Investment Exchange, what must it do with its FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order, and under what condition may the Recognised Investment Exchange continue to operate an MTF or OTF under that Recognition Order?
expected_answer: When an Authorised Person that is operating an MTF wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, it must relinquish its FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764]. After it becomes a Recognised Investment Exchange, it may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF only if its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]. The Source further indicates that, where the FSRA licenses the firm to carry out both activities (for example, operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the relevant Recognition Order will include a stipulation to that effect, aligning the permission to operate the MTF/OTF with the Recognition Order’s terms [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764]. If such a stipulation is included, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS apply to that function, but only to that function, reinforcing that the permission is conditional and scoped to the MTF/OTF activity [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].

After it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, it can operate an MTF or OTF only if its Recognition Order contains a specific stipulation that permits that activity [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]. If the stipulation is included, the rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS apply to the MTF/OTF function only, meaning the additional requirements attach specifically to that permitted function rather than to all of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s activities [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].

question: Where the record-keeping requirements for AML purposes apply in relation to the specified AML Rulebook provision, what must a Relevant Person do to ensure its money laundering risk assessment is properly documented and kept current, and how does that obligation interact with the need to review risks arising from its business, customers, products and services?
expected_answer: Because the record-keeping requirements for AML purposes are expressly set out as applying in relation to the specified AML Rulebook provision, a Relevant Person must treat documentation and retention of its risk-based assessment as an integral part of its compliance approach within that scoped application [#SRC:34201eec-cbf5-469f-a0c2-759935e137f1]. In practice, the Relevant Person must first assess and address its money laundering risks by reviewing the risks it is exposed to due to the nature of its business, customers, products, services, and any other relevant matters in the money laundering context [#TGT:8112ad15-b59b-429c-b290-deaa07c5363d]. It must then ensure that any risk-based assessment undertaken for AML Rulebook compliance is objective and proportionate to the risks, based on reasonable grounds, properly documented, and updated at appropriate intervals [#TGT:8112ad15-b59b-429c-b290-deaa07c5363d]. The scope linkage to the record-keeping requirements means the documentation element is not optional or incidental: it is part of meeting the AML Rulebook’s requirements for the purposes covered by those record-keeping rules [#SRC:34201eec-cbf5-469f-a0c2-759935e137f1].

It also must make sure the assessment is properly documented and updated at appropriate intervals [#TGT:8112ad15-b59b-429c-b290-deaa07c5363d]. Because the record-keeping rules set requirements for AML purposes, the “properly documented” element should be treated as a required compliance output within that scoped application, not just an internal working note [#SRC:34201eec-cbf5-469f-a0c2-759935e137f1].

question: Where the Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral amendments to the Governing Contract and proposes to do so, what must the Third Party Provider communicate to the Customer about deemed acceptance unless the Customer objects, and by when must the proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or other specified contractual information be provided before they take effect?
expected_answer: When the Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes to implement those changes, it must inform the Customer that the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed date the changes enter into force [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. In parallel, for any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or to the specified contractual information, the Third Party Provider must provide those proposed changes to the Customer no later than two months before the date on which they are to take effect [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. Read together, the Third Party Provider’s obligations cover both (i) the content of the notice—making clear the default outcome if the Customer does not object by the entry-into-force date—and (ii) the timing of delivery—ensuring the Customer receives the proposed changes at least two months in advance of their effective date, so the Customer has a defined window to respond before the changes take effect.

debug_context.semantic_hook: must inform the Customer that unless the Customer notifies

answer_spans.text: Changes in contractual information.

question: If the Third Party Provider wants to change the Governing Contract on its own, what must it tell the Customer about what happens if the Customer does not object, and how far in advance must it send the proposed changes before they start to apply?
expected_answer: If the Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes to do so, it must tell the Customer that the Customer will be considered to have accepted the changes unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed date the changes take effect [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. Separately, the Third Party Provider must also meet a minimum advance-notice timing requirement for the delivery of the proposed changes themselves: any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract, or to the specified contractual information, must be provided to the Customer no later than two months before the date on which the changes are to take effect [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. Together, these requirements mean the Customer should receive the proposed changes at least two months ahead of the effective date, and the notice must clearly explain that silence will be treated as acceptance unless the Customer actively objects before the effective date.

question: For purposes of determining when quarterly cash reporting may be imposed, how should the assets eligibility test be defined for an Applicant, and in what scope of admissions will the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to provide quarterly cash reports (including where the admission resembles a cash-box)?
expected_answer: The assets eligibility test is a defined admission basis that applies to an Applicant and is met only where the Applicant satisfies the requirements that make up that test [#TGT:86469cd3-cfcc-448c-b4e2-e50bf2d32f91]. In scope, the Regulator’s general approach is to require a Reporting Entity to provide quarterly cash reports in connection with an admission to the Official List where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted is admitted under the assets eligibility test, where it has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed, or where the Regulator considers—on other grounds—that quarterly cash reporting is needed, including admissions that function like a cash-box [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. Read together, the definition establishes what it means for an Applicant to be proceeding under the assets eligibility test, while the scope statement explains that this admission pathway is one of the key triggers for the Regulator’s expectation that quarterly cash reports will be produced by the Reporting Entity, alongside the audited-financial-history and other risk-based circumstances.

question: What does the assets eligibility test mean for an Applicant, and when will the Regulator usually make a Reporting Entity file quarterly cash reports for an admission (including a cash-box type admission)?

The Regulator will generally require quarterly cash reports from a Reporting Entity in admissions to the Official List where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted is admitted under that assets eligibility test, where the Listed Entity has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed, or where the Regulator decides for other reasons that quarterly cash reporting is needed—explicitly including situations like the admission of a cash-box [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. question: When a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears to the Regulator to be proposing to take, or may take, such action, may the Regulator issue a direction requiring the Recognised Body not to act, and what consultation and satisfaction steps must be completed beforehand?
expected_answer: Yes. Where a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body is proposing to take or may take action, the Regulator is permitted to issue a “negative” direction (i.e., a direction not to take action) [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e]. However, before giving such a direction, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator must not give the direction unless, in light of that consultation, the Regulator is satisfied that at least one of the specified grounds is met [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]. Those grounds are that taking action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other market participants; or that the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or that the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3].

debug_context.semantic_hook: the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body

answer_spans.text: may issue a "negative" direction (not to take action)

question: If a Recognised Body has not used its Default Rules yet, but the Regulator thinks it is about to act, can the Regulator tell it not to act? What does the Regulator have to do first?
expected_answer: Yes. If a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body is proposing to take or may take action, the Regulator may issue a “negative” direction telling the Recognised Body not to take action [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e]. Before the Regulator gives that direction, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body in question [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]. After that consultation, the Regulator is not allowed to give the direction unless it is satisfied (based on what comes out of the consultation) that one of the listed reasons applies [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]. Those reasons are: the action would be premature or otherwise undesirable for investors or other market participants; or the direction is necessary in the public interest for the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3].

question: Under the Markets Rules framework, when is a person prohibited from making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and how does that prohibition apply specifically to Issuers offering to the Public in or from ADGM unless the offer is made in accordance with the applicable rule set?
expected_answer: Both passages impose a prohibition framed as “shall not” on conduct involving Offers of Securities and admissions to trading, and they must be read together to identify both the general and Issuer-specific constraints. The TARGET states that a person “shall not” make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, except as provided by or under these Regulations [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]. The SOURCE explains the Markets Rules context and specifies that Section 58(1) of FSMR prohibits Issuers from making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (or to have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE) other than in accordance with FSMR and MKT [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237]. Taken together, the prohibition applies to any person’s offer or admission activity in ADGM, while clarifying that Issuers, in particular, are barred from public offers in or from ADGM (and related RIE admissions) unless the activity is conducted in accordance with FSMR, MKT, and the Regulations’ permitted exceptions.

debug_context.semantic_hook: prohibits Issuers from making an Offer of Securities

answer_spans.text: shall not

question: Who must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and what does the Markets Rules text add about Issuers making an offer to the Public in or from ADGM unless it follows the required framework?
expected_answer: The TARGET sets a broad rule that a person “shall not” make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies “as provided by or under these Regulations” [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]. The SOURCE adds the Markets Rules framing and narrows the focus to Issuers by stating that Section 58(1) of FSMR prohibits Issuers from making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (or to have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE) other than in accordance with FSMR and MKT [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237]. Read together, the combined effect is that the default position is prohibition for any person engaging in an offer in ADGM or seeking admission on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and Issuers are specifically prohibited from public offers in or from ADGM (and related RIE admissions) unless they comply with the FSMR/MKT framework and fall within the Regulations’ permitted carve-outs.

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether its Financial Services Permission places it in Category 2 versus Category 3C, where it is authorised for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and also has permissions that could include Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services? In particular, how do the respective exclusion tests against other Categories and the scope limitation condition for dealing affect the classification outcome?
expected_answer: To classify an Authorised Person, start with what its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on and then apply the category-specific conditions and exclusions. Category 2 applies where the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (including Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm satisfies the Category 2 conditions, it is excluded from Category 3C by Category 3C’s express “does not meet Category 2” requirement; if it does not satisfy Category 2 (including because the dealing scope condition is not met), it may fall within Category 3C if it meets the listed-activity limb and the broader exclusion set.

question: If an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission lets it do Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal, but it is also authorised for things like Managing Assets or Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), how do you decide whether it is Category 2 or Category 3C? What role do the “not limited in scope” dealing condition and the “must not meet other Categories” tests play?
expected_answer: You decide by matching the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission to the category tests and then applying the “must not meet other Categories” exclusions. Category 2 is triggered when the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the firm’s dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. Category 3C is triggered when the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. So, if the firm meets Category 2 (including the “not limited in scope” condition), it cannot be Category 3C because Category 3C excludes firms that meet Category 2. If it does not meet Category 2, then Category 3C remains possible, but only if it meets the listed-activity requirement and none of the excluded categories apply.

question: How does the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, as a component used to calculate the Capital Requirement, affect when an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator and provide written confirmation if its Capital Resources drop below the required threshold?
expected_answer: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum matters because it is expressly identified as a component used in calculating an entity’s Capital Requirement, and that Capital Requirement is the benchmark against which the notification trigger is measured [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the obligation to notify is activated when its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement; once that condition is met, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the notification in writing [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum feeds into the calculation of the Capital Requirement, it is relevant to determining whether the 120% threshold has been breached and therefore whether the notification and written confirmation duties are triggered [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. In practice, the Authorised Person should ensure it is using the correct Capital Requirement calculation (including this component) when assessing its Capital Resources against the 120% test, so it can meet the immediate notification and written follow-up requirements if the threshold is crossed [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d].

The notification duty itself applies to an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 when its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement; at that point, it must notify the Regulator immediately and also confirm the notification in writing [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. Because the trigger is expressed as a percentage of the Capital Requirement, the way the Capital Requirement is calculated—including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum—directly affects whether the 120% threshold is met or breached [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. So, when the Authorised Person assesses its position, it should calculate its Capital Requirement using the required components and then compare its Capital Resources to 120% of that figure to determine whether it must make the immediate notification and written confirmation to the Regulator [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d].

question: When a Listed Entity issues Securities under a dividend or distribution plan, or under an agreement to Underwrite a shortfall where the issue is made within 15 Business Days after the dividend or distribution payment date and the underwriting details were disclosed before that payment date, what must a Reporting Entity do to disclose the required matters, and under which disclosure framework must it do so?
expected_answer: Where the circumstances involve an issue of Securities under (a) a dividend or distribution plan, or (b) an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall on such a plan, the scope is limited to cases in which (for the underwriting scenario) details of the Underwriting agreement were Disclosed prior to the date for payment of the dividend or distribution, and the Listed Entity makes the issue within 15 Business Days after the date for payment of the dividend or distribution [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558]. In that context, the applicable obligation on the Reporting Entity is that it must Disclose the matters specified in APP 2, and it must do so in accordance with Rule 7.7.1 [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326]. Read together, the source defines the relevant transaction timing and conditions (including the 15 Business Days deadline tied to the payment date and the prior disclosure of underwriting details), while the target sets the required disclosure action and the governing disclosure mechanism (Rule 7.7.1) for the APP 2 matters that must be Disclosed.

question: When a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, what must it do with the results of its stress tests in assessing its total financial resources, and how does the applicability of that obligation depend on the service scope described?
expected_answer: Where a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, the relevant requirements applicable to it include the stress testing of capital framework identified for that service scope [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]. Within that applicable framework, the Recognised Clearing House must take the outputs of its stress tests and use them as an input to a concrete assessment of whether its total financial resources are adequate. It is not sufficient to run stress tests as a standalone exercise; the results must be applied to evaluate overall resource sufficiency and, based on that evaluation, the Recognised Clearing House must make adjustments where appropriate [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e]. Read together, the scope statement ties the obligation to the context of providing Central Counterparty Services, while the obligation specifies the required action: use stress test results to assess adequacy and then adjust total financial resources as warranted by those results. This links stress testing directly to ongoing financial resource calibration for a Recognised Clearing House operating in that service capacity.

question: When calculating RWA for Credit Risk Exposures, how must an Authorised Person sequence the categorisation of an Exposure for determining the applicable risk weight and completing the RWA(CR) calculation across on-balance sheet and off balance sheet assets?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person calculating RWA for Credit Risk Exposures must follow a defined sequence that links Exposure categorisation to the determination of the applicable risk weight used in the RWA formula. First, it calculates the Exposure value (E) for each on-balance sheet and off balance sheet asset using the specified Exposure measurement methodology and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM. It must then categorise each Exposure under the relevant categorisation framework, which exists to categorise Exposures for the purpose of determining the CRW for CR Exposures [#SRC:4c9a1a36-5ca7-420b-a5ce-f389fcb68c1f]. After categorisation, the Authorised Person allocates an applicable Credit Quality Grade and risk weight for that Exposure in accordance with the applicable Rules, so that the CRW is determined based on the categorisation and the credit quality/risk weight allocation steps. It then calculates the RWA amount for each Exposure using RWA(CR) = E x CRW, where CRW is the applicable risk weight determined through those categorisation and allocation steps, and finally aggregates the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].

question: In simple terms, what steps must an Authorised Person follow to sort (categorise) each Credit Risk Exposure so it can determine the right risk weight and then calculate total RWA for all CR Exposures?
expected_answer: To calculate total RWA for Credit Risk Exposures, an Authorised Person must apply a step-by-step process that uses categorisation to arrive at the correct risk weight. It starts by calculating the Exposure value (E) for every on-balance sheet and off balance sheet asset using the required Exposure measurement methodology and taking into account any applicable CRM. Next, it categorises each Exposure using the relevant categorisation Rules; this categorisation framework is specifically designed to categorise Exposures for the purpose of determining the CRW for CR Exposures [#SRC:4c9a1a36-5ca7-420b-a5ce-f389fcb68c1f]. After the Exposure is categorised, the Authorised Person assigns an applicable Credit Quality Grade and then the risk weight for that Exposure under the applicable Rules, which together determine the CRW used in the calculation. It then calculates the risk-weighted amount for each Exposure using the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, and finally adds up the RWA amounts for all of its CR Exposures to produce the total RWA figure [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].

question: In the context of an investigation, when may the Investigator compel attendance at an interview and questioning, and does that authority extend beyond the Person Under Investigation to other individuals regardless of any connection to that person, provided the requirement is issued by written notice?
expected_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to compel a person to attend an interview and answer questions as part of an investigation, and the mechanism and scope are clarified. The TARGET then specifies how and to whom that power may be directed: the Investigator may do so by written notice, and the notice may be addressed either to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, expressly including persons who are not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the Investigator’s permission is not limited to the subject of the investigation; it can reach third parties, and it is exercisable through a written notice that can require attendance at a specified time and place and answering questions. This combined reading supports compliance planning for both primary subjects and potential third-party interviewees.

question: For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, when must it apply the restriction in APP 7, and in what circumstances are specified APP 7 restriction categories treated as not applying unless the Regulator decides otherwise?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities is required to apply the restriction in APP 7, or comply with such other restrictions as the Regulator decides in its discretion [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f]. However, the scope of that obligation is qualified by an express carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that meets any of the stated conditions [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Those conditions are that the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to the specified admission basis, (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (3) in the opinion of the Regulator has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Accordingly, the Listed Entity must look to both the general requirement to apply APP 7 restrictions and the Regulator-dependent exceptions that can remove certain APP 7 categories from application.

answer_spans.text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction.

question: If a Listed Entity has issued or plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply the APP 7 restriction, or are there cases where some APP 7 restriction categories do not apply unless the Regulator says they do?
expected_answer: When a Listed Entity has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, it must apply the restriction in APP 7, or follow other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose in its discretion [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f]. But the Target text narrows when certain APP 7 restrictions apply: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that meets at least one of three criteria [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Those criteria are: the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under the stated admission route; it has a profitability or revenue track record that is acceptable to the Regulator; or, in the Regulator’s opinion, it has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of its total asset value [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. So, the general “must apply” obligation exists, but whether particular APP 7 categories apply depends on these conditions and on whether the Regulator decides otherwise.

question: When an Authorised Person identifies that it does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the capital needed to meet its ongoing Tier 1 Capital and minimum Leverage Ratio requirement, what notification must it provide to the Regulator, in what form, and how quickly must it be made?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person has two linked obligations: it must continuously maintain sufficient Tier 1 Capital so that, at all times, it meets a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% (or a different level if the Regulator sets one) [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. If, at any time, the Authorised Person does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the amount and quality of capital necessary to comply with that capital requirement, it must notify the Regulator immediately and the notification must be in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. Practically, this means the trigger for notification is not limited to an actual breach of the leverage ratio; it also includes a forward-looking likelihood that the Authorised Person will not have the required capital to sustain the minimum leverage ratio on an ongoing basis. The required action is a written notice to the Regulator, and the timing standard is immediate once the Authorised Person becomes aware of the shortfall or likely shortfall.

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital to maintain, at all times, a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% or as otherwise set by the Regulator

question: How should an Authorised Person reconcile its duty to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio through sufficient Tier 1 Capital with its duty to alert the Regulator where its capital position may no longer support that requirement, including the timing and medium of any alert?
expected_answer: The framework imposes an ongoing prudential maintenance duty and a separate escalation duty. First, an Authorised Person must hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital to ensure it maintains, at all times, a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3%, unless the Regulator sets a different minimum [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. Second, if at any time the Authorised Person does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the amount and quality of capital necessary to comply with that requirement, it must notify the Regulator immediately in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. Read together, the Authorised Person must monitor its capital position against the leverage ratio standard on a continuous basis and treat both an actual inability and a likely future inability to maintain sufficient Tier 1 Capital as a reportable event. The notification obligation is not discretionary and is not delayed until the ratio is actually missed; it is triggered by the existence of a shortfall or the likelihood of one, and it must be communicated promptly and in written form to the Regulator.

If, at any time, the Authorised Person does not have, or is likely not to have, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with that requirement, it has to tell the Regulator right away and it must do so in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. This means the duty to notify is triggered not only when the leverage ratio requirement is already being missed, but also when the Authorised Person expects it may not be able to keep enough capital to meet the requirement going forward. The required action is a written notification, and the timing is immediate once the issue (or likely issue) exists.

Put simply, the first duty is to keep enough Tier 1 Capital to meet the leverage ratio continuously, and the second duty is to send a written, immediate notice to the Regulator as soon as there is an actual or likely capital shortfall against that requirement.

question: When conducting an investigation, in what circumstances may the Investigator compel the Person Under Investigation or another person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide information, and what kinds of material can fall within the scope of “information” for that purpose?
expected_answer: The Investigator is permitted to compel information by issuing a written notice to the person who is the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring that person to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This permission aligns with the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. For scope, “information” is to be interpreted broadly in its ordinary meaning and can include multiple forms of content, not limited to formal documents. It may encompass knowledge communicated or received about a matter, fact, or circumstance; knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction; and data produced or handled by a computer at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It can also include an explanation or statement about a matter, identification of a person/matter/thing, and a response to a question, which complements the ability to require answers in an interview setting [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to—
(a)	attend an interview at a Specifie

expected_answer: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, and may also require that person to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This sits alongside the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. In assessing whether a request is properly treated as “information” (as distinct from a request to “produce… Documents”), the key is that “information” is intended to be broad and not confined to documentary production. It can include knowledge about facts or circumstances, knowledge gained through professional or other activities, and computer-related data at any stage of processing (including stored or transmitted data) [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It also includes explanations or statements, identification details, and responses to questions—meaning that oral or written answers, clarifications, and identifications can fall within “information” even where no specific document is being produced [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

expected_answer: A written notice can require more than just documents. The Investigator may require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide such information as the Investigator may require, and may also require the person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information is intended to be broad [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. “Information” can include knowledge about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work or study. It also includes data obtained as output from a computer through processing, and any data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. Beyond data, it can include an explanation or statement, identification details, and a response to a question. That means the Investigator’s interview-and-questions power and the information-request power work together: the “information” requested can be provided as answers, explanations, identifications, or relevant computer data, not only as produced documents [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

debug_context.semantic_hook: empowers the Investigator to require a person to give

answer_spans.text:
The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to—
(a)	attend an interview at a Specifie

question: When an Authorised Person has Non Trading Book assets or liabilities denominated in multiple currencies, how must it determine which currencies are treated as material for purposes of measuring interest rate risk Exposure, and what evaluation and measurement steps must follow for those currencies?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must first identify which currencies qualify as “material currencies” by applying the threshold that each currency accounting for 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or Non Trading Book liabilities should be treated as a material currency Exposure [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28]. Using that definition to set the scope, the Authorised Person must then carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. In addition, because it has positions in different currencies, it must measure its risk Exposures in each of the currencies that meet the materiality criterion, rather than only on an aggregated basis [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Practically, this means the evaluation of interest rate risk must be supported by currency-by-currency measurement for every currency that reaches or exceeds the 5% share of Non Trading Book assets or liabilities, ensuring the assessment captures the relevant exposures in those material currencies [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28].

debug_context.semantic_hook: each currency accounting for 5% or more

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities

question: If an Authorised Person’s Non Trading Book includes more than one currency, which currencies must it treat as “material,” and what must it do next to assess interest rate risk in those currencies?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must decide which currencies are “material” by using the criterion that any currency making up 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or its Non Trading Book liabilities should be considered a material currency Exposure [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28]. Once those material currencies are identified, the Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Because the positions are in different currencies, it also must measure its risk Exposures separately in each of the material currencies, rather than treating all currencies as one combined exposure [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. In effect, the 5% threshold determines which currencies trigger the more detailed, currency-specific measurement that supports the required interest rate risk evaluation for the Non Trading Book [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28].

question: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how must it deliver the refusal notification to the Customer, and what must the Governing Contract include to evidence the agreed means of communication for transmitting such notifications (including any technical requirements)?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to notify of a refusal and must deliver that refusal notification in the manner that has been agreed for such communications [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. To ensure that this “agreed manner” is clear and operational for the Customer, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer, set out the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, including any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive them [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. In practice, this links the delivery obligation for refusal notifications to the contractually documented communication channel(s) and any prerequisites for receipt. The contract must also address the manner and frequency with which information under the relevant chapter is to be provided or made available, supporting consistent delivery of refusal notifications through the agreed communication arrangements [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

(a)	about the Thi

question: If a Third Party Provider intends to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, what must it do when it refuses a Third Party Transaction, and how must the Governing Contract address both the reservation of that right and the agreed notification method?
expected_answer: Where a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must provide a notification of the refusal and must do so using the agreed manner for delivering that notification [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. Separately, if the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, the Governing Contract must include the conditions under which it proposes to reserve that right, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. The same Governing Contract must also document the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications (and any relevant technical requirements), which provides the contractual basis for what constitutes the “agreed manner” for refusal notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Together, these obligations require that the refusal event is both contractually anticipated (through stated conditions for stopping/preventing execution) and operationally communicated to the Customer through the contractually agreed notification channel [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

The Governing Contract must include the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, and it must also cover any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive those notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. First, it must include the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, so the Customer can understand when a refusal may happen [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Second, it must include the agreed means of communication for sending information or notifications (and any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software), which defines how the refusal notification will be delivered in practice [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Taken together, the contract explains both the basis for stopping/preventing execution and the agreed channel for communicating the refusal to the Customer [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: When an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a qualifying multilateral development bank, what risk weight must be applied, and in what way may guarantees from MDBs be recognised as eligible credit risk mitigation in relation to that exposure?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a qualifying multilateral development bank, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure, provided the MDB is one of the listed qualifying MDBs (including, for example, members of The World Bank Group such as IBRD, MIGA, and IFC, as well as ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB, and CEDB) [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. In parallel, the Authorised Person is permitted to recognise guarantees as credit risk mitigation where the guarantee is provided by an eligible guarantor, and the eligible guarantor categories expressly include the MDBs referenced for this purpose [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]. Accordingly, for exposures involving qualifying MDBs, the compliance outcome combines (i) the mandatory application of the 0% risk weight to CR Exposures to the qualifying MDBs and (ii) the discretionary ability to recognise guarantees when they are provided by eligible guarantors that include the relevant MDB category, subject to the Authorised Person’s decision to use that recognition as part of its credit risk mitigation approach.
