answer_spans.text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class.

question: If an Authorised Person has a credit exposure to one of the listed MDBs, what risk weight must be used, and can the Authorised Person also treat an MDB-provided guarantee as an eligible guarantee for credit risk mitigation?
expected_answer: For a CR Exposure to an MDB that is on the qualifying list, an Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. The qualifying list includes specific MDBs such as The World Bank Group (IBRD, MIGA, and IFC), ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB, and CEDB. Separately, the Authorised Person may recognise guarantees as a form of credit risk mitigation when the guarantee is provided by an eligible guarantor, and the eligible guarantor categories include MDBs for this purpose [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]. Putting these together, the rule set requires the 0% risk weight outcome for exposures to the qualifying MDBs, while also allowing (but not requiring) the Authorised Person to recognise an MDB-provided guarantee as eligible credit risk mitigation where it chooses to rely on that guarantee and the guarantor falls within the eligible MDB category.

question: When a Fund Manager proposes to remove and replace the Trustee of an Investment Trust, what independence condition must the replacement Trustee satisfy in relation to the Fund Manager, and what submissions must be provided so the Regulator may grant approval for the replacement?
expected_answer: In seeking to replace a Trustee, the Fund Manager must ensure the proposed replacement Trustee satisfies the independence requirement applicable to a Trustee of an Investment Trust, meaning the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager and must not fall within any of the specified non-independence relationships (including cross-shareholdings or voting rights, common holding company arrangements, overlapping Directors on the Governing Body, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings within the previous two years other than acting in their respective roles) [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. The Regulator is permitted to grant approval for the replacement only after it has received a written notice from the Fund Manager stating its intention to remove the Trustee, together with either a certification that the removal will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In addition, the Regulator must receive the written consent of the person agreeing to act as the replacement Trustee, and that person must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as the replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

answer_spans.text: The Trustee of an Investment Trust must be independent of the Fund Manager of that Investment Trust

question: If the Regulator is asked to approve a replacement of a Trustee, how must the Fund Manager demonstrate that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager, and what alternative Unitholder or certification pathway can support the approval request?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager must structure the replacement so that the incoming Trustee is independent of the Fund Manager of that Investment Trust, and therefore does not have any of the disqualifying connections that make a Trustee not independent—such as either party holding Shares or exercising voting rights in the other, having a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, sharing Directors across their Governing Bodies, sharing individuals performing Controlled Functions, or having had professional or material business dealings in the previous two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. For the Regulator to be able to grant approval, the Fund Manager must submit a written notice of its intention to remove the Trustee and then satisfy one of two alternative pathways: either provide a certification addressing adverse impact on Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or obtain and provide a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. The approval request must also include the written consent of the proposed replacement Trustee, and the proposed replacement must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act in that role [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: If a Fund Manager wants to replace the Trustee, what must be true about the new Trustee’s independence from the Fund Manager, and what documents must the Regulator receive before it can approve the replacement?
expected_answer: The replacement Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager of the Investment Trust, meaning the Trustee cannot have certain close links with the Fund Manager. In particular, independence is not met if the Fund Manager or the Trustee holds Shares or voting rights in the other, if they share a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, if they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, if they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or if they have had professional or material business dealings in the previous two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. Separately, the Regulator may approve the replacement only after receiving specific submissions: a written notice from the Fund Manager stating its intention to remove the Trustee, plus either (i) a certification that the removal will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. The Regulator must also receive the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee, and that person must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: When changing a Trustee, what must the Fund Manager check to avoid a non-independent Trustee relationship, and what are the two ways (certification or Unitholder vote) to support the Regulator’s approval?
expected_answer: Before proposing a replacement, the Fund Manager must check that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager for that Investment Trust. The Trustee will not be independent if there are cross-holdings of Shares or voting rights, a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, overlapping Directors on each other’s Governing Bodies, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings in the last two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. To obtain the Regulator’s approval to replace the Trustee, the Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice of its intention to remove the Trustee and then follow one of two routes: provide a certification that the change will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or provide a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In all cases, the Regulator must also receive the written consent of the proposed replacement Trustee, and the proposed replacement must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is permitted to pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what specific record relating to that permission must be included in the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack, and what condition must be satisfied before the payment is allowed?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent only if it has first carried out a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and, on reasonable grounds, concluded that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. In parallel, because the Authorised Person is conducting Investment Business, it must ensure its Resolution Pack includes the records evidencing the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent (and the related acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money) so that the basis for using the Third-Party Agent is documented and retrievable as part of the Resolution Pack contents [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Read together, the permission to transfer Client Money is conditional on completing and documenting the prior suitability assessment, and the Resolution Pack obligation requires that the assessment record (and associated acknowledgement record) is maintained within the specified pack to support oversight and resolution readiness.

expected_answer: Before an Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, it must complete a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and reach a reasonable, evidence-based conclusion that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. Separately, because the Authorised Person is conducting Investment Business, it must include in its Resolution Pack the records that relate to the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Putting these together, the “can pay Client Money to a Third-Party Agent” permission depends on doing the assessment first, and the “must include records in the Resolution Pack” requirement means the Authorised Person needs to keep the assessment record (and the related acknowledgement record) in the Resolution Pack so there is a clear audit trail showing why the Third-Party Agent was considered suitable.

question: When an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight, how must the Authorised Person apply the prohibition on incurring a Large Exposure above the Tier 1 percentage cap after recognising eligible CRM—specifically, is it prohibited to treat the entire Exposure as exempt, or only the guaranteed portion?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated conditions, its Trading Book) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Where an Exposure is partially guaranteed by the Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would be assigned a lower risk weight, the exemption is limited: only the part of the Exposure that is subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit, not the unguaranteed remainder [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. Accordingly, it would be inconsistent with the prohibition to exclude the full Exposure from the Large Exposures calculation merely because a parental guarantee exists; the Authorised Person must separate the guaranteed and unguaranteed portions, apply the exemption only to the guaranteed portion, and then assess whether the remaining exposure (after recognising eligible CRM effects) would breach the 25% Tier 1 cap. The Authorised Person may also consider other permitted exemptions relating to parental guarantees when determining the final treatment [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].

debug_context.semantic_hook: only that part of the Exposure subject

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: If an Exposure is partly covered by a guarantee from an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution, is the Authorised Person prohibited from ignoring the whole Exposure when checking whether it has a Large Exposure above the Tier 1 limit, or can it ignore only the guaranteed part after factoring in eligible CRM?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated conditions, its Trading Book) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 once it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. The definition of exempt treatment for a partial parental guarantee is narrow: if an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by the Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would receive a lower risk weight, only that guaranteed portion is exempt from the Large Exposure limit; the rest of the Exposure remains subject to the limit [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. So, it is not permitted to treat the entire Exposure as exempt just because there is some parental guarantee. Instead, the Authorised Person should carve out the guaranteed part as exempt, then apply the Large Exposures prohibition to the remaining part (after eligible CRM effects) to confirm it does not exceed the Tier 1 percentage cap. The Authorised Person may also consider other exemptions permitted for parental guarantees when applying this treatment [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].

debug_context.semantic_hook: only that part of the Exposure subject

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: How must an Authorised Person operationalise daily monitoring and control of its Exposures so that it remains within the applicable Large Exposures limits, including the requirement to keep the aggregate of its Large Exposures within the Tier 1-based cap?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must implement a daily process that both (i) monitors and controls its Exposures within the Large Exposures limits and (ii) ensures the sum of its Large Exposures stays within the Tier 1-based ceiling. Practically, this requires the Authorised Person to identify its Exposures and Counterparties (including whether any are Closely Related or Connected), measure and establish Exposure values, and determine Exposure size as a proportion of Tier 1, so that daily monitoring is anchored to current Tier 1 and Exposure metrics [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must also aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or relevant groupings, and identify any Exposures subject to CRM requirements or exempt from the limits, so that the daily control framework reflects the correct perimeter of constrained Exposures [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. In parallel, the Authorised Person must ensure that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, which functions as the quantitative cap that the daily monitoring and control must be designed to enforce [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697].

debug_context.semantic_hook: monitor and control its Exposures on a daily basis

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: What must an Authorised Person do each day to track and manage its Exposures so it stays within the Large Exposures limits, and how does this link to the rule that caps the total of its Large Exposures as a percentage of Tier 1?
expected_answer: Each day, an Authorised Person must run controls that let it monitor and control its Exposures within the Large Exposures limits while also keeping the total of its Large Exposures within the Tier 1-based cap. To do that, it must first identify its Exposures and identify its Counterparties, including checking whether any Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those relationships affect how Exposures must be grouped and managed [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must measure and establish the value of Exposures and determine their size as a proportion of Tier 1, then aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, so the daily view reflects the correct combined risk position [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must also identify Exposures subject to CRM requirements and any Exposures that are exempt from the limits, so daily monitoring focuses on the right set of constrained Exposures [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. Finally, it must ensure the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, which is the overall quantitative limit the daily controls must enforce [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697].

debug_context.semantic_hook: monitor and control its Exposures on a daily basis

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, what must it do to ensure timely discharge and clearing and settlement of parties’ rights and liabilities, and in what circumstances can the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House be treated as sufficient to meet that requirement?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place to secure the timely discharge (including by performance, compromise or otherwise) and the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, insofar as those rights and liabilities relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. In assessing whether this obligation is met, the framework also recognises that the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or a Remote Clearing House can be treated as sufficient to satisfy the relevant standard referenced in the source provision [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. Read together, this means the Recognised Investment Exchange must still focus on the outcome—satisfactory arrangements that secure timely discharge and clearing and settlement—while it may rely on engaging a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as a deemed-sufficient way of meeting that standard in the context of its Clearing Service engagement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820] [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service, what does it have to make sure happens for clearing and settlement, and can it rely on engaging a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as enough to meet that standard?
expected_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge of obligations (including by performance, compromise or otherwise) and the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, where those rights and liabilities relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. Alongside that obligation, the source provision indicates that engaging a Recognised Clearing House or a Remote Clearing House is treated as sufficient to satisfy the referenced requirement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. Putting both together, the Recognised Investment Exchange still has the duty to ensure the arrangements are satisfactory and achieve timely discharge and clearing and settlement, but it can treat the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as a deemed-sufficient way of meeting that requirement in the context of its Clearing Service engagement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820] [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].

question: When the Rules distinguish between an Authorised Person operating as a Branch versus operating as a Domestic Firm, what capital-resources obligations must be met by the Authorised Person that falls within the Domestic Firm category, and how does that scope boundary affect the applicability of those obligations?
expected_answer: The scope provision differentiates which requirements apply depending on how an Authorised Person is operating: one set applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch, while a different set applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. Where the Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, it must comply with the capital-resources obligations specified for Domestic Firms. Specifically, the Authorised Person must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, the Rules, and it must also ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to that baseline requirement that are adequate for the nature, size, and complexity of its business so there is no significant risk it cannot meet liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. The scope boundary matters because these capital and liquidity maintenance duties are framed to apply to an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, rather than to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch, so classification as a Domestic Firm is the trigger for these ongoing “at all times” requirements.

answer_spans.text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources.

question: If an Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm (not as a Branch), what must it do to maintain capital resources and liquidity, and why does the operating category matter for which Rules apply?
expected_answer: The Rules first set the boundary for applicability by stating that different requirements apply depending on whether an Authorised Person is operating as a Branch or operating as a Domestic Firm [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. Once the Authorised Person falls into the Domestic Firm category, it has specific ongoing obligations on capital resources and liquidity. It must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in the Rules and calculated in accordance with those Rules [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. In addition, it must ensure it maintains extra capital and liquid assets beyond that baseline, and those additional resources must be adequate for the nature, size, and complexity of its business so there is no significant risk that it cannot meet its liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. The operating category matters because the scope text makes clear that the Domestic Firm set of requirements applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, while a different set applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6].

question: When a Trading Halt is imposed, what must be observed about the maximum duration of a Trading Halt of the relevant type, and in what circumstances is the Regulator permitted to impose a suspension in connection with that Trading Halt?
expected_answer: Where the Trading Halt is of the type imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, it must not run for more than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter period; this duration cap is a binding constraint on how long that Trading Halt can remain in effect [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]. In parallel, the Regulator is permitted to impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 in relation to Trading Halts, including the ability to do so at any time during a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1, and also upon completion of the duration of a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2 [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da]. Read together, this means that for a Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Trading Halt itself is time-limited as described, while the Regulator retains discretion to impose a suspension during that Trading Halt (and, for the other Trading Halt type, after its duration completes).

question: If there is a Trading Halt of the kind covered here, how long can it last at most, and when can the Regulator impose a suspension linked to that Trading Halt?
expected_answer: For a Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, the Trading Halt cannot last longer than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees it will be shorter; that limit sets the outer boundary for the Trading Halt’s duration [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]. Separately, the Regulator has permission to impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 in connection with Trading Halts: it may impose that suspension at any time during a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1, and it may also impose a suspension upon completion of the duration of a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2 [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da]. Putting both points together, you should treat the Trading Halt’s maximum length (for the Rule 7.8.1 type) as fixed by the two-Business-Day cap, while also recognizing that the Regulator can decide to move from a Trading Halt to a suspension during that same Trading Halt period (and, for the other Trading Halt type, after it ends).

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, what exclusions must an Authorised Person apply, and how must it ensure those required exclusions are implemented without making prohibited fair-value adjustments to remove unrealised gains or losses from its Capital Resources (other than the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition)?
expected_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must apply specific exclusions, including (i) certain increases in equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards (notably where linked to future margin income that produces a gain on sale, and—where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation—net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement), (ii) the cash flow hedge reserve amount related to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value (including projected cash flows), and (iii) unrealised gains or losses on the Authorised Person’s fair-valued liabilities that arise from changes in its own credit quality, subject to an exception where those gains or losses are offset by a corresponding fair-value change in another fair-valued Financial Instrument driven by the same own-credit-quality changes [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc]. At the same time, outside the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition, the Authorised Person must not make adjustments whose purpose is to remove from its Capital Resources unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]. Practically, this means implementing the mandated CET1 exclusions while avoiding any additional, discretionary fair-value “removal” adjustments beyond what is expressly contemplated.

debug_context.semantic_hook: must not make any adjustments to remove

answer_spans.text: CET1 Adjustments.

question: For CET1 Capital, what items must an Authorised Person leave out, and what does it mean that it generally must not adjust its Capital Resources just to strip out unrealised fair-value gains or losses (apart from the limited carve-out mentioned)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must exclude several specified items when it calculates CET1 Capital. These include certain increases in equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards—especially increases tied to future margin income that creates a gain on sale, and (if the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation) net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement. It must also exclude the cash flow hedge reserve amount relating to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value (including projected cash flows). In addition, it must exclude unrealised gains or losses on its own liabilities that are valued at fair value when those gains or losses come from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality, except to the extent they are offset by a corresponding own-credit-quality-driven fair-value change in another fair-valued Financial Instrument [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc]. Alongside these required CET1 exclusions, the Authorised Person is generally prohibited from making adjustments that remove from its Capital Resources unrealised gains or losses on fair-valued assets or liabilities, other than the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6].

question: When an Authorised Person has an Exposure to a Client that is guaranteed by a third party, in what circumstances is the Authorised Person prohibited from treating the guaranteed portion as an Exposure to the third party for purposes of assessing whether it would exceed the applicable Large Exposures threshold, and what conditions must be satisfied for such treatment to be permitted?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from structuring or recognising a guaranteed portion in a way that would allow it to incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM; the Large Exposures limit applies on that post-CRM basis and must not be breached [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. However, where an Exposure to a Client is guaranteed by a third party, the Authorised Person is permitted to treat the portion of the Exposure that is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party (rather than to the Client) for the purpose of considering the relevant limits, but only if the guarantee meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight, and the Authorised Person must treat the guaranteed portion as having been incurred to the third party on that basis [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. In addition, the guarantee analysis must not involve any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure; if there is a mismatch, the permitted treatment cannot be relied upon for limit assessment [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: treat that portion of the Exposure which is guaranteed

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: If an Authorised Person seeks to re-allocate part of an Exposure to a third party because it is secured by third-party Collateral, how does the prohibition on exceeding the Large Exposures cap apply after eligible CRM effects are recognised, and what prerequisites govern whether the secured portion may be treated as incurred to the third party rather than the Client?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceed 25% of its Tier 1 once it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM; accordingly, any re-allocation of exposure via collateral recognition cannot be used to justify a position that still exceeds the cap on that post-CRM basis [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. At the same time, where Exposures to a Client are secured by Collateral issued by a third party, the Authorised Person is permitted to treat the portion of the Exposure secured by that Collateral as an Exposure to the third party, and it must treat that secured portion as having been incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for purposes of considering the relevant limits [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. This permission is conditional: the Collateral must meet the CRM requirements and must be of a type that would be assigned a lower risk weight. If those prerequisites are not met, the secured portion cannot be treated as exposure to the third party for limit assessment, and the Large Exposures prohibition continues to apply to the exposure as incurred [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

debug_context.semantic_hook: treat that portion of the Exposure which is guaranteed

answer_spans.text: Large Exposures limits.

question: If a Client exposure is guaranteed by a third party, when must an Authorised Person not end up with a Large Exposure above the limit, and when is it allowed to count the guaranteed part as exposure to the third party instead of the Client?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM; so even with CRM recognition, the exposure position must not breach that cap [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Where the Exposure to the Client is guaranteed by a third party, the Authorised Person is allowed to treat the portion that is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party (not the Client) for the purpose of considering the applicable limits, but only if the guarantee meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. The Authorised Person must also treat that guaranteed portion as having been incurred to the third party on that basis when assessing the limits. In addition, there must not be any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure; if there is a mismatch, the guarantee cannot be relied on in the way described for limit assessment [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: If a Client exposure is secured by Collateral issued by a third party, what is the rule that says an Authorised Person must not go over the Large Exposures cap, and what has to be true before the secured part can be treated as exposure to the third party?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceed 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM; the limit is applied after recognising eligible CRM effects and must not be exceeded [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Separately, if the Exposure to the Client is secured by Collateral issued by a third party, the Authorised Person may treat the portion of the Exposure that is secured by that Collateral as an Exposure to the third party, and it must treat that secured portion as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for purposes of considering the relevant limits [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. This is only allowed if the Collateral meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight. If those conditions are not met, the secured portion cannot be shifted to the third party for limit assessment, and the Large Exposures cap still constrains what the Authorised Person may incur [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: Where a Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List and meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria so that APP 7 category restrictions are disapplied unless the Regulator decides otherwise, may a Controller also be treated as not needing to be a party to the relevant Restriction Agreement, and on what bases?
expected_answer: Yes, these provisions can operate together, but they address different compliance outcomes. Under the TARGET, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List and either has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Separately, under the SOURCE, a Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any specified condition applies, including where the value of the Restricted Security is less than 10% of the total value of the assets of the holder of the Restricted Securities or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests; where the holder or such intermediate entity is a Listed Entity (or listed on an exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee; or where the holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7 [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010].

debug_context.semantic_hook: Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement

answer_spans.text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction.

question: If the Regulator treats a Listed Entity as not subject to certain APP 7 restriction categories because it qualifies for admission and meets the profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test, can the Controller still avoid signing the Restriction Agreement, and when is that allowed?
expected_answer: It can be allowed, but you need to apply both tests to the right issue. The TARGET says that, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List and either has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of its total assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. The SOURCE separately permits a Controller not to be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any listed condition applies: the Restricted Security is under 10% of the total asset value of the holder or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests; or the holder/intermediate entity is a Listed Entity (or listed on a qualifying exchange) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee; or the holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7 [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010].

question: What must a Listed Entity ensure is built into its constitution to support enforceability of Restriction Agreements, and how does this obligation align with the requirement that an Applicant operate in conformity with its constitution as part of being validly established under the laws of its place of incorporation or establishment?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must ensure that its constitution contains provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, meaning the constitutional framework must expressly support enforceability rather than leaving it uncertain or dependent on external arrangements [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]. In parallel, an Applicant is required to be duly incorporated or otherwise validly established under the relevant laws of its place of incorporation or establishment and to operate in conformity with its constitution, so the constitution is not merely a formal document but a binding set of rules the Applicant must follow in practice [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0]. Read together, the compliance expectation is twofold: (i) the constitution must include the necessary enabling provisions to permit enforcement of Restriction Agreements for Listed Entities, and (ii) the entity’s ongoing operations must conform to that constitution as part of maintaining its valid establishment status as an Applicant. Accordingly, constitutional drafting and operational adherence must be consistent so that enforcement mechanisms contemplated by Restriction Agreements are both permitted by the constitution and implemented through compliant conduct.

question: What do Listed Entities need to put in their constitution so Restriction Agreements can be enforced, and what does an Applicant have to do to show it is properly set up and following its constitution?
expected_answer: Listed Entities must make sure their constitution includes provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, so the constitution itself supports taking action under those agreements when needed [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]. Separately, an Applicant must be duly incorporated or otherwise validly established under the laws that apply where it is incorporated or established, and it must operate in conformity with its constitution, meaning its day-to-day conduct must match what the constitution requires [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0]. Putting these together, the constitution matters in two ways: it must contain the right enabling language (so Restriction Agreements are enforceable for Listed Entities), and the entity must actually follow that constitution in operation (as required for an Applicant’s valid establishment and ongoing compliance). In practice, this means the entity should both draft the constitution to permit enforcement and ensure its operations do not contradict those constitutional provisions.

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that is also an Authorised Person Managing a PSIA which is an Unrestricted PSIA, what exposures are prohibited when considering (i) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group's PSIAus) relative to the Group’s Tier 1 and (ii) Exposure to a Counterparty or related counterparty group relative to Capital Resources, including where the exposure is financed by Capital Resources and/or Unrestricted PSIAs?
expected_answer: The prohibitions operate in parallel and require the Authorised Person to monitor both group-level and counterparty-level concentration limits. First, where the Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group’s PSIAus) that exceeds 25% of its Group’s Tier 1, so any Financial Group Large Exposure above that threshold is prohibited [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600]. Second, where the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties that exceeds specified percentages of its Capital Resources, with the applicable cap depending on how the exposure is financed [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. Specifically, an exposure is prohibited if it exceeds 25% when financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, or exceeds 40% when financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f].

debug_context.semantic_hook: must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure

answer_spans.text: Exposure limits.

question: If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 and also manages an Unrestricted PSIA, what must it not do regarding (1) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group’s PSIAus) and (2) exposure to a counterparty or related counterparty group, and what percentage limits apply in each case?
expected_answer: It must avoid breaching two separate exposure prohibitions that apply in different ways. At the financial group level, an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure, including the Financial Group’s PSIAus, if that Financial Group Large Exposure exceeds 25% of its Group’s Tier 1; any amount above that 25% threshold is prohibited [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600]. Separately, when the same Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties that exceeds the applicable percentage of its Capital Resources [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. The prohibited level depends on financing: the exposure must not exceed 25% if it is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, and it must not exceed 40% if it is financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f].

question: When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, may the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User agree in writing that the regime governing charges for information will not apply, and how does that interact with their ability to agree charges for information requested by the Payment Service User that is extra, more frequent, or sent via a different communication method than the Framework Contract specifies?
expected_answer: Yes. Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are permitted to agree in writing that the specific Rules dealing with charges for information do not apply, meaning they can contract out of that default rule set for this topic [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Separately, the framework also permits the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information provided at the Payment Service User’s request when the information falls into defined categories: it is additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, it is provided more frequently than specified, or it is transmitted using a means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Read together, the parties can (i) rely on the permission to agree charges for these types of requested information, and (ii) if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, additionally agree in writing that the default Rules on charges for information are disapplied, leaving the charging approach to their written agreement within the overall contractual arrangement.

expected_answer: Yes. The texts work in tandem. Second, there is also a general permission for the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information that is provided at the request of the Payment Service User, but only where the information is (a) additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, (b) provided more frequently than specified, or (c) transmitted using a communication method other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Putting these together, the parties can agree charges for those categories of requested information, and—if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person—can also document in writing that the default information-charging Rules are switched off, so the written agreement governs instead.

question: When a substantial additional regulatory burden arises for FSRA and the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or ongoing supervision, may the Regulator require a Person (including an Applicant/Authorised Person) to pay supplementary or additional fees, and what practical step is recommended to manage the fee implications?
expected_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that FSRA reserves the right to impose additional fees where a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it highlights that such circumstances can include a migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange, indicating that fee impacts may arise from increased regulatory work [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET complements this by permitting the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision, which aligns with the SOURCE’s concept of additional burden translating into additional fee recovery [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Taken together, the framework supports the Regulator’s ability to levy extra charges in high-effort or high-cost cases affecting Applicants/Authorised Persons. As a practical compliance step, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, so potential supplementary/additional fees can be anticipated and managed in advance [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].

question: If extra work is expected for FSRA/the Regulator—like when an application or ongoing supervision needs substantial additional effort—can the Regulator charge extra fees, and what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do to avoid surprises?
expected_answer: Yes. The SOURCE explains that FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it gives an example where this may occur, such as the migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET sets out a closely related permission: the Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Reading both together, the common trigger is substantial additional burden/cost/effort, and the outcome is that extra fees (described as additional or supplementary) may be imposed or required from the relevant Person, including an Applicant/Authorised Person. To reduce uncertainty and manage budgeting and planning, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss the fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, particularly where the matter is likely to increase regulatory workload [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].

question: When assessing whether a Digital Settlement Facility has satisfactory arrangements for timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, how may the FSRA take into account the DSF’s clearing and settlement framework, and what is the scope of any regulatory tolerance where a Recognised Clearing House cannot arrange settlement of a particular transaction?
expected_answer: In determining whether there are satisfactory arrangements for securing the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions, the FSRA is permitted to have regard to a Digital Settlement Facility’s operational and governance arrangements across the settlement lifecycle, including its rules and practices for clearing and settlement (and any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), trade matching processes to ensure agreement on trade details, delivery and payment arrangements in relevant jurisdictions, and procedures and monitoring to detect, manage, and respond to a Member’s (or participant’s) failure to settle, including taking action to settle a trade and, where appropriate, applying Default Rules and default procedures [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]. At the same time, the scope of non-compliance for a Recognised Clearing House is limited in that it will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]. Read together, this means the FSRA’s assessment can focus on the DSF’s overall arrangements and controls, while recognising that an isolated inability to settle a particular transaction, by itself, does not automatically constitute a Recognition Requirement breach for a Recognised Clearing House.

question: If the FSRA is checking whether a Digital Settlement Facility has good arrangements to make sure trades settle on time, what parts of the DSF’s processes can the FSRA look at, and does a Recognised Clearing House automatically fail its Recognition Requirement if one specific transaction cannot be settled?
expected_answer: When the FSRA assesses whether there are satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the parties’ rights and liabilities in transactions, it may look across a Digital Settlement Facility’s end-to-end clearing and settlement setup. This includes the DSF’s rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person that provides clearing and settlement services), how it matches trades and confirms both parties agree on trade details, and—where relevant—how it makes deliveries and payments in the jurisdictions involved [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]. The FSRA may also consider the DSF’s controls for settlement failures, such as procedures to detect and deal with a Member (or participant) not settling under the DSF’s rules, arrangements for taking action to settle a trade when a Member (or participant) does not settle, and how it monitors Members’ settlement performance, including any Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]. Separately, a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as failing the Recognition Requirement just because it cannot arrange settlement for one specific transaction [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e].

question: For an MTF (using Virtual Assets), when the notification regime that is stated to apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges is extended to that MTF, what notifications must be made to the Regulator in relation to changes involving Key Individuals, and what are the applicable lead times or prompt-notification expectations?
expected_answer: Where an MTF (using Virtual Assets) is within scope of the extended notification regime described for Recognised Investment Exchanges, it must treat the relevant notification and information requirements as applying to it as additional requirements, and also comply with any other applicable notification requirements referenced in that guidance context [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. In that setting, the required action is to notify the Regulator, in the circumstances noted, about specified Key Individual events and to provide the prescribed information within the stated timing. This includes: (i) if the Recognised Body proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual, notifying at least thirty days before the appointment or election is effective and providing the Person’s name, date of birth, and a description of responsibilities; (ii) if a Person resigns as, or ceases to be, a Key Individual, notifying as soon as practicable and providing the name; and (iii) if there is a major change in responsibilities amounting to a new appointment, notifying at least thirty days before the change is effective and providing the name and description of the new responsibilities [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975].

question: In the context where certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges are stated to apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), what must a Recognised Body notify the Regulator about when its Governing Body delegates Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, and how quickly must that notification be made?
expected_answer: When an MTF (using Virtual Assets) is brought within the scope of the notification regime described as applying to Recognised Investment Exchanges, those notification and information requirements operate as additional requirements for that MTF, alongside any other applicable notification requirements identified in the same guidance context [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. Within that framework, a Recognised Body must notify the Regulator, in the circumstances noted, about governance arrangements involving standing committees where the Governing Body delegates any of its Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, or appoints a standing committee to manage or oversee the carrying out of any of the Recognised Body’s Regulatory Functions. The timing requirement for that notification is “as soon as practicable.” The information that must be provided with the notification is (a) the names of the members of that standing committee and (b) the terms of reference of that standing committee, including a description of any powers delegated to the committee and any conditions or limitations placed on the exercise of those powers [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975].

In that situation, a Recognised Body must notify the Regulator, in the circumstances noted, when it proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual. question: When may the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund avoid appointing a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, given the general obligation to obtain ongoing and at least annual attestation for the relevant portion of Eligible Green Fund Property?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund generally must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but this obligation is limited in scope: it only applies to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager may avoid appointing a third party where the Alternative Attestation Requirement applies. Specifically, a third-party attestation is not required if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, which substitutes for the otherwise required third-party appointment. Alternatively, no attestation is required at all if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark. In that benchmark-tracking scenario, the exemption removes the need for any attestation notwithstanding the general ongoing and annual third-party framework. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]

debug_context.semantic_hook: must appoint a third party to attest

answer_spans.text: Alternative Attestation Requirement.

question: In what situations can the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund skip hiring a third party to attest compliance, even though it normally must get ongoing and at least annual attestation for the part of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in taxonomy-aligned assets?
expected_answer: Normally, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but that requirement is targeted: it applies only to the portion of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The Fund Manager can skip appointing a third party under the Alternative Attestation Requirement in two cases. First, if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund, the Fund Manager may elect to provide the attestation itself; in that case, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party even though an attestation is still being provided. Second, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, then an attestation is not required at all. These alternatives operate as exceptions to the general third-party appointment approach and determine whether the Fund Manager must engage an external attester or can rely on self-attestation or no attestation, depending on the Fund’s status and asset composition. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]

question: When an Authorised Person determines its Credit RWA as an aggregate measure, how must it treat the RWA component for Credit Risk Exposures in terms of which balance sheet and off balance sheet items are included, and which categories of exposures must be excluded so that the CR Exposure component aligns with the overall sum-of-components approach?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s Credit RWA is an aggregate figure made up of separate RWA components, including the component for all its Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), alongside distinct components for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures) and Counterparty Risk Exposures [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. To ensure the CR Exposure component is correctly constructed within that overall sum, the Authorised Person must include, in its calculation of RWA for CR Exposures, any on balance sheet asset and any off balance sheet item [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0]. At the same time, it must exclude from the CR Exposure calculation any SE Exposure and any securitised Exposure that meets the requirements for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation, because those exposures are treated separately under the securitisation component of Credit RWA rather than within CR Exposures [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0]. It must also exclude any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book, so that only eligible banking book credit exposures feed into the CR Exposure RWA component that is then summed into Credit RWA [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0].

debug_context.semantic_hook: Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is the sum

answer_spans.text: Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures).

question: If an Authorised Person is working out its Credit RWA as the total of different RWA parts, what items must it count in the CR Exposures part, and what exposures must it leave out so they are handled in the other parts of the total?
expected_answer: Credit RWA for an Authorised Person is built as a total made up of multiple RWA parts, including a part for all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), plus separate parts for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures) and for Counterparty Risk Exposures [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. When calculating the CR Exposures part, the Authorised Person must include any on balance sheet asset and any off balance sheet item in that CR Exposure RWA calculation [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0]. But it must not treat everything as a CR Exposure: it must exclude any SE Exposure, and it must also exclude any securitised Exposure that meets the requirements for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation, because those exposures are not meant to be captured in the CR Exposures calculation and instead relate to the securitisation side of the overall Credit RWA total [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0]. It must also exclude any Exposure that is classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book, so that the CR Exposures part reflects only the required banking book credit items before being added into the overall Credit RWA sum [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0].

Read together, the Target defines who is covered, and the Source clarifies that coverage does not imply uniform treatment for all covered categories with respect to the Simplified Approach.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project, in what circumstances may a later Production Target disclosure omit the otherwise required supporting information, and what specific confirmations and cross-references must that later disclosure include?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose a Production Target in relation to either (i) the Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or (ii) a material Mining Project of the Mining Reporting Entity (or two or more Mining Projects which, together, are material) [#TGT:9ecca3cb-1427-4279-b104-2bb3d2f1d7f6]. If the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure under the relevant framework, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to that Production Target need not repeat the information otherwise required, but only where the subsequent disclosure meets specified conditions [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Those conditions include: the later disclosure must reference the earlier disclosure that was compliant; it must contain a statement confirming that all material assumptions in the initial disclosure on which the Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; and it must include additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or is based in part on an Exploration Target. These elements collectively define when omission is permitted and what must still be included.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for a material Mining Project, when can it make a later Production Target disclosure without repeating all the detailed information, and what does it still have to say in that later disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is allowed to disclose a Production Target in connection with the Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings, or with a material Mining Project of the Mining Reporting Entity (including two or more Mining Projects that are material together) [#TGT:9ecca3cb-1427-4279-b104-2bb3d2f1d7f6]. If the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier compliant disclosure, then a later (subsequent) disclosure about that Production Target does not have to include the full set of information that would otherwise be required, but only if the later disclosure follows specific steps [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. It must point back to the earlier disclosure, and it must include a clear statement that the material assumptions used for the initial Production Target still apply and have not materially changed. Also, depending on what the Production Target is based on, the later disclosure must add prominent, nearby cautionary statements: one if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and another if it is based in part on an Exploration Target. If those conditions are not met, the later disclosure cannot rely on the omission.

question: Where a Low-Value Payment Instrument is used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, and it is governed by a Framework Contract, what is the resulting scope of the Payment Service Provider’s disclosure obligations to the Payer and what information may be provided in place of the general and transaction-level information otherwise expected?
expected_answer: A Low-Value Payment Instrument within scope includes instruments used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, so the classification is not limited to only one of those use-cases [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]. When such a Low-Value Payment Instrument is governed by a Framework Contract, the disclosure regime is narrowed: the general-information disclosure requirements concerning the Payment Service Provider and the relevant Payment Service do not apply, and instead the Payment Service Provider is only required to provide the Payer with information about the main characteristics of the Payment Service. This includes how the Payment Instrument can be used, the Payer’s liability, charges levied, any other material information needed for an informed decision, and an indication of where the general Framework Contract information is made available in an easily accessible manner [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. In addition, the parties may agree that the usual information for individual Payment Transactions does not apply; in that case, the Payment Service Provider must provide a reference and key transaction details (or totals for multiple same-kind transactions to the same Payee), or, if anonymous use or technical limits prevent that, enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21].

debug_context.semantic_hook: encompass those used in relation to both Payment Accounts

answer_spans.text:
In respect of Low-Value Payment Instruments governed by a Framework Contract:
(a)	Section 19.

question: If a Low-Value Payment Instrument is used for both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, and it sits under a Framework Contract, what does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the Payer, and what disclosures can be reduced or replaced?
expected_answer: Because Low-Value Payment Instruments include those used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, the same instrument can fall within this category even when it spans both account-based and stored-value use [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]. If that Low-Value Payment Instrument is governed by a Framework Contract, the scope of required disclosures is reduced. The general disclosure obligations about the Payment Service Provider and the relevant Payment Service do not apply; instead, the Payment Service Provider only needs to give the Payer the main characteristics of the Payment Service. That includes how the Payment Instrument can be used, the Payer’s liability, charges, any other material information needed to make an informed decision, and where the general Framework Contract information is made available in an easily accessible way [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. Also, the parties may agree not to apply the usual information requirements for individual Payment Transactions. In that case, the Payment Service Provider must provide a reference and key details (or totals for multiple same-kind transactions to the same Payee), and if the instrument is anonymous or the Payment Service Provider cannot technically provide those details, it must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21].

question: When an Authorised Person provides any Regulated Activities, what must it do to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest, and how do the additional requirements that apply to the Authorised Person affect this obligation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must take all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest that arise or may arise in the course of providing any Regulated Activities, including conflicts between the Authorised Person (and its managers, Employees and Clients, or persons linked to them by control) and a Client, as well as conflicts between one Client and another Client, and it must do so as part of complying with Principle 7 [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. In parallel, the requirements applying to the Authorised Person under the referenced rule operate in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder, meaning the Authorised Person must treat the conflict-identification duty as cumulative with other applicable obligations rather than a standalone requirement [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. The Source further indicates that, once actual or potential conflicts are identified, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage them, reinforcing that reasonable-step identification is not an end in itself but part of a broader conflicts framework [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759].

question: When an Authorised Person is carrying out Regulated Activities, what conflicts must it take reasonable steps to find, and how does this fit with the fact that other requirements also apply to the Authorised Person?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must take all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest that arise or may arise while it is providing any Regulated Activities, including conflicts between the Authorised Person (and its managers, Employees and Clients, or persons linked to them by control) and a Client, and conflicts between one Client and another Client [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. The Source explains that the requirements in the referenced rule apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder, so the conflict-identification duty should be treated as an added layer that sits alongside other applicable obligations rather than replacing them [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. The Source also indicates that the Authorised Person is required not only to identify actual or potential conflicts but then to prevent or manage them, showing that the reasonable-steps process should lead into controls for handling the conflicts once found [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759].

debug_context.semantic_hook: take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts

answer_spans.text: Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to spot conflicts of interest involving its Employees and Clients, and what extra controls must it have when it prepares or publishes Investment Research?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 by taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest that arise or may arise in the course of providing any Regulated Activities, including conflicts involving the Authorised Person and its managers, Employees and Clients (and persons linked by control), and conflicts between one Client and another Client [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. In addition, the Source states that an Authorised Person must have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Because the Source also says these requirements apply in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder, the Authorised Person should treat the research procedures and controls as part of its overall compliance framework that supports the conflicts process, not as a separate or optional set of steps [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. The Source further indicates that, once conflicts are identified, they must be prevented or managed, which should be reflected in how the research controls operate in practice [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759].

question: When an Authorised Person becomes aware of a notifiable event that could affect whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller, what must the Authorised Person do, and how may the Regulator use that notification in its assessment?
expected_answer: Where an Authorised Person becomes aware of an event that is required to be notified, it must (subject to the stated carve-out) notify the Regulator in writing as soon as possible after becoming aware of that event [#TGT:3d835145-580b-48d8-94bf-850d0a5b3502]. That notification can then be used by the Regulator as an input to its supervisory and approval-related assessment, because the Regulator may consider whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller as a result of any notification given by a firm, including notifications made under the relevant notification framework, as well as through the Regulator’s supervisory work [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. In practice, this means the Authorised Person’s obligation is not only to report promptly and in writing once it is aware, but also to recognise that the information provided may trigger or inform the Regulator’s consideration of controller acceptability. The Regulator’s assessment of whether a person is an acceptable Controller is made by reference to the considerations set out in the specified paragraph, which frames how the Regulator will evaluate the notification’s implications [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b].

answer_spans.text: An Authorised Person must, subject to ‎(3), notify the Regulator in writing of any event specified in ‎(1) as soon as possible after becoming aware of that event

question: How should an Authorised Person align its written notification timing duties with the Regulator’s ability to consider, based on notifications and supervisory work, whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that, once it becomes aware of a notifiable event, it provides a written notification to the Regulator as soon as possible, subject to the stated exception [#TGT:3d835145-580b-48d8-94bf-850d0a5b3502]. This timing matters because the Regulator may use notifications provided by a firm as a basis to consider whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller, and it may also reach or refine that view through its supervisory work [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. Accordingly, the Authorised Person’s compliance approach should treat the notification as a key regulatory input that can prompt controller-related scrutiny, rather than as a purely administrative filing. The Regulator’s consideration is not open-ended: in assessing whether a person is an acceptable Controller, it will take into account the considerations set out in the referenced paragraph, which provides the evaluative framework applied to the facts disclosed in the notification and any additional supervisory information [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. Prompt, written reporting therefore supports timely regulatory assessment and reduces the risk that controller acceptability concerns are identified late.

question: If an Authorised Person learns about a reportable event that might change whether someone is an unacceptable Controller, what does the Authorised Person have to do, and what can the Regulator do with that information?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person becomes aware of an event that must be reported, it has to notify the Regulator in writing as soon as possible after it becomes aware, subject to the stated exception [#TGT:3d835145-580b-48d8-94bf-850d0a5b3502]. The Regulator can then use that notification as part of its work in deciding whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller, because it may consider that question based on any notification given by a firm and also based on its supervisory work [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. So the notification is not just a formality: it can directly feed into the Regulator’s controller assessment. The Regulator’s decision-making is guided by the considerations it will take into account when assessing whether a person is an acceptable Controller, which are set out in the referenced paragraph [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. In practical terms, the Authorised Person should focus on prompt written reporting once aware, knowing the Regulator may use the report (and other supervisory information) to evaluate controller acceptability.
